description:
The BBQ beef was delicious, the spring rolls were fresh, and when I picked up my to-go order, I was greeted warmly by the staff. Great food and prepared quickly!! 

The restaurant itself is not too large, but has table and chairs and plenty of room. I have loved this place over the years!!
author: Katie V.

description:
Not the best pho I've ever had, but it's the only accessible pho location near me, so I'll take it.  I had the Pho Tai, which was a huge bowl with lots of soup and plenty of noodles!  It was more than what I could actually finish eating.  I asked for lots of basil, extra lime, and some hoisin / sriracha - and this bowl satisfied what I was looking for.

Based on the reviews and what I saw around the restaurant, they're pretty well known for some of their other plate items particularly their garlic noodles so I'll have to try that another time, but it'll do for now ... being the only Vietnamese restaurant in walking distance!
author: Carena N.

description:
Americanized Vietnamese food with horrible service. 

Tomato wasn't even ripe and way too thick while the cucumber was cut unevenly.

I came with my father and asked for a side of broth. 2 servers gave me the weird eyes for asking that question. People next to our table were also shocked by their reactions. Then the 2 old lady servers wanted to charge $5 for a small bowl of broth.

I recommend ordering Tu Lan from Postmates or even better go to Larkin/Clement/Irving. 

7 years on yelp and my first 1 star review. Will never return.
author: Charles K.

description:
It's a great neighborhood spot for Vietnamese food!

My group of 4 had dinner here on a Sunday evening at 7 pm and was able to get seated immediately. It's a small space, so I can see there being a short wait during peak meal times over the weekend.

For a small restaurant, their menu is impressively large, with a wide variety of soups and salads, noodle soups, vermicelli bowls, different types of stir fried noodles, fried rice, and various protein dishes. They serve beer and wine as well.

I was pretty hungry, so I ordered their seafood pan fried rice noodle ($10.95), which comes with shrimp, calamari, imitation crab, and fish cake. Portion size was good and everything delicious. I appreciated that they didn't skimp at all on the seafood in the dish.

It's a great spot for catching up. The restaurant was never too crowded, so my friends and I ended up staying till almost closing time chatting.

Would love to come back again and try their garlic noodles next time!
author: Dianna H.

description:
One of my local Vietnamese spots in the area.

I had a hankering for some vermicelli the other day and decided to check this spot out.  I went to their other location quite a long time ago and couldn't recall the experience other than what I read on yelp.  

Five spice chicken and imperial roll vermicelli was my order.  I thought the imperial rolls were perfectly made and cooked.  Super crispy, stuffed with goodness, piping hot.  The chicken was overwhelmingly thick.  The bowl was large and very filling.  Worth every cent.  Service was also quick and efficient.  

They have a selection of wine and beer although I opted for tea.  Street parking is usually available.  Decent 3.5 star spot if you're a local and want something to satisfy your craving.
author: Jen W.

description:
3.5 stars.
This isn't a place I'd go out of my way to try rather a place I'd go if I were craving some basic noodles and in the area.

It wasn't crowded when I went on a sunday night at 8:50pm and there were quite a few solo diners. We sat at the corner and had a nice view of a row of lighted trees of the 20th st stores. The ambiance is definitely more on the fancy side.

Food for the most part was tasty but they were all very americanized "viet" food. There were only 3 or 4 pho options and a lot of standard items for those who want their fix of panfried noodles/roll appetizers or other "asian" dishes. 

While  items were a bit overpriced, they were quite filling; portions were fair. 

Foods:
Beef noodle soup/"pho": The beef broth was tasty but also too hot at first. Their jalepenos were fresh and added a nice kick. HOWEVER the beef was soo tough/dry... maybe because they overheated the soup? 

Fish clay pot: well seasoned and pretty delicious but became too salty towards the end and rice was extra$$

Imperial rolls: pretty large, not overly greasy, a little sweet from carrot/taro, and came with some vermicilli and picked veggies. Liked it!!
author: Lydia Z.

description:
This place has excellent lunch specials! At about $12 you get a bunch of food!

It comes with a variety of lemongrass stir fried with veggies and your protein of choice, and comes with an egg roll, white or purple rice, sour soup, and a mini salad. It all ends up being a lot of food!

The food taste pretty good as well. I particularly enjoyed the soup because it's harder to find the soup in restaurants, it's usually served at home or at a to-go eatery, neither of which are readily available in San Francisco.

Sure it isn't the best tasting Vietnamese place, but for San Francisco standards, it's a solid choice for great value.
author: Tyler T.

description:
Great food, extremely rude waitress who scolded us for not leaving a tip as we were figuring it out. She snatched the cash from my friend's hand and walked away. 
I've been a waiter. Always leave cash as it's better for the server. I was never once rude to a customer, even on my worst day.
author: Hermes A.

description:
Service is quick and friendly and they have bomb imperial rolls. But overall this place is a true 3.5 stars for me. 

Why I was here // decided to try this place out with bf, since we only live a few blocks away. It was a chilly night and Vietnamese food sounded tasty. 

Dress: I was wearing leggings, a sweater, and black boots while my bf came in a Cal hoody and jeans. This place gave off a slightly more well dressed vibe with lots of middle age men and women dining together. 

Atmosphere // very red...red walls that give off a very red hue to the room. A bit dim. Tables are very close together, so you are intimate with also the parties sitting next to you. The booth seats seemed more spacious than the tables. 

Food // Started off well but it just didn't finish the race for me...
-imperial rolls // 8.75 // absolutely delicious and perfectly crispy. Nice addition with the taro and it comes with a sweet sour sauce, which compliments it perfectly. Starting with this you can see why we were excited..
-hot and sour fish soup // 10.55 for a large bowl (perfect for sharing) // honestly didn't like it. It's called hot and sour but actually it's SWEET and sour and wayyy too sweet. It's like they dumped all the pineapple juice/syrup into the soup. This one ruined my appetite cuz I felt nausea afterward... 
-shaken beef // 16.95 // tender and absolutely flavorless. This made me sad because the beef itself was tender, but there was no flavor....  
-jasmine rice // 1.50 // gotta love rice with everything 

Overall // I only liked 1 out of the 3 dishes that we ordered. I give it a 4 stars because service was super nice and they kept refilling our waters (very attentive). Maybe their noodle soups are better.
author: Emily T.

description:
Love walking to my local pho broth and freshly made veggie rolls with no noodles  lovely woman in charge knows my order 

Growing up in the Midwest, I appreciate when people just greet you and know you ala Cheers & Seinfield

Pho broth is so soothing for the soul, closest thing in Dogpatch / Potrero to a korean girl's bone soup. It's my favorite place to go after a sweaty yoga sesh 
‍
author: Caroline L.

description:
For every year we've gone to the SDES Crab Feed we make sure to run into The City for Sunflower's Garlic Noodles and everyone at our table is always so jealous and comments on our Crab and noodle plate.

Thanks Sunflower!

Four Stars!
author: James G.

description:
No frills Vietnamese food with great portions and value for a restaurant in the city. My personal favorite is the BBQ Pork vermicelli bowl which comes out to a whopping $11 with tax.

Will be coming here again!
author: Daniel Y.

description:
This is pretty much my go-to Vietnamese place in the city at this point -- relatively cheap (for SF!), huge portions, and super tasty. 

I usually (okay, always) end up getting one of the vermicelli bowls, but I've tried some of their fried rice and soups and everything is delicious. The lemongrass pork and beef, though, are the winners in my book. Perfectly cooked, perfectly seasoned, and I'm already thinking of going for the leftovers in my fridge right now. (I'm disappointed I had leftovers, but the portions are huge!)

The vermicelli bowls come with incredible imperial rolls, but pro tip if you're trying to go lighter -- you can substitute them out for fresh veggie rolls! (they're good, but you're missing out on the fried goodness of the imperial rolls)

The low reviews on this place confuse me -- sure, I'm not an expert on Vietnamese food, but I've always had great service here and the food has always satisfied. Definitely worth giving a try, and I know for sure I'll be back again, and again, and again.
author: Gautam G.

description: Worst Vietnamese Food we've ever had. The beef tasted like pork or gum. We couldn't eat it. The wine made your stomach burn right away. And the service was so unfriendly, that we couldn't belive it. Terrible experience and first time in our lifes, that we left without tip.
author: Käthe R.

description: Still my favorite place in Potrero Hill. Love the people that work there, they are friendly and work hard. My favorite is their chicken vermicelli bowl. Portions are pretty large as well. I'm known to call in a pick up order after a 12 hour shift. Every time it's ready in 10 minutes and still hot when I get home. Highly recommend trying this place.
author: Angela D.

description: Flavor is off on traditional Vietnamese dishes such as pho. Use of imitation crab may be the culprit but generous portions of MSG do not help either. Good Vietnamese fare should be light and this place just fails to capture the delicious essence of the cuisine.
author: Harry P.

description:
After two visits I have to say Sunflower does a solid job at serving up reasonable priced lunches that will leave you satisfied

The chicken bowl is spot on and pho is good

Overall Thoughts

I would easily come back again!
author: Eddie W.

description: This place was recommended by a friend. I have to say this place is better than most other I've tried, it's clean, friendly and fast service and the food is delicious. Ordered a Beef Vermicelli bowl and was really taken back by it, the beef was so tender and fresh and honestly the amount of food they give, one bowl can be shared between two people easily. I would like to come back and try Phó to see how it compares to other places. Definitely a place to check out if you want good Vietnamese food.
author: Roman L.

description:
I was like Maria Von Trapp climbing over the Austrian Alps with the Captain's curtain-clad brats in tow as I walked from my car at the bottom of Mariposa at Arkansas to the restaurant at Connecticut and 18th. But instead of escaping the Nazis, I was searching for Five-Spice Chicken with Garlic Noodles, which clearly induced the same level of anxiety and hope for peace and Rodgers & Hammerstein music for all mankind...

Climb ev'ry mountain,
Search high for pho,
Follow every claypot,
Every slurp you know.

Climb ev'ry mountain,
Ford ev'ry beef ball,
Follow ev'ry spring roll,
'Till you find your dream.

Note that I didn't cast myself as the Captain since I wanted top billing. Regardless, I thought to myself that surely Sunflower would offer the same menu choices as Perilla and that my dream meal would not be a problem. But I didn't see it as a combo dish on the menu, so I asked the impatient server if I could switch the vermicelli choice with the garlic noodles. She gave me an emphatic no and told me I would need to pay for two separate main dishes in order to get what I wanted. I was upset much like when Maria found out the Captain was marrying the Baroness who hated the brats because they wore drapes from the Martha Stewart collection at the Salzburg K-Mart.

What would Maria have done? Sing "I Have Confidence" and barrel her way into the kitchen to make it herself? Yeah, not me. I simply shrugged and ordered the $12.95 Five-Spices Roasted Chicken which came out flattened and a tad burnt and accompanied by sliced tomatoes and cucumbers, and a bit of the vinegar lime juice with chiles (photo: http://bit.ly/2o06gJI). It was alright and frankly could have been greatly enhanced by some garlic noodles, but I refused to pay the extra $8.95 for it. Instead I went for the bowl of jasmine rice for a $1.50. I guess nothing is complimentary here. Life is never easy for a postulant nun-turned-Nazi-hunted hausfrau.

To provide relief, I also ordered the $8.50 Shrimp Spring Rolls filled with vermicelli and accompanied by the thick peanut sauce (photo: http://bit.ly/2oG7hJV). This was good and certainly fresh-tasting though for the price, six pieces is usually standard and not just four. I was wondering if they were punishing me for being a solitary diner or just being high maintenance about the garlic noodles. We'll never know. As an added treat, I also got a $2.75 Thai Ice Tea (photo: http://bit.ly/2nGmgyK). No particular reason though I was wondering how far the road was between Bangkok and Ho Chi Minh City. It had the requisite sweetness to blunt the pain of not getting the garlic noodles.

So long, farewell, auf wiedersehen, goodnight. Adieu, adieu to you and you and you...

FOOD - 3 stars...the five spices chicken was not five-star at all though the spring rolls were closer to the top of the class
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...a darkened space not that well laid out
SERVICE - 2 stars...there will be no garlic noodles...and let's cancel Christmas, too
TOTAL - 3 stars...go elsewhere for Vietnamese food more kindly...and musically served
author: Ed U.

description:
This place is one of my go-to places in the city. The wait staff knows me ( and my peanut allergy) by name. Usually always packed but their service is fast and food is great, turnover is quick. Since this place was once a fancy French food restaurant the ambiance is pretty nice. 
This place would be great for a first date. The food is cheap too.
And to top it off - hands down best pho in the city. The beef is cooked perfectly and is of good quality.
author: Stacey B.

description: I jus love all the ingredients looking fresh, rice is not too dry... the rest theres nothing special about the dish.... chicken is so plain.... no flavor... coffee is good though... love how they decorate the place... but its so hot in here... no fan no ac... i wouldn't come back and try another dish at lunch time.... oh and saw the Zagat 2014.... but havent figure out whats best at this place...
author: Michael P.

description:
I felt like something high protein wt lost of veggies but not too heavy and i was thinking about Vietnamese noodle.
 
Actually i'm not a big fan of Pho but i do like vermicelli with bbq pork or grilled shrimps and imperial rolls, so I tried no.24,25 here! 

Amazingly awesome! Only a bowl but made me full but didn't feel too heavy. I can tell that they provide such a good ingredient and fresh 

Another place for Vietnamese food in town you should try !
author: Tiratiwan L.

description: Delicious Vietnamese food! I highly recommend. I tried the beef pho, chicken vermicelli bowl with 2 imperial rolls, and house fried rice. I would love to come back. The service was quick and friendly. Food was a good price. I'll definitely be back!
author: Megan O.

description:
This small but efficient Vietnamese spot in Potrero Hill is legit! Good food, fast service, large portions, at reasonable prices. 

It's almost always crowded but people don't seem to linger, so you don't have to wait that long for a table. You can also place to-go orders. 

I recommend: 
Crispy Imperial Rolls
Rice or vermicelli plates w choice of meat
Hot & Sour soup with pineapple
Garlic Noodles w Prawns
Pho Noodle Soup

Thai Iced Tea
Fresh Coconut water in a coconut
author: Mitzi G.

description:
San Fran is filled with "New Market" Chinese people, a term used for Chinese people who lived in Vietnam for a short while, learned the language/culture. Or Vietnamese people who fled Vietnam during the war and moved to Hong Kong.

With that being said, these people not Vietnamese.. they might not even be New market. On multiple time I tried to speak Vietnamese to them, but they kept speaking English to. All of this is fine, but don't tell me how to eat my people's food then!!

This is a poor excuse for someone who might have picked up a couple of recipe from a Vietnamese cook book and just opened a restaurant for profit. They are 100 percent happy with serving to Non-Asians and making money off of the name of "Vietnamese food"

If you think the food here is good, you've probably never had real Vietnamese food before. 2 stars, at least the coke was real and the rice wasn't off brand Jasmine..

***These are harsh words and though I respect anyone who maybe a self made business owner, you should also be ashamed that you've sold out YOUR Asian culture.
author: Charley P.

description: Some of my favorite food in the city! Vegetarian imperial rolls, garlic noodles, spicy green beans are my favorites and I just love eating here! This area of Potrero hill is so cute.
author: Breanne B.

description: This crew always remembers us and makes me feel like a family member-teasing and all! We love the imperial roll vermicelli and I am obsessed with the lemongrass tofu lunch special with fresh shrimp spring roll and brown rice ...yum!!
author: Liza F.

description: Beef vermicelli too salty, uses tough cuts of meat. Pleasant staff.
author: Inigo M.

description:
Came here for the first time last Friday. It's a cute little restaurant in the Potrero Hill area. Parking is all street parking and it can get busy in the area. 
The restaurant wasn't crowded at all on a Friday which was great and we got seated right away for 3 people.  We got the menus and we ordered within few minutes. One of my friends ordered the pho, and my other friend and I ordered the vermcelli. I don't specifically remember which ones they ordered but I'll go ahead and explain mine lol. We all ordered the spring rolls to share and it comes with the peanut sauce for appetizers and thai tea. I ordered the Five Spice roasted Chicken & Imperial Rolls. Super yummy and delicious. I wish they give you more pieces of chicken though but that's ok. The five spiced chicken is honestly my go to usually or pho when it comes to Vietnamese restaurants. The entire meal was super filling and delicious. Nothing special about the thai tea. Thai tea all taste the same to me and you could never go wrong with it. 
Overall, we all had a good time and the food came out in a timely matter. Customer service was fine.
author: Monica W.

description:
Me and my fiance go here all the time. Atleast once a month. We love the food and the service is always good. If you avoid the peak dinner times, usually there is no wait. 

What we have ordered numerous times:
-Spring Rolls
-Sunflower Crepe
-5 spice roasted chicken with vermicelli
-Grilled Shrimp with Vermicelli
-Garlic Noodles
-Pan Fried Fish Filet (sooo good and I'm not even a big fish fan)
author: Aimee E.

description: Such big portions.  The lunch is so worth it. $12. The soup is sweet sour.  The bbq pork was flavorful.  The garlic noodle could feed 2 people.  Service was great and super fast.
author: Helen L.

description: I come here for the imperial rolls, which are truly delicious and excellent. However, Sunflower is the kind of place that just serves "beef pho", rather than offering a variety like Vietnamese restaurants that I'm used to. I would pick some less traditional items to try, and definitely get the imperial rolls!
author: Christina S.

description:
I came here after a long weekend at a bachelorette party. I was pooped and sick. So I had their sweet and sour soup. It was perfect and hit the spot. Another reason I liked this place was because they were too the point- they weren't trying to be my friend. They brought me food and left me alone. 
Sometimes that is what you want!
author: Julianna I.

description:
Fried rolls shouldn't contain big pieces of bone. This place trying to crack my tooth? What kind of quality control is going on here?? 

I won't eat here again. Careful if you decide to. You might be visiting the dentist.
author: Graham R.

description:
BEST $12 BUCKS EVER SPENT!!!

Lemongrass Prawn lunch special was so amazeballs!!!

It came with a salad, rice, soup, and one of the best fried spring rolls I've ever had.

The food was hot and came out quickly.

Good customer service and found parking quickly.

Definitely coming back!

2 thumbs up
author: A B.

description: I got a large-portioned chicken salad from this tried and true SF business. It is nice location, inexpensive, but the chicken in the salad was a strange substance (definitely not free range organic). Nevertheless good flavors and not bad for under $10.
author: Alex S.

description:
I ordered the garlic noodles with shrimp and the BBQ beef w/vermicelli & imperial rolls. While it was ready in about 10 minutes, it was not good. The garlic noodles were super bland and the shrimp had a weird mealy soft texture. 

The imperial rolls were lukewarm and not crispy. The rest of the dish was subpar.
author: Ri R.

description:
I come here pretty often for work lunch meetings and the workers are so friendly. They remember us and our orders right as we walk into the door, despite them being busy pretty often!

We always start with the imperial rolls to split, and they're pretty tasty. Not too oily. Their fried rice is actually really good even though most people get the pho bowls (which are also tasty and filling). My coworker usually gets the five spice chicken with imperial rolls combination over vermicelli and ANYTHING you order, the PORTIONS are so great! Worth the decent prices for the amount of food you get! 

It does get pretty crowded so if you don't like waiting, I would call to pick-up to save even more time rather than showing up to order take out.
author: Cheri C.

description: Best pho in the city-- you can order beef pho with veggies (great variety of veggies with tender meat)! Our go-to place for comfort food.
author: Joline F.

description: My favorite restaurant in San Francisco! I totally recommend the Curry Chicken with white or brown rice. I also recommend the shrimp spring rolls with peanut sauce. SO GOOD!
author: Marilynnn G.

description:
Been frequenting this neighborhood gem for over a year. The beef noodle soup is amazing....and has been even better the last 2 weeks!!. 

Definitely on par with the other great Vietnamese restaurants of San Francisco.
author: Gary O.

description: The service was good. The food was bad. The chicken was not flavorful and the soup was terrible
author: Moawia E.

description: garlic noodles to die for. it's not dry like those other places. i just get it with vegetables and it's just amazing
author: Annie C.

description:
I ordered a grilled chicken breast and I got a deep fried chicken breast.... I asked the waitress and got confirmation it was the grilled chicken. 
I tasted and it was full of oil.... definitely deep fried. Too bad.
author: Sliman B.

description:
Ive been coming to sunflower for way over 10 years. I lost track. Does any one remember the 16th and Valencia Sunflower? The flamboyant server that used to kick out everyone after finishing.... that place was bad but you had a stupid story to tell your friends. 

This place is my go to since I live down the street. They have the best lunch special out of any viet spot in SF. They don't however have the best Pho. It's still good though. You will like it. Their menu is pretty bad ass. It's clean, the staff is real nice, viet decor, and great value. 

As usual the waits are long and service suffers on Friday and Saturday nights. Like anywhere in SF. Don't act surprised. Have a snack and don't be a hangry hangry hippo.
author: Fredo L.

description: I used to live close to here to be able to enjoy their food. The prices are very reasonable for the quality and portions. I highly recommend the five spice chicken vermicelli. I also got a fresh coconut and it was refreshing. It's a good place to go for a quick lunch or dinner.
author: Latonia L.

description: Order to go on my way into work and the girl who answered the phone couldn't have been more rude and short. So that started off my experience not so great. I ordered the beef soup aka beef "pho" and I wrote pho in quotations because it is not anywhere close to pho. The quality of the meat was horrible. Hard and rubbery with the broth having zero flavor. I also ordered a Vietnamese coffee which was so watered down and no condensed milk that I threw it away after tasting it. Horrible experience and I won't be back
author: Crystal K.

description:
Vietnamese Coffee: actually very tasty. They give you a little drip-cup of coffee and condensed milk that you pour over the ice yourself. It was a really good iced coffee, among the best I've had.

Shrimp spring rolls: I am confused why anyone would eat, let alone make these. 

Barbecue pork: really well-prepared. It's nicely thin-cut, which gives it a lot of texture (read: crispiness) and flavor. It comes with a kind of sweet sauce that compliments the meat well. A side of vegetables and jasmine rice is also helpful. 

Overall, this seems like a great spot for casual dinners.
author: John L.

description: Attempted to order food for pick up and the lady that picked up the line was rude. She was barking at me for every order just for asking to get the next order, and when I tried to ask if she had a certain dish, she yelled at me instead of explaining that she didn't have it. I do wish everyone turn away from eating here if that's the kind of customer service they give. She should be fired! I hung up the phone because who knows if she'll put in my food before giving it to me.
author: Doan T.

description: Great food, wonderful staff, they are attentive, friendly, and quick. Good prices, clean and comfortable atmosphere. Convenient location, good for kids and families. Highly recommend.
author: Zoe M.

description: I love this little place. It is a bit pricey but the food is delicious. The staff is very nice
author: Gabriela H.

description: Sunflower is awesome . Great veggie options, lots of flavor in all the dishes and I think the best lunch special in the city. I get the lunch special, veggie noodle soup and veggie fried rice - all are great. Friendly staff too
author: David G.

description:
By Far the Rudest people ever!! Where do I even begin!!! Four of my co workers and I went for take out. To start off the servers push and shove you and don't say a word. One of the servers even knocked my purse down from the chair I was waiting on and didn't even bother to pick it up or say sorry!! 
Then when it came to paying they only asked for two of our I.D's and when I asked to split one of the orders equally in half she rolled her eyes and said "No"! In the rudest way ever! Mind you she just split the bill for the couple before us! Beyond ridiculous no point of even arguing with someone who hardly understands English!! I Will never come back again to be treated like this!!
author: Ashley G.

description: Came here with co-workers for some dinner. Some dishes were a winner, others were just meh. Favorites of this place include the garlic noodles which were very flavorful. The bbq pork is another winner as well. We also ordered a chicken curry, which was ok.
author: Kenson K.

description: Went here regularly in 2017-18 while we lived nearby. Always quick and friendly. Usually had the pho and chicken spring rolls which are great. Will miss it now we've moved!
author: Nikolai P.

description:
Not the worst pho in the world (3-4 stars) but definitely not the best this city has to offer. More a dumbed-down version without much kick (you'll want to add your own sriracha and hoisin sadly). However, if it's late at night and you don't want to go to Larkin Street, bump these guys up a notch on your list.

So if you ARE going here, GET TAKE OUT. The service is god awful. Even for take out. I've been here a half dozen times, in house and take out, same with a few friends, and they just seem perpetually upset and rude.  Most of us were servers and/or bartenders at one time and we are pretty good patrons. But I was really struggling to even justify a 15% tip (and I almost never give less than 20 after tax). Why so curmudgeonly? I don't know. I personally think that part of Potrero Hill is rather pleasant and it's really nice to see some families going out to dinner. But sigh, not worth it anymore except take out from time to time when it's too rainy/cold to go a few blocks more.
author: Mike V.

description:
The food is pretty good, it's not Vietnamese but a Chinese style of Vietnamese food. The owner is Chinese, and many items are in that fashion.
The food taste good but it's not the place for authentic Pho, and they don't serve vermicelli noddles.
The reason I 1 Star is because the waitresses are racist. First time I went alone and wanted to order for take out. They both ignored me on purpose and after finally getting once attention I got asked to walk up to the bar. No smile, just aggression. She didn't look me in the face as she took my order, just staring down and said the final amount. After ordered she said "wait outside" and pointed at the door. I said ok thanks. 
Maybe she had a bad day, but the fact that when I went back a week later with two of my friends (one Chinese) and same waitress came up, she was super friendly to my friends who are both Asian, and when I was to place my order she got a mean face on. She just starred at me with a mean look as I asked about one of their items. I just ordered noodles to have her move along. My friends could clearly tell she changed mood, and I didn't even tell them about my first experience going there myself. 

I just don't feel welcomed here, and it's a pity cause the food is pretty good
author: Rein E.

description: Their garlic veggies and rice are to die for with the plum sauce  the employees are super nice.
author: Vonny K.

description:
Located in a cute neighborhood in Potrero Hill.  We were craving vietnamese food and this little restaurant seemed to be the only option in the area.  This place is definitely good for lunch or a quick dinner.  We came for an early dinner and the service was not amazing - since this was our first time here, it's hard to say the service isn't good in general, but they must have been busier than normal.  The party sitting next to us even saw our waitress's attitude and commented that they are probably just busy and stressed.  

We ordered Five Spice chicken (special) and house fried rice for 2 people.  They serve really good portions here - HUGE plates.  The chicken was delicious but also a little too salty and had an MSG-like aftertaste.  The house fried rice did not seem too special to me but it was filling for sure.  The portions were so large that we had left overs; it was worth coming here just for that reason.  I always get happy when one meal lasts me multiple meals.  I wouldn't mind coming here again if I wanted to pick up something quick, but the food quality is mediocre.
author: Connie L.

description: I always get takeout here and bring it to my work down the street. I almost always get the garlic noodles with tofu and the seafood noodle soup. The soup has an amazing, complex flavor like a pho, I could bathe in it. The garlic noodles come in a huge portion, and you wont be kissing anyone for a few days after you eat it, but it is delicious. These two items turn into 3 lunches for me, so it's a great value.
author: Simone B.

description:
Average food and pricy service.

My wife and I just moved to the neighborhood and went here for dinner looking for some good vietnamese. My wife ordered an oolong tea, so they brought a tea pot and a single cup. We asked for second cup for me, and the lady said we would be charged double. Never seen a place charging for cutlery. And it wasn't even a bottomless/re-fillable tea pot (at least we weren't asked for a refill). 
The food wasn't great either to make up for the bad service.

Might eat there sometime for the lack of options (unlikely in SF), but we surely would be sharing teacup. :)
author: Amit M.

description:
Got the house fried rice to go. about $10-$11? Portions got alot smaller over the year and there is not as much shrimp, pineapple, and chicken anymore. A bit disappointing. Still good, but not really worth getting since the ingredients aren't there

Shared the imperial rolls, not bad but a bit too oily. Nice crisp but can't taste the ingredients too much since it was a bit too fried

Pho was oily with a bit too much msg, but the noodles weren't soggy. The meat was also yummy.
author: Eva L.

description: I ordered take out today. I checked their website for their current dinner menu and prices. Then called ahead and ordered 1 vermicelli with 5 spice chicken and imperial rolls for $9.95 plus tax. The lady who answered didn't sound nice and first confirmed that I was calling the Potrero Hill location. She sounded irritated when taking my order or she was in a hurry. I was quoted 10 minutes for pick up. I arrived 10 minutes later and my order sure enough was ready along with several other orders for delivery. Portion is huge. The chicken thigh was the meatiest I've ever eaten. Lots of vermicelli. First thing I noticed about the 5 spice chicken was there was no skin. The skin is my favorite part. Because the skin was missing, I didn't get any crispy crunch from the chicken and it wasn't flavorful enough for me. The imperial rolls however was the highlight. It was packed with glass noodles, wood ear mushrooms, taro, carrots and more. The rice paper wrapper deep fried is delicious. I would return and try other dishes.
author: Vinkin Ken T.

description: Always the best.  Good Vietnamese food, fresh taste, quick service, friendly neighborhood restaurant. I love the steamed sea bass.
author: M. B.

description:
Far from authentic flavors, but a good spot if you need clean, hot Asian noodle soup in a pinch.  I'm usually not into fried rolls, but the imperial rolls are unusually really good here.  

Good service and reasonable prices.  I usually order to go.  

And I already mentioned clean broth (no msg bloat the next day).
author: Ania B.

description: Kinnda the only Asian  restaurant around this Neighborhood.  Def acceptable. Coming from garden groove and Westminster in LA, so the standard is high for vietnamese food. But this place does its job. Got the lunch special and it was acceptable. This place gets packed so might wanna come early.
author: IHeartMambo S.

description:
Solid Vietnamese food in Potrero Hill.

I got the BBQ pork vermicelli bowl, which is my go to at Vietnamese restaurants.

The meat was grilled to perfection, my only complaint was that the chunks were larger than I would have liked. The egg rolls were also delicious. However, the bowl contained fewer vegetables than most I've had in the past, and only had a little bit of lettuce at the bottom, and some carrots and radish at the top. Not a generous portion at all. In comparison, the amount of noodles was overwhelming. The dish could also have used more sauce.

Overall, the flavoring of the meat made the dish for me so I enjoyed my meal. Worth a try if you're in the area!
author: Anna M.

description: I saw all the reviews about the garlic noodles and was so excited to try it! However, I am quite disappointed at how dry and bland it looked and tasted. It was definitely a large portion, but I didn't taste much garlic at all in it. I also tried their combination crispy egg noodle (ordered to go) and it was honestly the saddest box ever. The crispy noodle looked like two small fried clumps sitting in a soup of sauce.. soupy and watery sauce. Unfortunately it did not look appetizing at all. I'm disappointed at my experience, but maybe their lunch menu may look more promising?
author: Stephanie C.

description: I've been going here for years.  It was near my work so we went at least once a month for lunch.  Great food and service!  The lunch plates are enormous!  Great prices.  Highest rating!
author: John H.

description:
This is a great little Vietnamese restaurant in the city that serves family style Vietnamese food, rather than just pho.

I really enjoy the combo appetizer Bc you can make your own wrap with the rice paper they provide. The combo is relatively large and two people can split it and probably be full just by that alone. 

I've also gotten the five spice chicken, garlic noodles, hot and sour fish soup and clay pot fish. Dishes run on the salty side, but the clay pot fish was especially salty, so don't think I will order that again in the future. 

The portions here are generally pretty big, and so I'd suggest ordering family style so you can try several different dishes. Definitely value for money for a place in the city.

Come early as it tends to get crowded w/ a line on weekend evenings past 6:30pm.
author: Cynthia X.

description: Love me some sunflowr. This place literally can do no wrong so I'll keep this review short. Try the sunflower prawns. Best thing on the menu. Imperial rolls = bomb. Beef pho = bomb. If you haven't tried this place already...idk what to tell you
author: Sidy F.

description:
TLDR - just passable pho, expensive but will get the job done if you don't want to trek further for more legit Vietnamese 

Meh. As far as Vietnamese food goes, this place is definitely on the expensive side and not quite authentic. It's like the Vietnamese equivalent of "fancy" Thai places like Lers Ros, but not executed quite as well. The place is pretty small so it can get busy pretty easily. The staff aren't the friendliest, but no one really goes into any Asian joint expecting great service. Service is pretty quick though once you're seated and there isn't much Vietnamese (or Asian food in general) around Potrero, so it's a solid spot if you're looking for some quick Asian food in the area.

-BEEF NOODLE SOUP ($9.50) - 3/5
Not sure why this wasn't just labelled as pho on the menu.. The portion size was pretty large, but it was mostly just a ton of noodles. There was a decent amount of meat, but instead of the beef being served more on the rare side and cooking more in the broth, it was already pretty well done. Broth was whatevers too. 

-SHAKING BEEF ($14.95) - 3.5/5
My group got this to share and it wasn't too bad. Definitely more "Americanized", aka covered in some sort of sweet-ish sauce. The beef was cooked decently well. Portion size was definitely small for the price though.
author: Jessie L.

description: Been coming here for years and even though I don't live in the neighborhood anymore, I keep coming back. If you're in the neighborhood, stop by for some great food.
author: David S.

description: Zero vegan options. At least they are aware of it despite the nuance that some of the food is just not vegan because it is cooked in the same oil as non-vegan food.
author: Mike D.

description:
Fast service. Walked in and got table for two quickly.

Wonderful strong ice coffee.

Tip to restaurant : please wait for the customer to finish the meal and then pick it up.Or better ask me if I am done.Dont Rush.
author: Priyanka L.

description:
Great service, quick, and great prices.

We got the 5 spice roasted chicken entree and an order of garlic noodles. The roasted chicken was good and the garlic noodles were very good.

The garlic noodles were huge! We could have easily shared it as an entree. Highly recommend you ask for hoisin and add a drizzle - it needs just a little bit of extra sauce.

I was amazed I got a whole pot of hot green tea for $1.50. There was seemingly only one server who was extremely efficient, yet made you feel like she was attentive even though she was serving a lot of tables.

Far from the best Vietnamese I've ever had, but for the price and service it can't be beat.
author: Lilly D.

description:
Sunflower is very close to our house and our go to when we don't feel like cooking. We always get the same thing: BBQ Pork Vermicelli with spring roll. It's only $9.95 and the portion is a size that I can usually only eat half of it and have the other half for lunch the next day.

The food isn't spectacular, but it's good and consistent. A great place if you want an affordable meal.
author: Casey S.

description: I had the crab fried rice, which is a seasonal dish and perfectly hearty for rainy weather like today's. The service is friendly and fun -- our server comically scolded my friend for ordering too much food and then not finishing it. Hey, the server told her it would be too much food! Oh well, more for her dinner tonight.
author: Teresa D.

description:
We have been here SO MANY times and tried many items from the menu. To be honest, everything was GREAT!!
My husband and I crave for this food at least once a week. 
I always get Vegetable Pho with chicken broth. Five spice chicken vermicelli is also great. Veggie vermicelli is also fantastic. We have tried their veggie options from lunch menu, it was also awesome.
Portions are generous and for SF area, prices are very decent.
Service can be a bit weird but it was never bad, that won't stop us from coming back anyways :)

One last thing ( I promise) try their tofu salad or veggie Vietnamese crepe as an appetizer, you will not regret :)
author: Faranak R.

description:
My wife has a weekly standing lunch date with her classmate here cause its that damn good.  When class schedule permits she picks up the beef pho for dinner... which is amazing... and huge... and still piping hot 20 minutes after take out!  I've driven across the city in the rain to pick it up.  The best pho I have ever had... period. 

My wife has tried a number of their dishes and can't name one she doesn't like.  The ones that top her list are the Chicken Vermicelli with Imperial Rolls and the Chicken Curry.  Put a blindfold on and pick any dish. I doubt you'll be disappointed.
author: Craig M.

description:
Their Chicken noodle soup is very good the rest didn't impress me!
I always order by phone and to go so maybe next time I'll dine in and give their other dishes another chance.
author: Ghiz S.

description:
Pho. Garlic Noodles. Whatever your craving for Vietnamese food this is the best spot on Potrero Hill and possibly SF outside of Little Saigon. Plus it is in a top notch location with some of the best city views right outside the door. Sure, service can be a bit nicer, but most people know the deal with good cheap Asian food.

Come here for the lunch specials and five spice chickens or whatever your heart desires and you'll quickly be hooked to Sunflower's prompt service and great quality for the price.

Cheers!
author: Joseph L.

description:
First of, I wouldn't consider this place "authentic" judging by the choices/names on the menu. Anyway, this review is for their beef traditional noodle soup, only..... or "pho?"

At first, I was taken aback by the choices for pho: beef, seafood, veggie, or chicken. Coming from the east coast, I'm used to the "pho dac biet / special pho" which contains all sorts of meat, tendons, tripe, etc. or any combo. But then I remembered it's not uncommon for pho restaurants to serve 1 choice of beef in Vietnam so I stopped judging and chalked it up to different styles.

I got the beef pho and quickly tasted the broth before adding anything else. Well? It was flat, severely flat. Didn't taste like it's been stewing or simmering in herbs, spices, or stock at all. It didn't have the hearty, fatty, comfort feel that a bowl of pho should have. So after tasting their pho, I definitely wouldn't consider this place authentic. If I were to come back, I'll probably try the vermicelli bowls because those look good.
author: Thao T.

description:
The Vietnamese Crepe (chicken and shrimp) was visually appealing and lightly crisp. They definitely did not skimp on the veggies they offer for you to stuff into your already fat bean sprout-filled crepe. I was pleased they also gave a good helping of shredded, pickled radish/carrots and fish sauce. I was tempted to give 4 stars because this dish was pretty well made.

I was satisfied with my dish but the restaurant is definitely Americanized though the workers appear to be Vietnamese.

I was a bit disappointed by the small menu offerings but it is a small restaurant. I was thrown off by all the English translations of the names of the dishes, but they do offer traditional dishes that I don't normally see at Americanized Vietnamese restaurant.
author: Christina V.

description:
Good place to grab lunch if you're in the area. The menu is varied and there are lunch combos that are a pretty good deal (in addition to the already large portions). I opted for the garlic noodles with chicken, which was tasty and filling - however, it was rather one-dimensional and in retrospect I wish I had ordered one of the combos like my coworkers, which looked a lot more interesting. 

Service is efficient but not the most friendly. Cute/casual ambiance but poor ventilation - the entire dining area was very smoky.
author: Oliver L.

description:
It's a great spot when you want some tasty Vietnamese food. 

Lunch combos are probably the best deal because you get a ton of food for like $10.  I'm boring and I usually like to get my chicken pho.  The chicken is pretty boring chicken but the broth and noodles are enjoyable.  A little on the oily side though.

The pork vermicelli bowl is really good.  Fish sauce is kinda fishy (ok, what do you expect, I get it).

The young coconut.  Well, that's a yes.  It seems expensive because it is expensive but it is really really really quite tasty in my opinion.  Maybe refreshing is more like it.

If you're walking from most places, beware, you're probably gonna have to trek up or down a hill.  But why not get some exercise before eating!  Oh, I don't know if they have air conditioning or not but a lot of times they keep the windows on and it's steaming hot inside.  So yeah it makes eating a hot bowl of pho on a hot day miserable (that's when you get the young coconut and pork vermicelli bowl!).
author: Traci H.

description:
Ate here on a Thursday night at 7pm and we were seated immediately. The restaurant was pretty full and definitely has a good following.

Decent food, but it is definitely Vietnamese food for local white people. Don't come here expecting super authentic pho with all the tripe and meat options. It's got some basic satay, salads, spring rolls, noodles, and friend noodles, and fried rice. I thought my pho was fine, and my friends were happy with the Shaken beef w/rice, and fried rice dishes.
author: L C.

description: Not really a top pick, if you are in the area go to Chez Maman or one of the other restaurants in the area.
author: M K.

description: The pan fried garlic noodles were just boiled noodles with some oily garlic thrown on at the end.  Not tasty.
author: Jes S.

description:
This place is awesome! The servers are super quick to seat you, take your order, and refill your water glass. It really is "no frills", like they advertise.

The Combo Appetizer and Five Spice Chicken are both excellent.

But the Sunflower Prawns dish is hands down the best noodles I've had in the city. They put some sort of sweet sauce on them that is delicious and amazing. The portion is pretty big too. 

I love this place and there's usually no wait. Perfect dinner. They used to have house wine on the menu for $4 a glass, I wish they would bring that back.
author: Rebecca S.

description:
The food here is good, no doubt about that. Most of the waitstaff is great. Attentive. 

But going out to eat, for me, is also about the ENTIRE experience, including comfort. This is where Sunflower lost two stars.

It's simple - other than one other table of two, my friend and I always order more for four than for two... so we asked if we could switch to a corner booth table. The waiter said no that's for more ppl, like 6. I said no prob, how about this table right next to us (for 4). He said no.

We ended up ordering our usual and I couldn't move without dropping utensils or napkins, etc. 

The restaurant was EMPTY for the hour we were there. Check picture. 

The food was good... but not good enough for that kind of bull. Was feeling uncomfortable duration of the meal.
author: S. C.

description: Average pho. Angry servers. Worst soggy garlic noodles of my life. Over rated and too Americanized for my liking. The dumplings though are great. The 1 star is coming from the grumpy server, pho with mostly broth and charge of $2 for an extra lime slice!! How ridiculous
author: Natalia G.

description:
I LOVE this place. Best food ever and the prices are very very good. Don't miss the bbq lemongrass beef. Their dumplings are best when steamed (which says something because I love anything deep fried). Their service is difficult and if you come during a busy time you can expect to wait in uncomfortable conditions. But if you get a table, this place is top notch.

Their hot and sour soup is so fresh. It's pineapple and fresh veggies, not your typical Chinese food type.
author: Peter S.

description: I've dined here many times for lunch and they are consistently delicious. Their lunch specials have generous portions. I usually get the lemongrass chicken. It comes with a tasty pineapple soup, rice (try the brown rice), salad, and a spring roll. There is a lot of garlic in the chicken, so don't make any romantic plans for the evening!
author: T W.

description:
I am in love with their vermicelli noodle bowls! I have been here three times, and I've always gotten their noodle bowls. In my opinion, the portions are pretty big for a $10 noodle bowl, and the imperial rolls they put in the dish are amazing. They're super crispy but also juicy. 

One star was taken off because the first two times I've been here, it took FOREVER for them to bring out my food, which had me thinking if they're actually making the noodles from scratch. My boyfriend had ordered pho, and mine came out when he was almost done with his food :P on a brighter side, their pho comes out REALLY quickly, although my boyfriend said it wasn't that great.
author: Jessica L.

description: Solid option on the Hill. Garlic noodles and pho are two of my favorites but lots of good options, large portions at reasonable (SF) prices.
author: Jason B.

description:
This place next fails to satisfy my five spiced chicken craving! This place is always busy, be prepared for a wait especially for groups larger than 4. 

My go-to dishes:

Fresh shrimp spring roll
Five spiced chicken entree
One of the vermicelli bowls
Shaking beef

I always forget to take photos of my food here. That should say something about how yummy the food is here
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Good vermicilli with imperial rolls
Good broth in the pho but beef was average
Chicken pho not good
Combo appetizer average
Good service
author: Jones T.

description: I come here at least once a week and grab the sunflower prawns with the garlic noodles my favorite dish on the menu very quick and organized place food very filling never let me down if you like Vietnamese food give it a try
author: Sam A.

description:
This is really a cute little spot. Definitely love that it's not your typical Vietnamese restaurant in that the decor/furniture isn't grungy at all, the servers are friendly, and it's not full of flies. It's pretty wide open, and bright with light pouring in from the windows. Sunflower is definitely a winner in the Potrero Hill area!

Got myself my typical bun order here. It was pretty close to amazing. Meat was super tasty, noodles were fresh, and the spring rolls were super tasty too. It just felt completely easy to eat. Felt more like eating a nice refreshing salad rather than a bowl of bun. My friend got their pho, and she seemed to like it plenty, so I guess you can't go wrong with wet or dry!

Perfect lunch spot, especially if you work around the area like myself. Parking can be a bit of a challenge, but if you can get a spot, you can easily find yourself grabbing a nice little meal here at Sunflower!
author: Sean H.

description:
Ordered the clay pot. Came in a metal bowl with a scoop of rice and sauteed items. Was not clay pot. Even the waitress told me it was sauteed and not a real clay pot. It was my birthday lunch and I feel like I got dupped. 
Have had real clay pot at many other restaurants. They need to not false advertise " clay pot" on their menu. 
If you want clay pot don't go here.
author: fritz k.

description: Went here for mothers day dinner. It was my first time here and it was a little busy as exoected, but we got a table right away. Food was absolutely delicious! We have the sweet basil chicken. Lemongrass bbq beef, crab fried rich and a sizzling seafood platter and the shrimp spring rolls. The only problem I had was with the smell of the table...now it looks like a copper table, so it's like we Were eating on one giant Penny. Before the food came all I kept smelling was the gross smells of copper or metal.not sur3 why the selection to have such tables. But everything aside from that was great!
author: Coraline J.

description: This is not fine dining but for what it is, it is great! The price, quality and quantity of meals served are very good.
author: Caesar A.

description:
Not my favorite Viet restaurant in the city by far (the honors go to Le Soleil for fancy Viet and Golden Star for pho), but Sunflower is pretty good, and in a far more convenient location than the others, so that's a win in my book. Dropping in with Alice L yesterday for lunch, we ordered [ Photo: http://instagram.com/p/amKWspwfvO/ ]:

* Fried Tofu - Large slabs of tofu sandwiching a layer of lemongrass. Unless you really, really like lemongrass, I would suggest passing - and even then, I'm sure you can get your lemongrass fix some other way, because the tofu still comes off as rather bland.

* Garlic Noodles w/ Chicken - Given the ridiculous serving size (it's enough to feed two or three), if you're ordering this as an entree for yourself, rather than a side dish, I'd highly recommend spending the extra few bucks for both the meat and veggies. Having just one or the other leaves you with just a bit too much noodle and not enough... stuff. And despite not being as garlicky as I've had elsewhere, this was still fairly tasty!

* Beef Pho - I only had a small bite of this out of Alice's bowl, but, it was pretty good.

All in all, a solid 3.5 stars, and a place I can see myself coming to when I don't feel like making the trek to my faves.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - While the restaurant itself is accessible, bear in mind that this part of Potrero is ridiculously hilly, so be prepared to deal with those steep grades.

Bathroom - Didn't check them out, so no comment.
author: Johnny W.

description: This place is really good (albeit a little expensive).  The portions are good and the service is efficient and friendly.  I will definitely come back.
author: Chris L.

description:
I love this place. The food is definitely a bit Americanized. The menu could use me a little more Vietnamese text (sometimes the English translations are a little confusing). And I'm not sure if the servers all uniformly speak Vietnamese, for what little that is worth. But I've enjoyed every dish that I have had hear, whether it's the rice bowls, the pho, the noodle bowls, the appetizer platter, or the Vietnamese crepe. I came here one time with a group of 6 - they did not seat us until everyone in the party had arrived, but once they did they gave us a secret booth in the back. The decor was beautiful.

This place is slightly on the expensive side by Vietnamese standards, but given the location and ambience, it's not bad. I wish they had given me a little more extra hot water for my iced coffee as well, like other places will do (they were very confused when I requested more hot water).
author: Sidney L.

description:
I randomly found Sunflower on Yelp when I was in the area and craving Vietnamese food.  It was early evening on a Sunday and the place was pretty crowded.  The service was friendly but a bit slow.  I don't really think they had enough waitstaff for how busy the place was.  

Went with a friend and we ordered spring rolls, garlic noodles with chicken, and five spice chicken with vermicelli.  Everything we ordered was good (4/5 stars).  The spring rolls were fresh with big shrimp in them, but the peanut sauce was just average.  The garlic noodles were very garlicky!  The 5 spice chicken was pretty standard.  

Overall if I happen to be in the area again and craving Vietnamese food I would go back.  There is a big menu with a lot of other items I would like to try!
author: Paul W.

description: Sunflower is a neighborhood gem for us! Great food, very friendly employees, and very easy to call in an order and pick it up. The inside dining area is not huge, so we usually do take-out. Pho is outstanding, as well as their spring rolls, garlic noodles, and shaken beef!
author: Hayley S.

description:
They have the biggest fattest juiciest spring rolls ever !!! I know that sounded pretty wrong but trust me they're to die for and super worth the price !!  

The portions are really big here and service is always on point . The server even remembers what I want before I ask. Food comes out in less than ten minutes and environment is really clean. 

My to go Vietnamese restaurant in San Francisco
author: Cassondra G.

description: I'm a new vegan and got a little lost trying to find my options. Sunflower, unfortunately, didn't have a vegan/vegetarian menu so I did some guessing. I felt safe with the vegetable fried rice but didn't get a clear answer when I asked if there were any animal ingredients to be sure. Personally, I didn't like the dish because I'm not much of a mushroom person. I'm still giving Sunflower 4 stars because the service is great and the non-vegan dishes are delicious!
author: Senait H.

description:
Shrimp Spring Rolls ::
Shrimp, vermicelli, peanut sauce 7.95

Shaken Beef ::
A house favorite, tender beef cubes wok flashed in a special garlic chili sauce 13.95

Garlic Noodles ::
Our house favorite, pan fried noodles with egg, garlic
8.5 + $3 for shrimp

The shrimp spring rolls were nothing special. 
The shaken beef was tender BUT really really salty.  It also had a strong bitter garlic taste.
The garlic noodles were just Ok.  It tastes more like chow mein with garlic.
author: Heejin L.

description: It's pretty affordable, but I think I'd rather go somewhere else for lunch. I ordered lunch special #4. The salad was alright, the soup was alright, the actual main course was alright. The meat (beef) was pretty good. The best part was the roll it came with. Everything else was pretty forgettable.
author: Jen A.

description:
We went here for the first time on a friend's recommendation.  We were lucky enough to find parking right in front of the restaurant.
We were seated at a nice window table near the bar.  Our server was friendly and prompt.  To start, I had a lemonade and my partner had a Sprite.
As an appetizer, we split a Vietnamese crepe, which was delicious once we learned that we were supposed to wrap a piece in lettuce with shredded carrots and used the dipping sauce.
For entrees, my partner ordered the seafood pho which he liked very much.  I had the five-spice chicken over vermicelli with Imperial rolls.  It was wonderful!  My serving was so generous that I took two-thirds home and got two lunches from it.
We would definitely return again.
author: Philip C.

description:
My friends and I tried Sunflower on a lark one evening, and we were pleasantly surprised! We ended up getting a bunch of vegetarian dishes including the vegetable and tofu vermicelli noodles, the lemongrass tofu, the garlic noodles with vegetables, and the vegetable potstickers. I would say my favorite was the garlic noodles, but all the dishes were quite flavorful (and I say that as someone who is a diehard omnivore!). 

One downside was that the service seemed a bit brusque; I think the servers were trying to make sure we got our food quickly so they could turn over the tables quickly. It wasn't the worse, but it took away a bit from the evening. However, I would definitely visit again, and I thought the food was great!
author: Keith H.

description:
Nothing comperes to "beef noodle soup"
It is like a drug for me lol, I need it least one's a week, And I know that Vietnam rice noodle soup is good for diet so I love it more.
author: Laura S.

description:
Beef Pho: 4.5 stars
The pho is excellent here.  Noodles are springy, broth is tasty, and beef is tender.

Chicken Pho: 3.5 stars
The broth is less tasty, but very healthy -- it tastes like no MSG. All the flavour of the chicken went into the broth so the chunks are pretty bland.

Veggie Tofu Pho: 3.5 stars

Vermicelli Five-Spiced Chicken and Imperial Rolls: 3.5 stars
I love the crispy luxuriant imperial rolls crunching around generous fillings, but don't like the texture of the noodles and the five-spice chicken is not juicy or tender.

Prices are steeper than your average Vietnamese restaurant but the decor is classy and portions are huge. A respectable lunch spot near work.
author: Letitia L.

description:
One of my go-to places for good Vietnamese food. Located in Potrero Hill which is one of the less busier areas of SF, parking is never usually a problem. This place has always been packed when I've seen it so you may have to wait 10-15 minutes but service is quick so tables clear up pretty quickly. The decor is really nice and the red/orange walls make a very vibrant and lively environment. 

Service: Like I mentioned service is quick, though maybe not the most attentive. Aside from taking our order and delivering food to the table, the waiters hardly had time to come back and check on us. 

Food: Really good! Both times I have gotten the vermicelli bowl (once w/ beef and once w/ the grilled shrimp). Vermicelli bowls tend to be bland, but the meat/seafood always has enough flavor. Wish that the fish sauce they give had a bit more flavor though. My friend got the garlic noodles w/ tiger prawns. They give 4 HUGE tiger prawns along with a lot of noodles (could easily be 2-3 meals). The noodles were packed with garlic flavor. The serving sizes are very generous. Overall great food for even greater prices. It's rare to find somewhere where you can have a meal within $10. Would recommend getting the thai iced tea too!
author: Alysha F.

description: I love coming here for lunch during the week. With only one hour it's tough to find restaurants that can get me in and out in a decent amount of time. The service is quick but I never feel rushed while eating. The food is great too. They have solid options for lunch combinations with the perfect amount of food to leave you full but not in a food coma.
author: Lauren F.

description:
Great place for authentic and delicious Vietnamese food in the neighborhood. I recommend the Chicken Pho and the Pork Vermicelli paired with a beer. The staff is energetic, attentive and quick.  Service is great, food is great and casual atmosphere is great. 

After eating, walk around the neighborhood for small shops and cafes.
author: Tom T.

description:
4 stars for the food, an extra star for the excellent service! 

My husband comes here frequently for lunch during the work week, but this was my first time here. I came for lunch on a Saturday with my husband, our friend, and her one year old. We were seated quickly and the staff was very accommodating to the one year old. They swept up food bits on the floor before we could even get to it and even brought us a kids plate (the plastic kind with sections and fun designs) for her to use. Thank you! 

For food, we ordered the five spice lunch special, garlic chicken, and BBQ pork & imperial rolls vermicelli. All were excellent and very reasonably priced.
author: Kim R.

description:
I came here on Halloween eve and I'm not sure if it was because I hadn't eaten all day, but this place was amazing. It's situated on a cute street in Potrero Hill with sick views of the city. I walked in and was surprised by the pleasant ambiance. I'm used to hole in the wall Vietnamese places but this place had good vibes. I also noticed that the majority of the patrons were white, so I'm not sure how authentic this place is, but you should still check it out. 

On to the food - we ordered the imperial roll & pork vermicelli dish, a beef pho soup, and the clay pot special. Holy moly, it was delicious and the portions were huge. One of the Cantonese speaking waiters even said "wah, too much food" as he passed by. My boyfriend really liked the savory, sizzling clay pot and I really enjoyed the beef pho. However, the beef pho doesn't compare to other places in the bay like Golden Star. It's missing some tendon and tripe!

Overall, we had a great meal. I would definitely come back here again and check out the area. You should probably take an uber here since it's located on a pretty steep hill.
author: Joyce S.

description: Had the Vietnamese crepe, which was great for about $10 for lunch.  Like the beef pho here, very friendly staff and a much quieter location up here in Potrero Hill.  Plenty of seating, super casual place that seems to do a large amount of takeout, given the continuous foot traffic that comes in to pickup their orders.  Solid casual Vietnamese food.
author: Albert C.

description:
Great food. I recommend the Lemongrass chicken!
Friendly and fast service. Cute, small place.
author: Nancy K.

description: I've had mixed experiences with Sunflower. I live in the neighborhood and it has definitely been better dining-in compared to ordering togo. The noodle soup is great. I ordered vermicelli noodles with shrimp tonight ($10.50+) and received a pile of noodles with only 4 small shrimp and a crispy roll. The ratio of noodles to meat was ridiculous. I do not feel that I got the value I was expecting.
author: Tessa J.

description:
um.... Dont think I will return...Ever.
Came in during my lunch break a few weeks ago with my coworker because I was craving something soupy and this was a few blocks away. 
From service to food, it was all a nightmare. I got pho and she got the garlic noodles. Its rare for me to say a bowl of pho is bad.. the pho was bad. The broth was sweet?? My coworker's garlic noodles were bare and boring and under seasoned. 
The male server is VERY rude. From the reviews I glanced at,Im not the only one that feels that way. I mean, I understand Asian places are not known for superb service, but it was a little ridiculous. He kept rushing us throughout our meal and seemed to have skipped out on manner lessons.
author: Jess L.

description:
Pretty unfriendly, rude waiters. I ordered something to go and waited FOREVER for it. I politely asked a couple times when it would be ready, and all I got were abrasive, snappy comments that it was still being made. 

No smiles, just lots of side-eye and an annoyed tone.

The cherry on top? What I ordered wasn't even good.

Would not repeat.
author: Yanni L.

description: Really tender shaken beef I think it's called. The garlic noodles and prawn was awesome.
author: Dean K.

description:
My boyfriend lives in Potrero Hill and most of the time, we order take out. Take out is efficient, and the food is packed well for us to enjoy at home. Decent price point for the area as well. This past sunday afternoon, I wanted to dine in. We had beat the lunch rush, but for some reason people that were seated after us received their beef noodle soups before us. After waiting a least 20 minutes, our noodle soups finally arrived, but it was only because we had asked the waitress where the order was (she forgot). By that point, the beef was overcooked and tough, and i noticed the noodle portion was smaller than usual.  The waitress apologized as I was paying the bill, but I didn't think it was very sincere. 

I'll stick to my to go orders for this place.
author: katrina c.

description:
DO NOT EVER COME TO THIS RESTAURANT!
The employees are bit*chy, even the boss!
Food are overpriced!
And a side note, the manager doesn't even give all the tips to the employees that they deserved, he took most of them!!
author: X L.

description: mediocre vietnamese at best. good for when we need a quick pho fix (chay and ga, specifically), but have been unimpressed by the curry items, the garlic noodles, and the garlic vegetables and eggplant as well. they give alot of food, but our leftovers needed a lot of culinary doctoring to be enticing the next day. we will no doubt eat here again because proximity, but certainly not someplace we'd deliberately seek out.
author: Archana P.

description: Sunflower is great.  Ive seen a few reviews that didn't think so highly of this place.  Here is what I would say as someone who eats here often.  Yes the staff is prompt and can make you feel rushed.  This is not them being rude as much as it is them being efficient.  It can be very busy and it seems like most people who attend are regular-ish.  The food is super consistent,   always fresh, always quick and always tasty.  Seeing that I come here probably 4-5 times a month I might be a tad biased.  Leslie runs the place and is great.  She is always heckling me which I love.  I literally feel like family at this point.  I haven't eaten the whole menu but have ate quite a bit of it.  Imperial Rolls are amazing, the BBQ lemongrass beef is also a great choice.  The Pho is good,  broth is tasty.  All in all I have to give this place 5 stars.   If you want quick fairly priced food thats fresh and always consistent this a great place.  if you go here somewhat regularly you will fall in love.  After a few visits they will remember you and your orders.  we almost always get something free added in because, well because Sunflower is Awesome.
author: J B.

description: Get there at 6pm on a Sunday since apparently if you go later there might be a line. The people working there seemed like they were in a huge rush as they seated new people every 45mins to an hr per table. The portions were huge, service fast, and the food was good. I would go back again with a group of 4 just to try more. We were thinking about doing the imperial rolls but the portion was 8 pieces and after seeing the enormous pho bowls we decided to skip it. The garlic chicken didn't seem to have that much garlic (flavor or in it) but was a great assortment of mushrooms, onion, chicken, broccoli, cauliflower, snap peas, bell peppers and etc. They give you a lot of meat on those dishes too.
author: Lily P.

description:
I actually cannot believe this place has 3-star reviews. It's excellent.

I work down the block and so had lunch there yesterday. The lunch specials look amazing and for $10.50 you can't beat all the food they give you. I had the #25 bun with pork and imperial rolls.

It was to die for! The imperial roles were soooo good. Very light tasting. But I had good envy of just about everyone around me. During the rush the service was still really good. I look forward to going there again.
author: Sarah S.

description:
I'm originally from Orange County where Vietnamese food is hugeee so after moving to SF I found that there were no real food Vietnamese food spots!!  That's the one thing I miss the most

My bf and I had #25, bun thit nuong with imperial rolls. Price was right (8.95), portions huge, rolls were packed with goodness and fried to perfection. They didn't skimp on portion size! So glad I've found a good Viet spot in the city 

Ohh!! Get the coconut juice and have them pop the top off so you can enjoy the fresh coconut meat!! Soooo good. I had a serious emotional moment right then and there
author: Zara H.

description:
Good things come to those who wait, but good things also come to those who make the trek to Potrero.

Sunflower is a cute family owned restaurant. Somewhat abrasive service, but absolutely delicious food - which I guess in this setting is what matters more. 

Order what you want. Get what you want. Eat great food. I personally love their fried rice, but you can't go wrong with any of the noodle bowls and the five spice  chicken is where it's at.
author: Katie K.

description: Consistent, inexpensive, easy take out or dine in table availability makes Sunflower one of my top Potrero Hill restaurants. For a few weeks in a row I ate here at least 3x a week and I had a chance to try almost everything they have on the menu. My favorites are their steamed sea bass special. It's preparation is really simple (ginger, scallions and fish) and tastes so healthy and clean. I recommend giving it a try. My other favorite is a cubed beef stir fry. It's my favorite dish to have after an intense workout. Minus a star for not having any dessert options.
author: Darin E.

description:
A cute place in the Potrero! I would definitely come back! It's clean, cute and my friend and I were seated very quickly!! We ordered the garlic noodles, and I must say... Best garlic noodles I've had so far!

Parking wasn't a problem either.
author: Majileen C.

description: Lunch time, get a good portion of food and services. I had also tried their meals during dinner time which also all fantastic. Servers are nice and the food took very little time to prepare. I would recommend this olace to anyone sho love vietnames food that prep for American standards.
author: Thyra K.

description:
Menu is just like the 16th & Valencia location's. Decor & ambiance is vastly different; the P. Hill joint is airy as opposed to hot & steamy, has more seating, & boasts a romantic burgundy & black color palette. It's slightly more sophisticated & put together than their hipster-covered sister restaurant. 

Bf ordered the appetizer combo ($12.50.) His notes--grilled shrimp lacked flavor, but lemongrass pork was flavorful. 

I usually come to Sunflower for lunch, where soup, rice, lemongrass chicken, & imperial rolls is $8, thanks to their lunch special. Last night for dinner, I ordered their imperial roll vermicelli bowl (~$9.) Huge portion! I love the sticky sweet fish sauce (never thought I'd utter those words...) Peanuts, scallions, lettuce, carrots--these toppings really add crunch & an interesting combo of tastes. So good! 

Next time I'll get the whole fresh coconut juice ($4.50.)
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Solid vietnamese fare!  Good vermicelli dishes with fresh ingredients and tasty, savory meats (pork and chicken are both excellent).  Imperial rolls are also awesome.

Parking can be rough in this neighborhood.  And take out is always busy!  But, when you eat it, you'll understand why.
author: Kathryn C.

description:
I love authentic Vietnamese food and this restaurant takes the cake! I like everything from their menu but I will point out my absolute favorite ones here - the Steamed Sea Bass is perfectly done every time - never had sea bass this good. Among the vegetables - Lemongrass Tofu is recommended. The Vietnamese Crepes and potstickers are just delicious. Curry Prawns with rice + Hot and Sour soup absolute best combination and my favorite. Highly recommended. 

This restaurant is also in a very good spot of Potrero Hill. Getting to the restaurant and out you will find the beautiful view of San Francisco skyline (no views from inside the restaurant but their amazing food makes up for the view in my opinion!)
author: Sun B.

description:
Not that this place needs another review to confirm it's greatness, but I will contribute anyways! 
What we tried - vietnamese crepe - this was my first time trying something like this and I was very pleasantly surprised.  Crispy in the sides and very moist in the middle, wrapping bean sprouts, served with mint, cucumber, chili sauce - LOVED IT, gimme more... actually - no, please don't give me more - the portions are HUGE! may be more next time!

Also great -their prawn dish - I was not able to understand the exact name of the dish due to server's heavy accent and noise level, but it was awesome.  These were some of the biggest prawn's I've ever seen in my life! 

Everything came out timely, they constantly refilled out water. 
Next time must try (saw in on the other table) self-assembled vietnamese spring rolls! And fresh cocoanut.
author: Marianna K.

description:
definitely an americanized vietnamese place. you can tell when the menu has no vietnamese names of the dish. 

i ordered the beef pho, and it was decent. they do give you the side of beansprouts and stuff at least.

the only irk was how fast they tried to get you to leave. checking in way too fast and often. 

but since it's the closest place near work....will probably be back. seems like the vermicelli dishes are the way to go.
author: Christine M.

description:
Good for lunch, very fast, cheap, and good food. 
They have a menu for lunch for 10$ (or 11$) with a salad, rice, soup, nem and some choices for the main dish. Less one star for the service. You really feel that you too, you need to get out fast.
author: Morgane M.

description:
14-September, Saturday
Watered Down Thai Iced Tea: bland, un-flavorful.. 

Tiger Prawns over garlic noodles: was actually fairly descent, it left me with the exact greasy mouth-feel I was hoping for after eating half of this. Also had a good portion left over for lunch the next day..

I took a small bite of my boyfriend's 5-Spice chicken dish and nearly had to spit it out, it was so Tumeric heavy I only wondered what the lining of his stomach must have looked like after eating that.

I don't think I'll be making any kind of effort to come back here, this place is as bad as the Sunflower in the mission -although that location actually has some downtrodden authentic charm to it as if you're eating in a restaurant run out of ma's house in Vietnam.
author: Ty T.

description:
I've tried almost everything on the menu, with the exception of the seasonal sea bass stuff.

I think all the noodle dishes are good choices with the exception of Crispy Egg Noodle which is only okay. The meat that gets piled into the Garlic Noodles is also only okay. For Garlic Noodles, I think no added meat is best and get your protein fill in other dishes. 

BBQ Pork, Five Spice Roasted Chicken, BBQ Beef are also good but don't really come with any vegetables.

Items prefixed with Grilled come with rice paper for you to assemble your own rolls which is fun.

Things I didn't enjoy were the Clay Pot Special...because I don't really like Chinese sausage and crispy rice.

It's one of the few asian spots in the neighborhood and probably one of the more affordable options. Aperto, Chez Maman, Mochica, Umi being much pricier.
author: Dian X.

description: Good food, basic restaurant. Friendly enough service. Gets lines at meal times but worth it.
author: Sergio M.

description:
First time in my life I have ever walked out of a restaurant!   This review is not because of bad food...we didn't even get food.... just terrible service.
