author: Stephen O.

description: Solid 4 star place. Everything from the 5 spice chicken vermicelli dishes to the noodle soups are flavorful and have big portions. Good for sit down or delivery. Well priced too. Check it out!
author: Carl N.

description: I expected good Viet food here from my coworkers' recommendation. This is one more Chinese Vietnamese restaurant in the city. I am spoiled by authentic Vietnamese food from growing up in Vietnam and lived in Orange County most of my life. I had pho bo here. The broth is so plain and the meat/vegetables are just OK. The fried rice and crab soup here are totally Cantonese. I have no problem with that but I would like more authentic Vietnamese food at a Vietnamese restaurant. Maybe this is just not for me :(
author: Minty R.

description:
There are a few go-to dishes here that are quite good.  Some other items not so much.

Lemon grass chicken, and lemon grass beef are both good. Very spicy and clean sauces.  They like to use a lot of green beans here!

Garlic noodles did not have much garlic that I could discern and were overcooked. Shrimp role was ok but did not have a whole lot of flavor. The soups are somewhat lacking in the broth but are ok.

Service was excellent and the interior was comfortable and inviting.
author: Jeffrey O.

description:
GET THE LUNCH SPECIAL!!!  They are HUGE!  Totally worth it.  Authentic hot and sour soup, and real brown rice.  The fancy kind.  I'm like, hell yay!  So besides the lunch specials, I usually go for the vermicelli bowls and beef noodle soup.  Their Pho broth is actually really good.  Full of flavor and not mmmm so good.  Potstickers and funky, almost like rice crispy treats like, but not really my thang.  And finally drink here.  Real whole coconut, yummy Thai Ice tea or that rodent poop coffee, not bad.  Look up Kopi Luwak if you don't know what I'm talking about.  Service is good, but they could use one more person.  Door is nice, cuz their my favorite colors (black and red).  Finally, get there before noon, or you'll be waiting for a bit.  Just an FYI.  

NOTE: And compared to the Sunflower in the Mission, I dig this one better, cuz the other one is a not a bright, colorul, and service sucked.
author: Janice F.

description:
My friend brought us here the day after a night of drinking in sf, and I thought it was great!  I had the beef noodle soup (basically pho) and was very happy with my meal.  It was filling, and the beef was nice and tender.  My friends got garlic noodles with chicken and the garlic noodles with tiger prawns.  Both looked delicious, but there were a lot of noodles, so I think they ended up taking some home.

Great food, would come back again.

Edit: Oh, and I almost forgot to mention, their service was QUICK.  Like, after ordering our food, I feel like they brought it out to us within a few minutes...
author: Keith C.

description: Unfriendly, curt service and unappetizing food. As a vegetarian, I was extremely displeased to see my veggie and tofu soup contained a piece of chicken! The soup was very bland and flavorless; seems they just used the water they cooked the noodles in. Not recommended.
author: TZ J.

description:
Nestled in sleepy Potrero Hill lies a slightly souped up version of my favorite Mission Vietnamese hole in the wall. This larger, family-friendly joint has a bright, airy atmosphere complimented by plush booths and painted glass lanterns. Plenty of booster chairs make it easy on the moms and pops of the 'hood. 

The menu is almost identical to the other Sunflower, aside from some of the rice paper wrap selection. Their garlic noodles are a must - greasy, savory and oh so delicious. A runner up is the Vietnamese Shrimp ... with another dollop of roasted garlic greatness paired with lettuce, lemongrass and shredded carrot for rice paper wraps.

It's a great spot for a group craving some serious Viet comfort food in this laid back 'hood.
author: Jane K.

description:
I really wanted to like this place... I walk by it every day on the way home and it's just so cute, none of the usual grunginess of Vietnamese restaurants. 
My first visit was really disappointing. I was by myself so I just ordered the Garlic noodles with tofu. Huge mistake. The plate was as bland looking as can be... off-white noodles with yellow eggs with yellow/white tofu. The bites with the eggs were nicely seasoned and garlicky. The bites with no egg tasted like plain noodles and chalky tofu. The whole thing was quite greasy.
For the quality of the food I thought it was expensive...  The service is fast, but unfriendly, eeks!
author: Sylvia W.

description:
Fast and furious Vietnamese food.
Sunflower is the path of least resistance between you and tasty take-out.  

You cannot beat the efficiency at this place.
- 10 minute tops from order to pick-up (for 2-3 dishes)
- Each phone order takes less than 30 seconds
- The lady means business and gets to it fast.  She knows the menu... No confusion.  No need for credit card info.  No endless mumbo jumbo.  Once you are done, you will hear: "What else?  That's it?  10 minutes."  Hangup.  Done.  Love it.

The food is awesome and keeps me coming back.  Some favorites:
- Imperial Rolls
- Sunflower Prawns
- Claypot Special Fried Rice

Dine-in is also great too: simple but warm atmosphere.  Comfortable seating.  Fast service.
author: Thomas L.

description: called for take out, good portion size for vermicelli, imperial roll delicious, as was beef
author: Long C.

description:
Lucky for me I live close by.  It's my go-to place to take visitors or even just to pick up take-out dinner on a lazy night.  So far I've tried their garlic noodles, veg crepe and their lunch specials.  All of them have been absolutely delicious! I especially like the neighborhood feel to this place. It feels like a step up from a mom and pop restaurant, but just below the over commercialized hype.  

Thanks Sunflower, I'm definitely coming back.
author: Lea F.

description:
Garlic noodles, pho, and chicken vermicelli dish are all so, so good:

Garlic noodles: Very simple stir-fried noodles, but the chewiness and toasted garlic flavor are irresistible.

Pho: Nothing like the mass-produced pho a la Pho Hoa in the south bay. The beef is lean and tender, and the soup has a robustness that could only result from hours of boiling meat and spices. With a generous portion of rice noodles and bean sprouts that soak up all the flavor, the pho here is really heavenly.

Chicken vermicelli dish: Can't get enough of their rice noodles. The chicken is well-seasoned and moist.

The red-themed ambience is swanky, bordering on romantic, and food comes out super fast.

I also love their Vietnamese iced coffee. I can't really drink coffee, but I always have a few sips of my friends', and it's creamy and delicious. Very strong though.
author: Jen L.

description:
Beef pho is great!
I always get spring rolls as well. It's hard to find a parking though.

I didn't like garlic noodle.
author: Ryosuke K.

description: Sigh. I really wanted to like Sunflower, because it is so close to my new work place, but it turned out to be awful. I had the lemongrass beef rice with vegetarian Imperial rolls (hmm....Imperial rolls are not part of the Vietnamese cuisine lingo) and Thai iced tea. Everything I tasted, including the Thai iced tea, was off flavor-wise. I didn't think it was possible to get bad Vietnamese food on the West Coast, but all of the items I ordered was actually really awful. Most likely this is due to the fact that all of the waitstaff and cooks are Cantonese (they all spoke this southern Chinese language to each other) and probably do not understand what Vietnamese food should taste like. Sure, there were some ingredients that would be used in Vietnamese cuisine, but these cooks definitely did not know how to balance said ingredients correctly. Definitely not worth returning.
author: DV P.

description: Now their hours say 230 but I just called and the kitchen closed at 215. LOL. They are the goofiest restaurant owners ever.
author: Letty E.

description:
This was a 3.5. 
Food was good, but lacking just enough to keep it from making it to a 4, as was service. A little slow in terms or refills and attending to what we needed and even just getting the staffs attention.
author: Neesheet P.

description:
came here for lunch during a workday... 2 of us went in to get a table and the other one was looking for parking. the asian ladies saw us and said how many. we told them 3... so, they didn't seat us until our entire party was there. i was a bit annoyed because although it was packed, they had a few empty tables available. but whatever. i was actually surprised with the amount of people in the tiny restaurant. after we sat down, the asian ladies were quite nice to us. weird, but true. 

we decided to each order a dish and split them. the claypot was just alright. i felt like the chicken was overcooked and the rice was too soggy and didn't have the crispies at the bottom. they were pretty generous with the chinese sausage and mushrooms though. anyway, i've had way better. the second dish, sunflower prawn. garlic noodles with giant tiger prawns... HUGE dish and it was so tasty! i definitely have to bring the bf here! the garlic noodles are on a bit of the sweet side though. i guess it's a good thing because our breath didn't smell too much like garlic throughout the rest of our work day. for an appetizer, we ordered banh xeo (vietnamese crepe). this one was also a big portion, but i think the beans sprouts overpowered the other ingredients (they also offer a vegetarian version). we got thai iced tea to wash it all down. this place tastes pretty authentic to me!

oh and they also offer a decent amount of lunch specials, so we'll probably give that a try next time. the table across from us ordered vietnamese potstickers and they looked so good! btw, parking sucks!
author: Ann T.

description:
There's really no need to risk magniloquence when you can sum it up in two words. And they are: garlic noodles.

Over a week later and from eight time zones away I'm still dreaming of their simple satisfaction.
author: Miriam W.

description: Sunflower is a neighbor favorite with good food, service and quick seating for lunch. The luncheon specials are our usual fare including the five spice or lemon grass chicken or shrimp that includes spring rolls, soup and salad. Excellent value.
author: Michael R.

description: This place is a fantastic little restaurant, with wonderful Pho and other Vietnamese delights... the staff is courteous and friendly, the service is quick and thoughtful, and the atmosphere is charming and inviting. I almost hate to share with Yelp how great this little place is because I'm naturally a little selfish. You will not be disappointed!
author: Paul N.

description:
I've tried this place multiple times now and have enjoyed each time thoroughly.  This is cheap per P'Hill's standards, but they deliver great service & food.

Last night I had the garlic noodles with tofu and I think it altered my universe.  Salivating about it now (after consuming leftovers in 2.4 seconds).  What's most impressive is that these noodles don't leave a gross oil reside at the bottom of the takeout box.  By no means are they "healthy"...but I feel slightly better about ingesting a giant bowl of carbohydrates.  Nom.

My friend's lemongrass beef was also very good.
author: Helen F.

description:
This place is BOMB!!! take this from a person who DOESN'T like Vietnamese food!!! My friend lives in Mission Bay and is her go-to spot, so she brought me here several times. I have to say, this place is delicious. I LOVE their SPRING ROLLS- meaty, full of that delicious melt in your mouth noodles, and the sauce is delicious. I LOVE their imperial rolls too!!! And I always dream about the VERMICELLI!!! I normally get it with the shrimp! The fish sauce that comes with it isn't too fishy, more vinegar-y which I love. The noodles are the perfect texture and melt in your mouth. It is light and fresh tasting!!! My friend and I also bought GARLIC NOODLES WITH BEEF for our ride down to San Diego and I swear that dish feeds a family of 4 for days! Best value there ever.

I had their Vietnamese Iced Coffee too! It was super bold and creamy. Loved it!

The place is cute and quaint, with nice decor. I really like the painted walls and the seating. It is a great place to have lunch or dinner with your coworkers or your friends. Parking is not bad. I have never had an issue finding parking up to a block away. 

4 stars for pricing though. It is a tad bit expensive for Vietnamese food, so it might deter some folks because they might think its 'bougie' Vietnamese food, but trust me, its totally worth it!!!
author: Annie K.

description:
This place is great. Nothing at all to complain about.

- delicious food
- excellent price, big portions
- SUPER fast service (the plates are out every time within 10 minutes, usually 5)
- good ambience, very clean and comfortable
- short wait (I've never had to wait, always get seated immediately)

Some of the things I've tried that are great are: lemongrass beef, garlic chicken with vegetables, spicy green beans, garlic noodles and various vermicelli bowls.
author: Sarah J.

description: The vegetarian crepe was basically fried pancake dough stuffed with bean sprouts and the pho was cold and bland.
author: Erica D.

description: Five stars. This is my go to place for pho. I always get the beef noodle soup with vegetables & am never disappointed. Portions are huge and you can save the leftovers for another meal! The staff is super friendly and very attentive, even when it gets busy. I love coming here and parking is usually really easy to find too! Did I mention you get a great view of the city when you step outside?
author: Katarina D.

description: I loved visiting this restaurant on a recent trip to SF. The food here is delicious & authentic. The staff is very welcoming and friendly, and the lunch special is huge!!!
author: Rachel B.

description:
Service: 1 *
Food: 2* 
Cleanliness: 2*

I really don't understand how this place got all the food reviews.  First, we got yelled at for sitting at when we arrived because we requested to sit at a specific table.  Then, when someone finally came to is, she was very short and straight to the point (what do you want to order?).  
The food is as food as you would expect from a cheap, whole in the wall place (but not he good type).
author: Thiago S.

description: We were headed to the city, had a hankering for Vietnamese and wanted to try a place we haven't been.  Yelp led us here and it was a tasty stop, indeed.  We both ordered the vermicelli bowls--pork for me and chicken for the Mr.  The pork was well marinated, the aroma of lemongrass very fragrant in the meat.  The five spice chicken, on the other hand, was just okay.  I didn't get a hint of five spice at all.  The servings were large and service was decent.  Sunflower is definitely a place I'd frequent if I lived in the area.  I wouldn't go out of my way to come here though.
author: Thi D.

description: Incredible garlic noodles, for which I admittedly have a soft spot. Way above expectations for such a staple dish though. Nice staff, and complementary chocolate bars for dessert. Reliability and the little pleasures in life bring a smile to my face. If you run to the top of the hill, you'll have earned your dinner and the view of downtown :)
author: Gil M.

description: Their garlic noodles are great and their pho is solid. It's not my favorite Vietnamese restaurant though - those are in the Tenderloin or in San Jose for me. However, for Potrero Hill, this place is great. I've been several times now and it's been good every time.
author: Kelly B.

description: I've been wanting to come here for a while, but the hill you have to walk up can be intimidating. The service was quick and friendly and the food was exactly how I wanted it. I would suggest the Imperial Roll as an appetizer. I also got the chicken noodle soup, which was ok. They didn't have that many choices of soup, but it did cure my hangover. The customers were funny. There were a lot of parents there with kids in their early 20s. Interesting crowd. Good food. Great service.
author: Sophia G.

description:
I go to the 16th St location every so often. I like it fine (good imperial rolls,) but parking is rough. So I thought I'd try the Potrero location.  As I suspected, the parking was great.  Walked in, and there were a few empty tables.  The waitress came over immediately.....and then gave us the talk-to-the-hand thing while she told us to leave.  She was REALLY RUDE.  She said they were closed.  Okay, I get you want to close a little early.  But more than an hour early? Huh.

But all's well that ends well...went across the street to another place and had a great meal.  Wasn't a bowl of ok pho like I was expecting, and cost a little more than I wanted to spend, but hey, the service was amazing and the food was fantastic, so my evening was salvaged.

I will never go back to the Potrero Sunflower.  I will just have to deal with the parking hassle at the 16th St location, where the waitstaff is nice.
author: El B.

description:
I stupidly avoided this spot when they came to the neighborhood, thinking there was nothing for me there since I don't eat white rice or noodles and a lot of asian sauces are sugary. But then I got the plague of the year and was desperate to get better and out of bed. A dear friend recommended pho from Sunflower. More concerned with feeling human again than the impact of the glycemic index of rice noodles, I crawled over and got pho take out. Before I could slurp down the last limey-cilantroy gulp, I felt my body respond and mood lift--I may live afterall! I can breath again! I'm not coughing! I can play cars again with my two year old who was about to ask for a new mother for Christmas! 

When I posted something about my revolutionary discovery on Facebook, I got approximately 147 comments to the effect of "No Shit, genius." The whole world knew about the amazing powers of pho and I'd just joined the party. I've since been back to Sunflower for more and also appreciate their almost instant service, fresh fresh fresh veggies, and reasonable prices. I'm not a vietnamese food afficiando (though I've been a Slanted Door customer since their Valencia days), so perhaps take my review with a grain of rice, but if you enjoy quality food at all, don't pass it by.
author: Gretchen T.

description:
Since I move to Potrero hill I am very excited to try the restaurants in the neighborhood. When we had our house  warming party, some of my friends recommended this place. 
1) food : my bf ordered crab meet fried rice, and I ordered veggie pho and we shared a thai iced tea. 
The veggie pho stock had a clean flavor and they put a lot of veggies and tofu but for me it was a little plain. The crab rice was above average, actual pieces of crab were visible.
2) portion : good size 
you know some asian restaurant's portions are not enough. 
3) price : reasonable
I paid around $25 including tip.
author: SS K.

description:
This is my go to Vietnamese joint when I'm in town. Legitimate Vietnamese food, generous portions and you can tell when you peek in the kitchen, that these Asian masters have been cooking their entire life. Plus the place is always crowded at lunchtime. Hence, I do the pickup and eat at home thing. Food is ready in 10 min. By the time I walk up the little darn hill, it's ready!

Thank you for a little piece of Asian goodness while I am traveling.
author: Grace F.

description:
Good and decent Vietnamese food on the hill for a bowl of Pho and vermicelli bowl on a cold winter night. Centrally located among other eateries on Potrero Hill, I decided on the last minute because it was convenient and nearby.

 The chicken pho broth was tasty with a good amount of saltiness, but somehow the chicken flavor broth had a off tasted to it, perhaps from a package concentrate? Maybe not or its just my taste-buds? I'm used to a broth that has a little fat to it as it was from a whole chicken simmering for hours. Still, its a fairly good chicken pho with tender sliced chicken breast with green onions. 

The chicken vermicelli bowl was also good with nicely roasted morsels of chicken and two Vietnamese rolls. Generous amount of vermicelli with shredded carrots, red leaf lettuce & green onions along with the fish sauce.
author: Wolfy W.

description:
This place is a hidden gem and is 1/2 a mile away from my Tues night basketball game.  It's perfect.  There is plenty of street parking and it doesn't seem like it ever gets super busy where there is a wait.

The menu has lots of options and from what I could tell almost everything looked pretty good.  I had the beef pho and it might have been one of the best I've ever had.  There are probably a lot better dishes, but I decided to try that tonight as a tester.  Next time I will order a few entries.

The service is fast, but almost rushed and they don't seem to like refilling iced teas.  Other than that, had a great experience and will definitely return.
author: Spencer T.

description: Food is tasty, but I'm always thirsty afterwards and I think they put MSG in their food.  There is also a lot of sugar.  For sure it's not traditional Vietnamese food, but we still go there when we want Vietnamese.
author: Andy C.

description:
Great beef pho! I've been looking for quality pho place that A) serves big enough portions, B) is within acceptable pho price range (Sunflower sells for about $7.50), and C) is not tucked away in an alley off the Tenderloin.  Sunflower hits all three.  I would have preferred the squeeze bottles  for the Sriracha and hoisin sauces on the table, but their container method will serve.  It was a bit crowded for a weekday lunchtime. We had to wait awkwardly by the door for about10 minutes, but if I've learned anything it's that all the places in SF worth eating are worth waiting in line for.  

The interior was also very nicely decorated.  A small, warm space in a equally cozy neighborhood.  The owner was also very friendly and accommodating.  Their menu goes well beyond just pho, but it is important to check the basics first.
author: Daniel A.

description:
This place wasn't disgusting but I would say far from good.  I eat Vietnamese food pretty often and this is at the bottom of places I have tried.  We ordered (1) fried potstickers (2) garlic noodles (3) hot and sour soup.

The hot and sour soup was neither spicy nor sour.  It was kind of the inverse of spicy and sour in that it was very sweet (due to a whole lot of pineapple in it).  It is pretty hard to mess up soup but this was pretty bad.

The garlic noodles were super oily and really didnt have anything in there except noodles, so a bit boring after the third bite.

The potstickers were quite a let down as the filling was very bland.

I had gone to the Sunflower on 16th years ago and remembered it being not so great but I thought maybe I just ordered the wrong thing.  Not the case...  The only reason I gave it two stars is because the location and ambiance are really nice.
author: Kurosh H.

description:
Had to check this place out at the recommendation of several friends.  Came here on a Sunday evening at 8PM and the place was packed.  Service was slow and the wait staff either forgot my request (for a straw) or it took a few repeats (for the bill and a box).  We ordered the imperial rolls and the sunflower prawns as mentioned by other yelpers.  

The Imperial rolls were good, but I've had better at both higher end (slanted door) and lower end (turtle tower) establishments.  The sunflower prawns were yummy and came with a plate of garlic noodles.  It's very filling so we mostly finished the prawns.  

In summary:

Service:  2 stars
Food:  3.5 stars
Overall:  3 stars
author: Yvonne N.

description:
I get take-out from Sunflower a couple times per month.

The food is consistent and my phone order is ready in less than 10 minutes.  It is so nice.

My favorite is the garlic noodles with chicken.  

I have had the pho and that is great too.  

Atmosphere and location is cool too.  After your meal you can take a walk around potrero hill and take in the epic views of downtown SF!!!
author: Chad J.

description: This place is great. Good Vietnamese food and the staff is very friendly.  I usually call in my lunch order and drive up the hill.  The food is very delicious and portions are just right. Love the vermicelli and BBQ pork!
author: Ian V.

description: This review is only for the Beef Pho.  I've been to numerous Pho restaurants and the broth here is hands down the best. They give you the beef rare, which cooks inside the broth as you eat, making it a delightful tender piece of heaven. The basil is extremely fresh and the noodles a perfect consistency. Highly recommended this place for the Pho, but I cannot speak to the other food, although the fresh spring rolls are money too.
author: Brandan P.

description:
Lunch for 6

Food: 

Banh' Xeo:   thought the "crepe" was too thick, the ingredients had a surprise - chicken instead of pork. Dunno what they are thinking, maybe lets try to extend the lives of our customers and sacrifice authenticity in the dish ? Accompanying veggies were true to VN form, fresh and plentiful. Nuoc Mam (sp?) the fish based dipping sauce was true to form (although you have to go out of your way to mess this one up).

Soup: 

The kid ordered some sort of soup  (I arrived after the ordering took place, thank the cell phone gods for the convenience) with what seemed like a beef Bouillon cubes broth, rice noodles. Not good. Kid ate maybe 25% and gave up. And this is a kid that I have to be careful when I buy dog treats at the pet store since the kid wants to sample each one of them. Maybe Pho' would have been a better choice. 

Salad:

Shredded cabbage, carrots, mint, roasted ground peanuts, fish sauce
with a choice meat to accompany. Good ! ( gotta like cabbage ). Fresh & basic but tasty.

Service: 

Itsa small place, and the waiter was attentive and had the perfect quality of never looking confused. 

Environ:  

Close quarters. Not unbearable, but when your elbo hits the baby stroller parked at the table next to you as you raise your chopsticks to your lips, you begin to realize how many tables they put in their space.  

Price: thought that the price/value was appropriate, felt the meal was worth the price.Thought convenient parking contributed to the warm after glow.
author: Matsuo U.

description:
Chicken garlic noodles. Delicious.

The service here is amazing!  Very friendly and exceptionally fast.  This is not your typical Asian cuisine restaurant.  The dishes look great on presentation and tastes even better.  This restaurant certainly compliments this neighborhood well.  A well deserved 5-stars.  Will most definitely revisit.
author: Ray W.

description: Food is decent. Service was rude. Kept forcing us to pay for our food mid meal when we weren't even done eating. Place closes at 2:30p they were trying to force us to pay at 2:15 before their "computers close" people next to us had to send their food back because their chicken entree was served cold. Tap water is served and noticeably tastes like sink water. Service people were rude and short with us throughout our meal. Won't be back, especially when there are so many other options for pho in the city.
author: Bobs S.

description: Very good place. Fresh veggies, good service, and clean. Try the garlic noodles they are so yummy!
author: Suzanne B.

description:
"Your Vietnamese place had better be OFF THE CHAIN!"

This said by an extremely hungry dude, after trying to find parking near Sunflower in the Mission on a Friday night, failing, asking if I had my heart set on Sunflower, receiving an unequivocal YES, then driving over to Sunflower's new Potrero Hill location, and easily finding parking.  Grizzly Bear mode in full effect.

After a short wait, I knew exactly what to order:

1)  Grizz loves BOOZE.

So we hit up the wine by the glass.  Not an extensive list but it had what we needed:  Cab Sauv for him, Sauv Blanc for me. 

2)  Grizz loves CREPES.

So we had my favorite, the Sunflower Crepe.  A very crispy rice crepe filled to bursting with bits of chicken, shrimp, and bean sprouts, and accompanied with mint, pickled carrots, cukes, lettuce to wrap everything up in and fish sauce to drizzle on top.  Messy and delicious!

3)  Grizz loves GARLIC. 

So I ordered another one of my favorite dishes, the Sunflower Prawns.  Four huge Tiger Prawns fried up and slathered in a tangy, sweet sauce and loaded up with chunks of garlic atop a bed of perfectly cooked noodles.  Perfect for garlic lovers like us! 

4)  Grizz loves SEA BASS.

Sunflower's version is generously sized and steamed with soy sauce, ginger, and green onions.  He ate it up and while it was good, I thought it was too salty and a tad dry.  Rice was extra.

He said, "Your place was good.  Really good."

THANK YOU Sunflower for turning this:  http://bit.ly/noHYj

Into this:  http://bit.ly/ml1Fw 

(Whew!)
author: Amy C.

description: Lunch specials, lemongrass chicken with imperial rolls are always a welcome lunch at the office. Serivce is very short and not so smilely, but the food will distract you from that. Ordering take out is usually easy and fast.
author: Kari D.

description:
The only thing acceptable was the food. 

My fiance and I had dinner here tonight. One server yelled at me for sitting down, because (1) there was no where else to sit; (2) i needed to check with some lady (that I had already checked in with); (3) the restaurant was loud and noisy. 

I don't appreciate getting yelled at, but I was hungry so I ordered. Mistake. The hour or so I was there, my chair kept getting banged into by staffers, even though it's their restaurant -- they work there regularly and know the layout. I tried to scoot my chair in, so the center support pole of the table was between my knees. Thank goodness my long, long legs on my 4'11" body fit under the table. 

The staff also didn't realize that you don't need fans on when it's cold outside, and that an open door only exacerbates the chill. Finally, they were slow with the check needlessly extending this terrible experience. 

Go to Sunflower in Potrero Hill if you're in the mood for crappy service with your pricey Asian food. (They raised the prices $1-$2 on all the menu items -- Tin in SOMA is a better value with better service).
author: An B.

description: One of my favourite Vietnamese restaurants in San Francisco with the best pho! The perfect place for a good bowl of soup especially when you're feeling under the weather. Very friendly service!
author: Ula K.

description: Wow, definitely coming back!! We ordered the Sunflower prawns because of the pictures I saw on Yelp, and it was SO good! I'm craving it right now. The noodles had a perfect texture and garlic taste. We also tried the shaken beef, which was also tasty and tender. We also tried the crab fried rice, which I was scared to try, but was also very good! I would love to return and try some other things on the menu now!
author: Eli P.

description: This place used to be great but as of June 2015, did something change?  Our favorite manager, Leslie, isn't there anymore and the dishes we order all the time weren't as good the last time we went. New management?
author: Robert F.

description:
I thought I had already written a 3 star review, but guess not.

So, basically to sum it up, I got food poisoning (first time in my life) from one of the following dishes: garlic beef, shaken' beef cubes, lemongrass chicken, garlic noodles.

I called to let them know that I suffered for the last 48 hours throwing up, the works... only to have them deny that it was their food.

how many people ate?
how many people go sick?
what did you have?
how many hours after you ate did you feel sick?
no one else called to say they got sick...

I told them I didn't want anything out of it, they said they'd let the manager know and asked for my number. No follow up.. sucks b/c it was nice to have a viet takeout place in the area..but definitely not going back.
author: Melody T.

description:
I came here with my boyfriend tonight looking for some Vietnamese comfort food. I thought the decor was cozy, warm and inviting, and the service was very fast and efficient.

I was surprised by how generous the portions were. I've eaten a lot of vermicelli noodles, and even at HOME, I never get quite that much meat! Unfortunately, the flavors were just not authentic enough to make the food satisfying for me. I like my Vietnamese food to taste fresh and light with lots of veggies and herbs, but the food here was very heavy. My noodles (vermicelli with pork and eggrolls) were a little overcooked and did not have enough greens (though when I asked for extra, they brought me some right away). I guess the restaurant is Chinese-owned/operated and caters to non-asians, so I would not come here expecting great Vietnamese food. But overall, the food is not...un-tasty, and considering the good prices and nice ambiance, I give it three stars.
author: Jenny O.

description: We visited this cozy Potrero Hill spot for Vietnamese food on a nice night. This little strip in Potrero Hill along 18th Street has something for everyone. Sunflower whetted our appetite. Fresh coconut. Great beers. Excellent selection of seafood. We had the Tofu Salad and the Shaker Beef. My girlfriend enjoyed a fresh coconut complete with straw. We were a bit concerned that the Shaker Beef would be salty, and the server graciously confirmed that it was indeed. But said that it was also his favorite. We decided to try it, I thought the dish was too salty, yet we were warned, so I can't take points away for that. Portions were very generous. Good atmosphere. Not too crowded. We definitely liked it and will return. I will reserve a 5 star rating until we have another opportunity to dine there. The true test of Vietnamese is the Pho! Yet, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend Sunflower.
author: Brian C.

description:
My favorite thing about this place is that you can substitute the fried imperial rolls (that come with some vermicelli dishes) with fresh shrimp rolls for $1. That's my dream come true!!! Also they let you sub white rice for brown rice! Can it get any better than that? 

I ate lunch here. Ordered 2 vermicelli dishes, one with beef and spring rolls combo and second with shrimp and spring rolls combo. I was very impressed. The noodles were perfectly moist and the rolls were super fresh. I can't wait to go back there and try their soups! Saw the lunch plates that other people order and they looked amazing as well.
author: CatsPjs Z.

description: Tasty food, and lots of it.  The prices are very reasonable.  The only downside is the service can be pretty spotty.
author: Shane O.

description:
Like Vanessa W., we were happy to see a familiar face when we arrived at Sunflower. We relied on Leslie to order for us and she did not disappoint. 

Our first dish was the combo appetizer. It comes with lettuce, sliced cucumber, shredded pickled carrots/radishes, re-hydrated wraps, beef, shrimp, spring rolls and rice sticks... all wrapped up to delicious rolls. The beef, shrimp, and spring rolls all have intricate and strong flavors. We were most impressed that unlike other Vietnamese restaurants, Sunflower's wraps were already re-hydrated and separated for easy usage.

Leslie waited till we were almost done with the 1st dish before ordering our 2nd, Sunflower prawns over garlic noodles. We were happy to find that the garlic noodles were on par with (or perhaps even better than) those at Thang Long and the prawns were succulent and delicious. 

Overall, we were very happy with the food and service at Sunflower; prices were reasonable too....certainly a rare combination to find at restaurants these days.  Can't wait to be back!
author: Christine C.

description:
Sunflower offers Vietnamese comfort food at comfortable prices.

The massive pile of evenly flavored Garlic Noodles is teeming with generous, if slightly bland, chunks of chicken breast.  Copious amounts of the appropriately spicy hot sauce enhance each bite without masking any garlicky taste.  

After determining that it would be wiser and healthier to split the meal into two portions and putting the garlic noodles to the side, barely two minutes passed before the intoxicating garlic smell drew me back in for several more bites.  This recurred at least 3 times until the noodles were gone.  I was helpless against the simple, yet powerful combination of garlic and noodles.

Ordering to go is prompt and hassle-free.  Will revisit for a dine-in experience!
author: Andrew M.

description: It's a small place and can be a bit challenging to get seating for lunch if you arrive too late.  It's worth the effort!  The garlic noodles are fantastic!  Staff is nice and they do well by their customers.
author: Theodore M.

description:
This restaurant has always been a delight.  I have been for lunch and for dinner and the meal is simply superb every single time.  My favorite part is the staff always recognized and greet me warmly whenever I enter and make me laugh.  It's a friendly atmosphere and the setting is elegant.

Love it.  One of my favorite neighborhood gems.
author: Mikael W.

description: This place is the bomb. A perfect go-to for all things Vietnamese. Their pho is great (even works to get it to go and you can assemble at home, sounds messy but it's actually quite fun) as well as garlic noodles (so buttery, and you get a giant heaping helping) and spicy green beans. A great neighborhood spot.
author: Elena K.

description:
As good as SoCal pho!  

The lady that is in charge is also hilarious and mean.

I hear that the veggie crepe is huge and tastes great.  I have had the veggie noodle soup (the BEST i have ever had), the garlic veggies, and the curry veggies.  All amazing... so amazing that i haven't gone without going there since i discovered the place.

This location is just as good as the mission one and the parking is free
author: Laura P.

description:
This place is only a few blocks away, so I've been there about a dozen times and sampled almost everything on the menu. I guess I'm not the only fan --- this place is always pretty packed for dinner (make a reservation!) Several things I like about this place. The atmosphere is comfortable, clean, simple. The service is always prompt; even when the place is packed to capacity. The menu has good variety and everything is delicious. Finally, the portions are generous and the price is right. 

You can't go wrong with any of the beef dishes -- big chunks of beef, and it's always surprisingly tender. Other favorites include the garlic noodles (lots of garlic!), and the five spice roasted chicken & imperial rolls vermicelli. If I'm in a pinch for dinner, this is always the go-to place.
author: Laurent L.

description: This review is strictly for garlic noodles. A wave of cravings came up one day and one of them was for garlic noodles. My first thought was perilla on irving, but i wanted to find a place closer to where i live, so i came on yelp for some guidance. Enter Sunflower. Having some people proclaim it as serving the best garlic noodles they've ever had piqued my interest. Actually, it got me really excited. I thought wow, this could be my new go-to spot. I finally got a chance to go, ordered the garlic noodles, and was instantly disappointed. Everything i was looking for, chewy, al dente texture and aromatic garlic flavor were not there. The noodles were soggy and flavor was lacking. I was bummed. I really really wanted to love this place and i tried, but alas the "best" just didn't cut it for me.
author: Melissa Y.

description: LOVE THIS PLACE! Nice people working and they do a phenomenal job at managing each table during busy times. They always remember my order and EVERYTHING you get is good! My favs are: Chicken Noodle Soup and Beef Vermicelli :)
author: Merlino T.

description:
Consistently good food. I've only eaten here as take-out, however, the restaurant itself is in a very cute area. The restaurant is sweet inside and seems charming. I would definitely eat at the restaurant if given the chance.

The take-out is always great. I love the curry vegetables (lots of veggies, nice thick sauce, not too salty). I got the tofu appetizer last time. It was ok. It was large pieces of tofu with lemongrass. I would rate that dish 3 out of 5. 

Highly recommend (as a vegetarian).
author: Jana C.

description: This place is perfect. They have very versatile menu, food is very delicious. We tried beef noodle soup and BBQ pork. Both were perfect, loved it. The staff is friendly and welcoming. Food was served in less than 5 minutes, although the place was pretty busy. Also the inside design of the restaurant is nice and warm. I would be absolutely happy if they gave a candy with check :) Anyway my experience was great!
author: Kira L.

description: I really really really love the Pho here. Runner up Garlic Noodles. Then maybe Five Spice Chicken. Oh but any of their pork or beef is good. Damn, it's all good. I know that doesn't help. What else can I say? This is just really quality fresh Vietnamese food in a gorgeous space in my favorite hood :) You should check it out.
author: Kelly W.

description:
Hmmm... so this is the fanciest of the triplet Sunflowers... but I think they may have sacrificed tastiness for the sake of fanciness.

This one is the most convenient... closest (within walking distance from my place) and the easiest to park... unfortunately, was not so satisfied.

Re: their pho: (1) the soup wasn't very flavorful (did they forget the MSG?) (2) the not-as-flavorful soup = not-so-flavorful noodles.

Sadly, I will have to deal with the parking in the Mission until they add a bit more flavor in my pho.
author: Victor C.

description:
In search of a tasty yet inexpensive restaurant - not far from where we live, we had heard that Sunflower was a good choice.  We have to say we agree.  The dishes are quite sizable and delicious (try the Vietnamese crepe starter - it can definitely be an entree in itself).  We had the crepe, a bowl of beef pho and the lemongrass tofu - all for $30, including tax.  Okay - maybe it's not dirt cheap, but the ambience was nice and it is in Potrero Hill . . .

We'll definitely return.
author: B. Y.

description:
I haven't been here for years. I was looking forward to prawn garlic noodle, but looks like that's no longer offered on the menu. 

Instead, we ordered:
*Garlic Noodle with Shrimp $7.95 + $2 (3.5 of 5) - I thought I remembered it to be liked http://www.yelp.com/biz/thanh-long-san-francisco. I was wrong. This noodle is so much more chewier and bouncier. Reminds me of gummy texture.  Garlic is coarsely chopped and not as fine. And there are bits of scrambled egg stirred into the noodle. Completely different. Not bad, but not as great as I remembered it. 
*Shaken Beef $12.95 (3 of 5) - Tender beef cubes wok flashed in their special garlic chili sauce. Beef cubes were very juicy and perfectly cooked, but I couldn't figure out the sauce flavors and it wasn't that great. I would actually skip this dish next time. The sauce flavor is confusing and not that appealing to me.
*Crispy Seabass about $26 (3.5 of 5) - Probably the most stunning dish. Huge piece of seabass that was first fried. Then re-plated on a sizzling platter and covered with a saucy caramelized mixture of ginger, sweetness, and garlic. Eventhough this dish was a bit pricey, it was worth ordering if you like seabass. The seabass was still crispy on the outside and so soft and flaky in the inside. Reminds me of a krispy kreme donut texture, but for seafood. The special sauce gives it this authentic asian flare. Be warned, the fillet is pretty big, so you can't eat it all by yourself. I recommend sharing with group of 3 of more.

I was pretty disappointed the menu changed and the garlic noodles isn't what I imagined. However, I could see how this local Potrero Hill Vietnamese Restaurant  is still a local favorite. Menu choices are great. Food comes quickly. And great location for Potrero Hill neighborhood.
author: Janice T.

description:
Ehhh, it's alright. The veggie spring rolls were awesome, but I ordered garlic beef for entree and despite it having about 5 cloves of garlic in there, there wasn't any flavor! The beef and all the veggies had the same weird, gummy, half-cooked texture, and it was covered in a watery flavorless sauce. I'm not saying it was bad, it was just sorta....nothing. Order something else, I guess is what I'm saying. My dad has the chicken soap and seemed to like it.

One definite plus is the hostess is HILARIOUS and so sweet and fun. My dad pulled her over before we ordered and said that he had some questions. Without missing a single beat she said "Five dollars each!" She was a riot.
author: Andrea W.

description: Great Vietnamese in this neighborhood. I love their hot and sour soup because it always tastes so fresh, as well as their lunch specials, which are a great deal and come with a TON of food, so it's easy to share.
author: Steph S.

description:
I have never been to the original Sunflower (in the Mission) but I know that Sunflower Potrero Hill is great! I would even dare to say that it boarders on amazing. Living on the other side of San Francisco I made a pilgrimage to the Hill. The warm August evening meant that everyone was out. The space is small but they seem to pack everyone in pretty well. I think that it is best to eat a family style meal so that you can sample as much as possible. I was there with four other people and that allowed us to sample a great deal of food (five dishes in all). It seemed that everything that was brought to the table was presented well and had  a wonderful taste. Every morsel of food was better than the previous one. I think that it was worth the wait. 

The only complaint that I have about the new location is a consequence of its newness. The service can (and probably will) improve. Yes, they are good at refilling  drinks and bringing out dishes. But they are still sorting out their table numbers and it took a pretty long while to get the check. Since that is my only complaint I have to say that this is a pretty excellent  place to eat. I think that I will make many trips across town to sample more of the menu.

OH! I nearly forgot! Once I figured out where this was i realized that it is easy to get there by public transportation. If you can easily access the 22 MUNI line you are set. It is right next to the bus stop.
author: Nicole T.

description:
The only reason we came to this place was because it's close to Anchor Steam Brewery and we needed a place close by to eat and sober up. Worst vietnamese noodle dishes I have ever had. I ordered the bun (which is a dry noodle dish served with bbq meat on top and sauce on the side). I order bun all the time from other vietnamese places and it's never been this bad. The noodles were waaaaay overcooked. They did not give me enough chicken for the price i paid. Other people in my group ordered garlic noodles, which I thought tasted just okay. Again the noodles for the garlic noodles was overcooked. 

I don't know why this place has such high ratings. Maybe my group of friends all just ordered the wrong stuff? I looked at other tables and most people ordered rice dishes. Perhaps they just suck at noodle dishes. 

BTW this is a vietnamese restaurant but the only Asians in the place were my table. Not trying to be racist or anything but if this was actually an authentic place I'd expect more Asians there. Oh and the restaurant people are Chinese. I can hear them speaking Chinese to the kitchen. Not that I'm against Chinese operated non-Chinese restaurants. Some of my favorite Japanese restaurants in the bay area are actually Chinese owned. But the food here just didn't taste Vietnamese.
author: Selina L.

description:
Walked in to get takeout, the food smells amazing and fortunately it wasn't too full. We were hoping to grab a glass of wine while we decided on our order and waited for the take aways. We walked to the two empty tables and asked to sit down, to order and have a glass of wine. The stern waiter looked at me, frowned and said "No. Go there!" He pointed to the three seat bar where a young man had already occupied about two thirds of the available space. I asked one of the women next to the kitchen and she also cut us off, so we accepted the only place to go was the corner of the bar, where one had to crouch down sporadically so they could type in an order. Eventually a cross looking woman barked at me "are you ready?" I crossed the bar to reach her stern "what do you want?" I gave her my order. The food arrived pretty quickly which cut short the dancing routine to duck away from the arm inputting orders. I can't understand not wanting to sell a glass of wine to customers while they wait especially if they're not going to dirty any plates. Seems like a good decision. But most of all I don't understand the need to be rude. A simple explanation would have been great instead of being barked at like a eight
year old who had managed to find its way onto the grumpiest man on the road's refrigerator. short: Worst customers service. Sour waiters. The food is good but don't expect to be treated with any respect.
author: Bee S.

description: OMG...This place rocks....for sure. Food is amazing, the portions are huge...and the best part... the bill is cheap. The service is good too. What more you want for a vietnamese joint. Trust me, I'm Vietnamese and this place reminds me of home.
author: Pete Nghiem P.

description:
I ordered their vermicelli bowl with bbq pork and imperial rolls.  The serving size is quite generous, the imperial rolls were fried to perfection and the ingredients all tasted fresh.  We also ordered spring rolls to share and they were yummy and fresh as well. 

The service was okay, food came out really fast but we found one of the waitress a bit rude.  She refused to seat us eventhough she had a table ready for us.  We had a party of 6 and 4 of us were here, the other 2 were looking for parking.  

It was a little pricier than other Vietnamese restaurants but it's expected for the area.  Tables were clean and the atmosphere is pleasant.  It does get crowded during lunch time, so come early to grab a table (come with your entire party).
author: Veronica N.

description: When I moved work locations from the Inner Richmond to the Dogpatch, I was concerned.  Then I found out that Sunflower was a few blocks away.  Phew!  Love those days that I can take a break from work and walk up the hill to get a bowl of vermicelli with Grilled Shrimp & Imperial Rolls or a bowl of pho!
author: Michelle S.

description:
Sunflower on Potrero is in the top echelon of my takeout places. The ambiance is pretty nice, too (red walls and Moroccan-inspired alcoves for lighting), but I rarely eat in because it's usually crowded and I live so close. 
 
It's quick (~10 min to pick up), relatively cheap, and tasty. There's a pretty wide spectrum of decent food for whatever I'm in the mood for:

I usually get: 
prawn spring rolls -- they're good and always fresh, but nothing astonishing
[extra-] spicy green beans -- these are pretty simple, but it's important that they're of the right consistency (not overcooked, still kinda crispy)
curry eggplant -- yellow curry with coconut milk; creamy and rich 
clay pot fish -- sort of a sweet/savory sauce with big pieces of white fish, and my favorite dish here; I haven't yet found another place that cooks it this way so it's caramelized on the outside and tender on the inside
garlic noodles -- I get these if I want something heavy, because they're pretty heavy... a medium-thick egg noodle sautéed in garlic sauce/oil
author: Eta O.

description:
One of my favorite Vietnamese restaurants in the Mission/Potrero area.  There are many great and better options in the Tenderloin as well.

Why Sunflower Potero stands out for me are the following 1) never a long wait, 2) fast and freindly service, 3) generous pho portions, and 4) parking is easier than other neighborhoods.  I guess it's worth noting I come here mostly for the pho + extra veggies.  I also have ordered the soups to go plenty of times - never had an issue.  It's so satisfying and I always feel like a made a healthy choice without comprising flavor.

What I wish I would have known before going:  No desert, soup portions are large so think twice about ordering appetizers or share, enjoy the downtown views if you are waiting for a table, if you are near the Tenderloin there are better more authentic Vietnamese options.
author: Adrian N.

description:
I am glad they opened their 2nd location as this is one of my favorite restaurants in the city. I came here on Sunday with some friends and were seated near the back in this cozy seating area. 

We ordered the following: 

- Fried Spring rolls 
- Lemongrass chicken 
- Steamed Sea bass (melts in your mouth) 
- 2 orders of the Sunflower prawns (huge order) 
- String beans (the lemon grass chicken also had string beans, so could have ordered another vege dish, but it was yummy) 

Overall, awesome food!! The service was okay as it was sometimes difficult to get someone to refill our water as we were closer to the back of the restaurant. The host, I believe, she was awesome - funnie. 

The cozy seating area was great - we were able to just hangout after dinner and just chat. It was an awesome experience and will be back - no doubt!
author: James L.

description:
Straight from the waiter's mouth: "This restaurant caters to non-Asians." The food is definitely NOT authentic. Vietnamese Crepe had overcooked chicken. Only 4 little prawns in their Prawn and Egg Roll Over Rice Noodle dish. Both dishes were mediocre, at best. 

One star for decor--which was from the previous resto biz.
author: Quyen L.

description: Good friendly service.  Very nice dwelling and interior.  First come first served.  I got to pick my seat but wasn't sure if I was to wait to be seated or not.  It got busy around lunch time.  I ordered the pho and the broth was kind of salty. Although, lots of noodles, protein, fresh basil and sprouts.  The broth was piping hot - just how i like it.  I also ordered the fresh shrimp spring rolls.  Rolls are a healthy size if you like a lot of noodles in them.  A few lettuce leafs were kind of old and pulled out.  The peanut butter sauce was very runny.  I'm used to it kind of thick.  Decent pricing but i've had cheaper and better quality food.  The water was not very good - from the sink i suppose?
author: Chris S.

description: I always order the Combination Crispy Noodles, and it has never dissapointed us. I've had this dish at a number of different vietnamese restaurants, and this is the best that I've found. I definitely recommend it. It's also very affordable.
author: Nicole H.

description:
3.5 Stars

I stopped by Sunflower Vietnamese Restaurant for a quick catch up lunch with a friend. We arrived on a Monday right around Noon and there wasn't a wait. We got seated pretty quickly.

I perused the menu and saw this restaurant offered a good range of traditional Vietnamese dishes like Noodle Soup (Pho), Vermicelli (Bun), and Rice Plates. There is even a selection of Lunch Specials for $8.95 that includes soup, imperial rolls, salad, and the main dish.

I opted to try Vermicelli (Bun) #25: B.B.Q. Pork (Lemongrass marinade) with Imperial Rolls for $7.95. The bowl consisted of rice noodles, meat, ground peanuts, and various veggies like pickled carrots. Fish sauce was served on the side and there were two crispy imperial rolls (deep fried rice paper rolls with pork, taro root, and carrots) cut into 6 pieces total placed on top. 

The portions here are big and my stomach was full when I reached the bottom of my bowl. Overall the dish wasn't super salty and tasted healthy. Everything was good, but nothing was over the top amazing. I wish the distribution of ingredients was slightly better. I felt I was eating a lot of noodles by the end of my meal. The meat was okay and had a good charbroiled flavor. I definitely enjoyed the Imperial Rolls the most.
author: Jason H.

description:
Absolutely love this place. The Potrero Hill location is easy to get to, fairly easy parking, and nice atmosphere.

The service can be a bit abrupt, but they are always nice. It is pretty regularly busy.

The food I've had is excellent. Love the garlic noodles. Huge portion. Looks bland, but full of flavour. The pho also is a very large bowl and very tasty. The broth is slightly sweet (not too much), but I love it. 

Will definitely be returning.
author: Rose B.

description: I was going to the Mission spot and now I have found Potrero and it is so much better! Same delicious, fast, affordable food in such a cute, quaint area of the city - decorated and much more appealing to diners. It is crowded and can get quite hot - also the non stop phone calls can get a bit annoying but hey! it's good - people want take out. I can't hate. Will be back - sorry Mission spot - you've been replaced.
author: S. M.

description:
Okay viet food.

Lunch specials - good deal.  quite a bit of food.  tastes okay.

Garlic Noodles - this tastes okay, and it is a huge amount of food.

Nothing stupendous tasting, but lots of food so the higher prices don't feel as ridiculous.
author: Steven F.

description:
Tasty Vietnamese food. Portion sizes are huge. Prices are fair for the area and low enough that this could be a multiple-time-per-week restaurant.

Not their fault (since it's not a Thai restaurant), but they should really think about stocking some of that sweet chili sauce for all the people who like to put it on their fried rice.
author: Scott T.

description: If you manage to sneak in during lunch, definitely order one of their lunch plate options - they're huge and offer a little of everything at a really reasonable price. I got the BBQ pork plate and was really happy with my choice. I'll definitely be visiting again.
author: Alice Y.

description:
Not even close. Went last eve and it was less than desirable. Chicken spring Rolls were old and sticky, almost a gooey wrapper. Chicken inside was over cooked hard chunks of breast meat. Lacked any real flavor even when dipped in sauce. They seemed left overs from a day ago.  The beef dish although tender was cut so small it was a chore to eat. Very garlicky but had no taste of chili sauce as menu mentioned.
 Shrimp with vegetable should be listed Vegetables with shrimp. When the server was asked how many shrimp were in the dish, she had to go to kicthen and ask, she came back and replied " 8 " and then scowled as she finished taking order. The plate although large was a mess of totally raw vegetables that included cabbage, broccoli,cauliflower and onions. The curry sauce was so thin it clung to nothing and just sat there almost overflowing on to table top. This dish seemed to barely even be hit in a wok or sauteed, the 8 tiny shrimp were over cooked and rubbery and the vegetable and sauce sauce were barely warmed and as I mentioned the vegetables were raw, If the vegggies and sauce were cooked the proper length of time to get rid of raw flavor and texture and even a hint of a thickened sauce , I could see this being a decent dish. At no time were we asked how anything was and checked was dropped off without even a thank you or eye contact. 45 dollars plus tip , we were far from satisfied and even pondered  Boneless Chicken at KFC as dessert.
author: Craig S.

description:
Just came back from traveling in Vietnam, and very excited to find this place! As vietnamese food goes, it's very fresh and tasty, a great neighborhood find. Not worth traveling to Potrero Hill for though, as I imagine there are a lot more authentic establishments elsewhere. 

So to clarify, if your local to Potrero Hill, think of this as four stars! If you're looking for authentic Vietnamese, you still have more searching to do.
author: Charlotte C.

description:
I had the Sunflower Prawns.  This dish made me want to punch the chef in the face LOL...that is actually a compliment.  This dish was so good I almost literally licked the plate.  If you love Garlic, ooo...we, this is a must have.  You get sweet salt & savory all in one dish and it is so well balanced I couldn't complain.  I also had the vegetable curry.  Another winner.  my friends and I completely cleaned the plates.
The waitress joked with us through out the meal, which made the experience even more pleasurable.  I wasn't crazy about SF but would go back for the Sunflower Prawns.
author: Carla F.

description:
I give this location one star above the Valencia street location because: 1) the more upscale ambiance (taken over the old "BARAKA" space),  2) the service is friendlier and 3) the food tastes better (even if it may have the same recipe).  I would give this location 4 stars IF, they found a better way to manage people waiting for a table (like having a waiting list)

On a Friday evening, ALL the tables were filled when a friend and I arrived at 8pm.  We waited for about 15 minutes for an open table.  When we arrived, the hostess was performing quadruple duty of hostess, server, buser AND tracking take-out orders.  AMAZING.

As for the food, we ordered WAY TOO MUCH of it:

Beef Salad - GINORMOUS portion enough for 2 - tangy cilantro dressing over cabbage and thin slices of beef
Five Spice Chicken - very well roasted chicken with five spice seasoning.  Very tender and flavorful.
Chicken Pho - had a sweet aftertaste, comes with lots of vermicelli noodles, vegetable garnish and shredded chicken.  Very large bowl.

I think that for 2 people with a normal appetite, just the main course would suffice (a rice or noodle dish).  The salad was way too much with the 2 meals ordered.

The price point is reasonable and if you order an appetizer and a meal, you will end up really full or with leftovers.

All together, the bill would have come out to about $26 for the meal w/o beverages.

The traditional vietnamese coffee is my favorite beverage.  It gives you a high octane kick-start.

My suggestion, come EARLY to avoid the rush, otherwise, you could be waiting a LONG time, as their management of wait list could use improvement.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
If you're eating carbs, you must indulge in the Sunflower Prawns!  Huge deep fried prawns served over garlic noodles with a delicious sauce ~$15!!!  The garlic noodles are the best in SF.

Some may say this is more Americanized Vietnamese cuisine, but it is flavorful and I loved it.  One of my favorite Vietnamese restaurants in San Francisco.  Also tried the crepe and sizzling seafood, both cooked perfectly.  Leftovers are still good the next day.

Affordable, kid friendly, good service, quaint decor, clean bathrooms and ample parking.
author: HY L.

description: This place gets no stars. I tried to grab lunch here last Friday during rush hour. At first we say a table  for three the greeter  goes to a crowd outside and ask are you waiting on a table. Strike 1. They respond it's a to go order. Next   he tries to put us at a rather small table. I advise that we see two more friends already seated  that  we would like to join our table  therefore we need a bigger table. Mind you they had been seated and only served water should be no biggie! He raises his voice and says we are busy please sit down. Strike 2!! I explain to him the situation calmly and ask l him to please clean the table we want. He cleans it with an attitude then says you said a table for three please sit at the other table. I advise him If our group having a larger table is an issue we will take our business to one of the many other restaurants. I explain he has one of two options  and he proceeds to argue. I walk out and he will never get my business. I believe that if I had not been dressed down as it was Friday my service would have been great. It was a Dining While Black experience (I really hate to ever use the Race card) however he was a jerk. I went to  Papito and the service& food  was excellence. I have heard other folks say that the service at Sunflower is bad  but the food is decent. I will never find out
author: Andre F.

description:
I used to like this place a lot.
What drove me away is a couple of things.
First I used the rest room during my last visit. There was no soap, no soap dispenser, nothing. I grabbed a paper towel to let myself out without touching the door.
Back at my table I asked the server out of curiosity, "is there another bathroom for the employees in the back?" The waitress replied "no just the one bathroom". So the bathroom the employees use has no soap...
THE EMPLOYEES DON'T WASH THEIR HANDS AFTER USING THE RESTROOM. NOT ONLY IS THAT DISGUSTING BUT ALSO ILLEGAL, OR IT SHOULD BE.
Anyways aside from that I was full-ish so I took the rest to go and tossed it later.
 I just couldn't eat it thinking that the cook didn't wash his hands after taking a deuce earlier that day. 
I apologize for that image.
Beware of unsanitary conditions in restaurants anywhere you go, this is a detail that too many people, Yelpers included, tend to overlook.

Being sanitary is a must, dirty hands means contaminated food which makes you sick or worse.
Peace.
author: Raj M.

description:
Ambiance, ambiance, ambiance.  Take your average mom-n-pop Vietnamese restaurant featuring authentic food and plop it in a cozy and sexy setting featuring silky red walls and floor-to-ceiling windows which offer a peek of the city skyline.

The best part?  The food is tasty and very reasonably priced!  About $7-15 a dish.  The beef Pho was tasty and huge!  The combo appetizer consisted of rolls, meat, shrimp on a bed of noodles, some translucent wrapper things, lettuce and a sauce.  The waitress was really nice and quite humorously explained to our blank gaze, "you make your own burrito."  And it was a pretty good Vietnamese burrito.

Also, I hear their lunch specials are less than $10 and offer big portions.  This is a great place to have a high-class dining experience for not a lot of money.
author: Nancy R.

description: The food is very average if not slightly below. The beef pho was over spiced and heavy-handed. The BBQ pork was tasty but with a lot of fatty pieces and the shaking beef was pretty low-quality meat drowned in spices to hide that fact. Definitely not authentic and the service was rushed and pushy. I'm not sure why the great reviews. I think Turtle Tower or Tin are better bets. However, the portions are ginormous so maybe people just like getting a lot of food.
author: Bunny C.

description: Their chicken curry is very good - good curry flavor with lots of vegetables and not oily at all.  They also use chicken breast instead of thigh meat to keep it healthy.  One of my favorite curry dish in SF.  Do know that this is a very loud restaurant.  Service has room for improvement.
author: Lenny C.

description: Huge, tasty portions with lots of flavor.  Very strong, good tasting flavors and fast service.  The only thing that keeps this from getting 5 stars is that the flavors aren't all that complex, and it can be a little bit oily.  If you're expecting a sophisticated restaurant with fine-tuned flavors, this isn't a top choice.  However, it's a good splurge if you just want flavorful, well cooked food and are okay with salt and oil.
author: Kenji M.

description:
This is just like Sunflower in the Mission except with nicer decor and a Potrero Hill crowd. Food is delicious (note: I am not Vietnamese, so I stake no claim in its authenticity). 

-1 star because the situation is awkward when entering the restaurant and waiting for a table. The restaurant is small, with no host stand in front, which actually gives it a nice, casual feel, however a list outside the door might make that uncomfortable, "oh, you were here first," happen a little less often.
author: jen h.

description: Spectacular food. The house fried rice is amazing. Try a Thai tea to put a bigger smile on your face.
author: Kate A.

description:
I'm all sorts of confused. It's a vietnamese restaurant, but they don't name pho in their noodle soup section AND you can't pick meats to add to your noodle. It's more of a chinese restaurant with vietnamese dishes. After saying all that, I got the shaken beef and it was delicious. The beef was tender and juicy. I thought it would have a hint of spice from the chili oil, but it wasn't spicy at all. The vermicelli noodle with grilled beef and imperial rolls was pretty good. You can't really go wrong with fried spring rolls and grilled meat as long as the noodles weren't soggy.

We brought a bottle of champagne and the cork fee was $8, which isn't bad. The waiters were attentive and friendly. I think the owner is a woman, who came around to chat with us. We were waiting on our friends, who were taking awhile after we were seated. While waiting, we ordered the thai ice tea and vietnamese pot stickers, which is a meatball covered with fried noodles and then dropped into the fryer again. The meat was a little weird, I think I expected something chewy or meatball like, but the meat just falls apart. It was interesting with the hoisin like sauce. I wouldn't say I didn't like it .... just interesting.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
Vietnamese food is never my top pick because I tend to find it a bit too bland at times, but a friend & I were in Potrero Hill tonight and needed to grab a moderately-priced and quick meal somewhere around the 18th & Connecticut area. Recognized the name from the Mission location which has never disappointed, but nor has it ever been on the top of my list (except for VIETNAMESE COFFEE - that shiz is THE BOMB and certainly NOT BLAND). 

Anyways, I would venture to say that this location exceeded my memories from the mission locations! The servings were larger than I remembered, and very fresh. We had the vegetarian crepe, the veggie imperial rolls, and an order of plain garlic noodles - plain simple goodness!!! The crepe and the imperial rolls were GIANT and were served with lots of lettuce leaves, shredded carrots, silver noodles, sliced cucumber, etc... a real " veggie lover's delight," if you will. This was plenty of food for two, with VERY generous leftovers for tomorrow's lunch. The garlic noodles could've easily served four. 

Bill was around $25. Very good value. I still found myself gravitating towards their shelf of hot sauces as soon as the food came out, and squirted what some might consider to be an ungodly amount of sriracha all over most of my food, but hey, I like it hot.
author: Shannon R.

description: I love Potrero Hill. Been here twice in a row now. Yesterday at Pera and today at Sunflower. Vietnamese food is very tasty but a little on the bland side. Ordered shrimp and green beans with lemongrass and that was delicious! This place is so busy! It's an 'In and out' kinda place and they don't even serve dessert. I guess their specialty is the huge bowls of Vietnamese noodle soups (pho), so must go back to try that although I'd have to skip the noodles since I'm not a big fan. Service could be better but I get it. They're busy. Wouldn't mind going back to try some other interesting dishes.
author: Sabina H.

description: Had a great dinner with friends.  Must say that I was a little taken aback by the prices and the portion size.  The portions are massive - huge bowls with steaming noodles, soup or cool fresh salads - all tasty.  And the prices were very inexpensive, especially considering portion size.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Sweet holy soothing powers of Vietnamese food, I bow with sniffly nose at thy tasty feet.

Seriously, is there anything better than pho and warm comfy noodle dishes when you have a cold? Last night, as I whined with cough drops in my mouth and a tissue stuffed up my nose, we were searching for takeout Vietnamese options in the neighborhood and I remembered that Sunflower had somewhat-recently opened in Potrero Hill, so we called in and headed over.

Chicken noodle soup and garlic noodles with tofu! Perfect. I'm excited to actually dine in at Sunflower, as an excuse to further explore Potrero Hill. And eat more noodles.
author: Anna G.

description: Entire family was happy. My 4.5 y.o. son ate 3-4 small bowls of seafood Pho!  My 10 month daughter was grabbing at tomatoes and everything else. My mother, who dislikes Vietnamese food, was a happy camper. Overall, we'd be back! :) New fan.
author: Jinny K.

description:
I live nearby and have patronized this restaurant a few times since it opened a couple or so years ago.  I make every effort to patronize all the restaurants encompassed around my zip code area.  I went for lunch yesterday, Sunday, 3/29 and ordered the appetizer combination which includes the Vietnamese spring rolls.  It also includes strips of pork, prawns, and raw or marinated veggies.  I have tried other menu items, but I am fed up pretending this restaurant of cooks and its owner(s) know, or willing to cook authentic Vietnamese food.  They take way too many inexpensive shortcuts which fools other customers who have no previous gastronomical or hands on cultural experience in Vietnamese cuisine.  I do, so I know the difference.  

This restaurant serves what should pass for fast food taste style version.  No culturally proud authentic traditional Vietnamese cook or chef would ever use canned pineapple as a menu ingredient.  Even the rice paper, used to encase bits of food, roll around like a cigar and dip into fish sauce, was so thin that it could not be removed from the plastic plate holding each one.  The food is boring including the broths. Obviously, this restaurant caters to customers with unsophisticated palates simply happy to brag that they had a menu with the word Vietnamese.  I took the diplomatic step to ask the waitress if the cooks were Chinese trained to cook Vietnamese.  She replied they were all Vietnamese.  However, the few times I have been there, I am pretty sure I recognize Chinese language being spoken by the wait staff and cooks.  I worked alongside of Vietnamese diplomats and several Vietnamese refugees at the time, when I was assigned to a Vietnamese embassy for almost four years, so II do know the difference there too. I am city born with Hispanic heritage but traveled and associated with an expansive range of cultural leaders and culinary professionals to know when food is fusion, traditional, or just diluted to appease those content with thinking they ate something culturally authentic.

Sunflower Restaurant must presume that nonVietnamese residents of this part of the city are too culturally naive to know the difference and they are probably accurate. I doubt this restaurant can fool anyone serving overseas before the communist took over all of Vietnam and the Vietnamese themselves or those of us with close links in various capacities with the Vietnamese community.   Many previous Vietnamese restaurants in other parts of town tried to appease the middle of the road Americanized  palate, but most of those don't last long in business. Fortunately, aside from a handful of us in Potrero Hill and surrounding neighborhoods, most remote from the 1970's introduction of Vietnamese culture and cuisine into the U.S. have a very sparse point of reference which Sunflower Restaurant hopes will be the common factor in serving unimpressive, boring rendition of Vietnamese food.  I will have to hop in my car and drive across town when I want better prepared Vietnamese cuisine, not just Americanized version.
author: Lizabeth G.

description: First off, let me say that I've come here before and had a great experience and love the garlic noodles. However, my poor experience tonight at Sunflower was really unfortunate and compelled me to write this review. It all comes down to the pho. Otherwise known as beef noodle soup on the menu. I was so disappointed. The beef was really overcooked and there wasn't a variety in beef cuts as there would be in more traditional restaurants. This place clearly caters to a more American palate AKA those unfamiliar with Vietnamese cooking. I guess the pho just isn't what you order here. My guest and I finished our soups, but we were still hungry because we were so unsatisfied with the meal. The broth was flavorful, but I would have liked it hotter. So we ordered some imperial rolls -- how can you go wrong with fried yumminess? Unfortunately, the pho had really melted away our appetites. We left dissatisfied and, sadly, have written Sunflower off our list. In addition, the service tonight was very rushed, brusque, and really added to the whole negative experience. I literally got pushed by a server as they were punching in an order as I was getting a toothpick -- all with out an apology. There are so many more Vietnamese restaurants where I can get a solid bowl of pho without all the negative service. I'll be going there from now on.
author: Cristina M.

description:
The food is really good here. I have eaten here once before and the service was good. However, when I ordered to go the lady was very rude and short with me, don't know why. 

But I'd still go back since the food is good and the prices are very reasonable as well. I recommend the Chinese fried rice and definitely the crab meat and corn soup.
author: Ashleen C.

description: I'm a fan!  A few buddies and I came here about a month ago.  We ordered large prawns garlic noodles, some kind of garlic fried rice, some kind of hot and sour soup, and one more dish.  All were delicious and portions were great!  I'd come back in a heartbeat... craving it right now, as a matter of fact!
author: Sasuke N.

description:
Very good Vietnamese food new on 18th street in Potrero Hill. It's great to have another option in the area. The food is definitely craving worthy on a Friday night. I'm not sure I'd make a trek across the city for it but the few block walk (mind you there are some serious hills involved) is worth it.

Favorite Items:
- garlic noodles
- vermicelli with five spice chicken and/or imperial rolls
- lemongrass BBQ beef
- shaken beef
- curry beef
- appetizer combo plate (lots of food)
author: Audrey N.

description: We ordered a combination appetizer platter and a beef garlic noodle to share. It was more than enough food to fill two people. I liked the appetizer platter because it gave you a taste of pretty much everything. The garlic noodles were excellent, although the beef in it was very bland and a bit too "soft." Tasted like they had sprinkled in too much baking soda to soften it.
author: H. L.

description:
We came here for lunch and the place was packed. We were seated rather quickly and got down to business.

I ordered the #3 lunch special...it was just okay. Large portions yes, but nothing really exciting about the food. My co-worker ordered a dish of vegetables and rice which looked really boring. She said it was just alright.

On a nice day, it is a cool spot to eat as the windows open up to let the breeze in.

Staff was okay but the place reminded me of Lai Lai's in how quickly you receive your food in order to get you out.
author: Jocelyn J.

description: I love their lunch menu, especially the Five Spice Chicken. It's very flavourful and filling and definitely the best bang for the buck. I come here every weekend.
author: XiaoChuan Y.

description: A Portero gem with great service, good, fast food and a casual vibe. Definitely coming back!
author: Aman V.
