description:
First Vietnamese restaurant I've been too that had all of their menu in English. (i.e. - it doesn't say Pho Ga for Chicken Soup). Not a negative or positive. Literally just the first thing I noticed. Sweet, rustic decor inside too.

Anyway, the lunch combo plates are huge. I am sitting here at work so full. I will not eat dinner tonight, unless I go run a marathon - that is how full I am. I might not even eat breakfast. 

Flavorful, colorful, tasty, healthy and everything in between.

Good service and the prices are reasonable. $25 for 2 people. Dankfully bliss. Will come again soon and so should you.
author: Jeffrey S.

description: decent food, but BEYOND-UNPLEASANT FEMALE STAFF(MANAGER?). Very unfortunately this woman ruins the supposed-to-be 3 to 4 star food. Restaurant business is a hospitality business, and she has no clue on that very important point. Glad to hear there is another one on 16th street so from now on I will try there and never come back here again. Off course I will return if this female staff/manager resigns.
author: Nobu K.

description:
Well...at least there are no crackheads sitting around the corner! Other than that, this place is inferior to the Vietnamese cuisine in the TL.
     The "noodle soup" (not pho) was ok. The broth had decent beef flavor and was not too salty or oily. However, the whole thing lacks soul. It feels like the cooks wanted to do a "censored" version of pho, so adventurous white people will try it without being scared away. There is NO brisket, NO beef balls, NO tendon, No tripe, and NO LOVE. The soup did not warm my heart.
     The service was attentive, but the dude kept bumping into me while I was trying to eat. I only got one apology.
     Overall, the ingredients and the flavors weren't bad but everything seemed fake. At least nothing was oversalted, unlike PF Changs. (thats right, I mentioned the crappy establishment) Next time, I'll get some Vietnamese cuisine made with LOVE (right next to the crackheads).
author: Siao W.

description:
One of the few places that make GREAT garlic noodles. Get the BBQ-Lemon Grass Beef!!!! It's great. 

Nice location, servers are friendly and prompt. Prices are super affordable and the ambiance inside is very warm and chic!!!!! Love this place
author: Serina H.

description: The other day my husband & I decided to walk around Potrero Hill & to look for someplace to have dinner.  We decided on Sunflower since my husband had a crazing for Vietnamese food.  Also, we had never eaten there before.  It turned out to be an excellent choice.  Service was very friendly, & accommodating.  The space is very attractive - Dark red walls, dark wood trim. We had a very nice seat at the window.  Great street scene, lots of people walking around.  It was a very warm night. Our waitress made excellent choices for us. We started off with the combo platter $11.95 - Excellent, selection of dishes. We also shared a plate of rice noodles topped with tofu & vegetables $7.95.  There was more than enough food for the two of us.  No room for dessert! You can't beat the prices for the amount of food you receive. We will definitely go back!
author: Pam R.

description: We picked this restaurant out because of its great reviews on yelp but the owner's attitude actually prevents us from ever coming back again. We arrived Sunday evening with 2 kids and 2 adults. We gave our names to the owner however he would not give us an estimated wait time and had the abrupt mannerism of 'too busy to be courteous', which didn't bother us at first, but when he passed us by to seat several successive patrons who came after us, we became rather annoyed. 3 groups behind us tried to tell him that we were in front of them, but he smiled and just waved his hand saying that my whole group was not present. In fact we where. One of the kids who was 4 was at most wandering around so dad was following him around the sidewalk. Me and my 8 year old daughter stood first inline at the door. We where all within reaching distance which other patrons pointed out too. It took the people behind us about 10 mins to be seated. It took us about 45 mins. The kids where very hungry by that point. Obviously we did something to offend him. I believe it was when I said we would be happy to take a 2 person table and the kids could sit on our laps since they were very hungry. I actually avoid the place now, too bad cause it's very close to my new office.
author: Ileanna R.

description: Talk about portions and yumminess! I ordered what I thought to be a modest 3 dishes -- and after my husband and I ate our share, we ended up having leftovers for 2 additional days. Garlic noodles are tasty -- so is the vermicellii with pork! Will definitely be going back
author: Erin C.

description: I think it's weird that they don't call their noodle soups "Pho", but whatever, it's Pho.  They busted out the pho within 5 minutes of us ordering it.  Their speed is amazing.  It's pretty pricey for pho, a little over $8 - but then again, this is SF right? The beef in my pho was a liiittle too tough for me, but overall, the taste was good and the sizes were great!  I would totally come back here.
author: Stephanie L.

description: I luv the claypot. Delicious Vietnamese/French Cuisine!
author: Lisa D.

description:
Food = 4.0 - The food here is really good, especially the garlic noodles.  It's not exactly the most authentic Vietnamese place.  I asked if their beef pho came with tendon and they said no.  I asked WHY THE HELL NOT!?  That being said, their noodle dishes are pho-king tasty.

Atmosphere = 3.0 - This joint is definitely a neighborhood place with that kind of feel.  Nothing fancy.  

Service = 4.0 - The waiters at this restaurant were really nice.  The food came out fast, which was great because I am always hungry and always impatient!
author: Eddie L.

description:
I've loved Sunflower for years but it was almost always takeout because parking in the Mission and the cramped and divey ambience wasn't all that.  How excited was I to discover last night that there's another branch in Potrero Hill in the former Baraka space!

After playing some tennis on a chilly evening, we were craving pho and so came here. First of all, parking is way easier out here. Second, the interior is quite inviting with bright red walls (left over from the Baraka days). We ordered the beef noodle soup (pho) which was really nice and not too oily. Comes with individualnside dishes of fresh bean sprouts, chiles, mint leaves and lemon. Unfortunately, no ubiquitous bottles of Sriracha and plum sauces that I love.  I'm not sure how the prices compare with the original Sunflower but it's still pretty reasonable for pho at just over $8. 

We also ordered the fried imperial rolls, which were really good and come out i. generous portions with sides of pickled carrots, cucumber slices and vermicelli.

Definitely intend to come back and try my usual favorites from the Mission spot - shaken beef and lemongrass pork
author: F. P.

description:
Seeing red.

From the Hot & Sour shrimp soup. Pineapple bonus. More shrimp please.

From the Lemongrass Chicken. Chili kick. Enough for two. House favorite for a reason.

From the Vegetable Spring Rolls. Only had someone tried to steal my second piece. Favorite dish.

From the decor. Lots and lots of red.

From the service. Rushed. Lukewarm. Indifferent.

Plenty to like. Few things will leave you seeing red.
author: Jason B.

description: I don't get it.  the food is not particularly good, nor inexpensive.  Been to this location three times and Im just dumbfounded each time as to why I went back and why anyone else is there.  The food is pretty bland and has neither authentic nor new flavors.  The service is generally poor.  I honestly cant understand how anyone who has eaten vietnamese food (or any food with flavor for that matter) could find this place worth eating at.   This is San Francisco.  We have some of the best restaurants in the world, dont bother with sunflower
author: jonathan s.

description:
The food isn't bad, I just grew up in Little Saigon so it's hard for me to be impressed by Vietnamese food.  For what you actually get, I don't get the hype.  I like the restaurant location but the food hasn't impressed me much.  Maybe because I know how fish sauce is really supposed to taste like?

I had a noodle soup recently.  Also just a little bit off.
author: Z C.

description: I did not have an opportunity to dine at Sunflower because upon calling them, I found out that a variety of vietnamese dishes that are usually gluten free at other vietnamese restaurants were NOT gluten free here because Sunflower intentionally uses gluten ingredients unnecessarily (ex using gluten soy sauce when gluten free soy sauce is commercially available). Some dishes that I am most sad that Sunflower makes gluten-y unnecessarily include the calamari and the vietnamese crepe. I'm super disappointed that they exclude gluten-free customers from their business, but maybe there's hope they can fix their problems at some point. Vietnamese is one of only a few cuisines that are chock full of gluten free dishes traditionally, so Sunflower's choices are particularly annoying. At least you were warned!
author: Frances H.

description:
pretty good food. 

sampler appetizer - (4/5 stars) a lot of meat
beef pho (4/5 stars)
sizzling seafood - bf got it and he seemed to like it

definitely a good option for the bunch of the restaurants in that corner

the waiters are ..quite authentic..but still an enjoyable meal
author: Janet Y.

description: wow, the garlic noodles are to die for,,,probably not lo-cal but extremely tasty.  I recently had shaken beef and lemongrass chicken and was not disappointed. Nice people and decent service.
author: Lisa C.

description: Came out of Yelp hiatus to write about this unfavorable experience.  Rude hostess! Will not bother coming back again. I walked in and the hostess asked if I was ready. I informed her I was not and needed to take a look at the menu. She asks me if I'm ready again while I'm looking at the menu. I say no again. She then points at me and tells her coworker I am stupid, in Chinese. Bad luck lady, I'm Chinese and understand what you said. Needless to say, I didn't stick around for long and gave her my middle finger salute as I walked out. Food isn't that good either, but closest thing to healthy in my work neighborhood.
author: Brandon Y.

description:
This place is a nice discovery, I saw it a short while back while dining at the Goat Hill Pizza across the street.  It's nice to have a Vietnamese option in this area because it's a fairly short drive from my office, and the street parking nearby is free.

The first time I came with two co-workers.  We ordered several items but the one that stands out was their yummy garlic noodles.  Last week, I came back again and tried their beef pho.  The soup wasn't bad, but too bad it lacked ingredients such as tripe which I like having with my pho.  At least they provide jalapeno peppers for spicing it up.

Each time I came for lunch so far, there's a pretty good-size crowd.  It might be partly because of its relative proximity to the UCSF Mission Bay campus.
author: H K.

description:
This place deserves 3.75 - 4 Stars but since they've been very consistent and the lunch menu is a great value, (one of the best in the city, I might add). 

Coming from San Jose, there is simply not many good Vietnamese restaurants in SF. Sunflower did pass my 1st test. I ordered in Vietnamese and they understood (this is a good sign). ANY place that cannot understand when you order in Vietnamese, 9 outta 10 times it's going to be a bad experience. Sunflower, good job at the 1st impression. 

I've only had 3 of their lunch specials:

#1 Soup, imperial roll, salad, Five Spice Chicken 
#2 Soup, imperial roll, salad, BBQ Pork 
#5 Soup, imperial roll, salad Lemongrass Prawns (spicy)

The first time, I saw the Lunch plate came out, I was quite amazed at how much food you get (no joke!). You get a lot of food for only $8.95.  I did opt to get brown rice for an additional $.50. 

The Five Spice Chicken is good. It's moist and flavorful and not fatty. My only gripe would be, the chicken is not made to order. It's made ahead of time. We ordered food and it came out less than 5 mins later and the chicken was only warm.  The BBQ pork is also very tasty, you get a lot of meat ...also flavorful and not fatty.

I would recommend both #1 & #2 again, if you need a good lunch spot that provides a lot of food for under $10. 

Now here's where Sunflower needs some improvements: of all the times I've been there, the Brown Rice & Reg. white rice has been dry. Only once has the rice been made perfect   (Come on, you're an Asian Restaurant....Perfect Rice should be automatic!)  Another gripe would be the Lemongrass Prawns Lunch Special. 1, 2...3...wait a minute...there's only 4 Prawns and the rest were all Veggies! This item is a great disappointment.  Add more Prawns, then it would be good. 

The Imperial rolls that come with it is good and the Sour Soup that comes with it is amazing. 

I'd definitely come back for lunch (since I work only a few blocks away) and so should you. Just don't order the Lemongrass Prawn then you will be happy.
author: David N.

description: The food is pretty good here. I give it only two stars due to level of service. Most of the time the service is fine with exception of one woman. I think she is the manager or owner but she spoiled the experience more than once. She is very curt and unfriendly. I took a colleague there today for lunch for the first time and she loved the food but also mentioned how unpleasant the woman was.  I don't think I will be going back to this location.
author: Tara B.

description:
Restaurant is billed as Vietnamese - it may be more accurate to say Chinese - Vietnamese fusion with a touch of California - the staff is Chinese and the food is served the way Californians like it - with a bit of flair and color, and thankfully not overcooked. This is a restaurant where the owners and manager seem to have a lot figured out. The food is fresh with an aesthetic presentation. Service is fast and usually friendly with some crankiness at times but even then the sense is they're just out to do the work as effectively as they can. Menu is highly formulated but nicely varied. Prices are exceptionally reasonable. After three prior restaurants in about a dozen years failed at that location, looks like they're here to stay, and that's great for the neighborhood. 

Would be nice if they made a point of serving organic food, or at least starting to do so. This is a tough one for restaurants - organic food costs much more at the wholesale level. Even if all restaurants banded together to ensure organic food, people might decide that eating out is just too expensive overall. On the other hand, they might be able to pull together to reduce prices in quantity buys of produce. However, it could work for each individual restaurant to start somewhere and increase organic offerings slowly and incrementally. 

The tofu, for example, could be organic; the price point on that might not be as large as in other food items, and that might be a good place to start. If the staff understands that GMO soybeans that go into making tofu means that pesticides are added into the crop as it's grown and that this has not been tested on humans, i'm sure they could pass along that info to their guests. 

Organic tea could come next, then organic rice, and over time organic produce could come later. Phasing it in this way, prices might go up a little but not shockingly, and the commitment to organic + local would demonstrate awareness that a neighborhood like Potrero Hill would likely appreciate and embrace. Clientele is already quite loyal so it might be tempting for the owners to not even try this, but it's way, way, way time for restaurants to help support healthier lifestyles and organic / local food items, especially in a neighborhood as aware, and with as many fresh food gardens, as Potrero Hill.
author: David G.

description: I was here on on weekday with my mom. She works nearby and had been before. I got the chicken garlic noodle dish. I would've stuck to the lunch specials if I had known it would be such a huge dish of mostly noodles. They get slammed and even  had to open up a closed-off area to accommodate lunch crowd. They have 2 staff, one of which was pretty short and not about to go above & beyond for her customers. The other was a warmer motherly type who spoke little English and was mostly listening to what the other told her to do. It wasn't until I had my cell out opened to the Yelp App that the 1st waitress asked me if I'd be needing a high chair, when I so obviously did, brought out a plate for my daughter, and asked if we needed anything. Anyhow, it's a restaurant catering to the Dog Patch workers, so it's an in & out deal. Besides all that, food is decent. Not family friendly during lunch hours.
author: Paola V.

description:
Yummy little place, Get there early or line up and wonder if there is a waiting list or some random haphazard method of order. I think it goes by the honor system of who was there first.
Anyhow the food was pretty good, We had the Garlic Noodles 8$ and the 9$ lunch combo: Five Spice beef with Egg Roll, Salad, Soup and Rice. Garlic noodles were pretty good with bits of egg mixed in with the noodle. The five spice beef was meaty, and cooked well. The Soup i particularly liked as it was a broth with Pineapples, Jalapenos and produced a nice blend of sweet n not too spicy.
The mountainous bowls of Pho looked good as well, maybe next time if it's ever cold on the east side of S.F.
author: ToAsTy T.

description: Had wayyyyyyyy better Vietnamese food elsewhere, don't know what all the hype about this place is, very disappointed.
author: Cathy L.

description:
Two words: eat there! 
More words: friendly servers, delicious food (both lunch and dinner)
Fish clay pot ?- shut the front door! Amazing! As is everything I've tried there so far.
author: jet b.

description:
I like this place and probably would have never discovered it had my friend not made reservations for us there.  I like that they offer uncommon dishes that I hadn't hear of before.  I really did enjoy the garlic noodles (the best!) and though it was crowded, we were served quickly.  

Parking was easy on the street.  We also enjoyed fried rice with pineapple, which for me can be a hit or miss at most restaurants, but it was good here.
author: Miss C.

description: I used to live in Dogpatch and walk up to Portrero Hill often to eat at Sunflower. My favorites are the seafood soup and pork vermicelli bowl. The fresh spring rolls are also great.
author: Jeremiah L.

description: Stopped by with some friends for dinner before a flight. Finding parking was surprisingly easy and we were seated and ordering almost right away. The food came out incredibly quick, it felt like only minutes after ordering. Perfect because we were starving. My friends ordered the lemon grass chicken and curry eggplant. I got the house fried rice. All of the food tasted great. The curry was nice and spicy with large chunks of eggplant, the lemon grass chicken seasoned just right, and a nice balance of flavor in the fried rice (though I still covered it in chili sauce.) Portions were large and filling and the staff are very friendly and attentive. My only gripe is the price. I've had comparable food for cheaper (3 entrees and 3 beers came out to just over $50 before tip) but overall it was a great place to eat at.
author: Wil E.

description:
A friend of the Boyfriend's recommended this place. Apparently, he goes every day for lunch and orders a big bowl of noodles. I'm not sure that I'd go every day but what I've had so far has been ok (and I haven't had much). 

The garlic noodles with vegetables are pretty good. I've tried the Mission Sunflower and Potrero Hill's is much less greasy. I love that they put in lots of vegetables like broccoli, cauliflower, bell peppers, cabbage and zucchini. 

The crab fried rice is pretty bland and gets boring after a few bites. A healthy dash of Sriracha makes it much more palatable. 

The Imperial rolls were so-so. Not great, not bad (but how can you really make a BAD Imperial roll? I think all the ones I've ever had have been about the same...). 

I've had a couple of other things that have slipped my mind but I think the best part about Sunflower is the portions. They certainly give you bang for your buck and if you're looking for decent Asian food and a decent price, Sunflower Potrero Hill is a good bet.
author: Christine P.

description:
Great food, great prices, good atmosphere. 

Not spectacular, but really good food. I love the beef noodle soup (great when you have a cold coming on). The garlic noodles with chicken, shaking beef and spicy green beans are all just great. The brown rice is really great too. I'm not generally one to comment on rice, but this is special. I've even gotten their house wine which is like $4/glass and while not great is definitely drinkable. I always leave with leftovers. 

It's not a place I'd go out of my way for, but if you're in the neighborhood it's worth a stop!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
So went there for dinner with a couple of friends and began my garlic noodle craving. They have the best garlic noodle, this was my first and I've only tried another at Thanh Long (the famous crab place on Judah). There was no comparison. 

We also ordered the garlic eggplant, which was good but nothing too different from other restaurants. The shaken beef, not my favorite and I couldn't tell you why. Maybe it was the texture or the strong beef flavor.

I would definitely go back to try other items on their menu and order the garlic noodles again.
author: Terri Y.

description: After eating there solo ONCE, they remembered my name, what I ordered, and where I sat! Incredible! AND the food is good and appropriately priced. That's all I need to say.
author: Amy L.

description:
3.5 stars. I came here for dinner w/ a group of 4. We ordered garlic noodles, lemongrass chicken, shaken beef, and something else I can't remember to share family style. While everything was tasty and well prepared, my favorite was the garlic noodles -- yum! Not sure I'd be back with so many other great food options in the area.

-L.
author: Leeann C.

description:
I needed somewhere close to home to fulfill my spring roll craving. This place did the job!  I ordered the fresh spring rolls (with shrimp) and the combo fried pan noodles (veggies, chicken & shrimp).  Both were incredibly tasty and generously portioned!  I ordered it to-go (so I could eat on my couch while watching a chick flick) and when the woman (i am assuming an owner) said 10 minutes, she meant it!  She was really friendly, and I don't think I waited more than 30 seconds before my food was in my hand and I was out the door.

I will have to go back and enjoy a meal there - seems like a great atmosphere and there are lots of other things on the menu I need to try!!
author: Kelsey C.

description:
Although they were quite busy on a Wednesday night we were able to be seated within 10 minutes. But the wait was cramped and as it was raining outside, we just hovered inside. 
The food was delicious, not greasy at all, tasted very fresh and well made...and they give you large portions. We have a good amount of leftovers. 
My Sizzling Seafood was very very good, not as hot as I would have liked but it was tasty.
The appetizer combo was also really good. My favorite part was the grilled shrimp. 
I would easily come back here, for the food, the friendly service and the warm and romantic ambiance.
author: Nilu r.

description:
This place was cool...went in for lunch today and had the beef pho. Tasty broth, lots of beef, noodles did the clump thing tho' so I had to coax them a bit with the chop sticks, but other than that it was good. Pot of hot green tea hit the spot on this rainy day too. I didn't like sitting on the couch thing tho'...felt too sunken in for the table. I'll know to sit across next time. The waitress was fun! She knew my friend from previous visits and gave him a hard time. lol. five stars for that! There were lots of cute patrons there too. Hehe, where do I give five stars for that? The place was pretty crowded, which is always a good sign but we were able to get seats within one cigarette so it wasn't a long wait. That is all. No witty ending to this review, just good soup on a rainy SF day. 

Damnit, I did it anyways.
author: Chris M.

description:
The red walls and large windows of this place are inviting, but unfortunately I couldn't say the same for the staff.  The hostess was very short and unwelcoming, and although my water wasn't icy cold, my waitress was.  I ordered the vermicelli w/ veggie imperial rolls.  I was expecting the normal appetizer size portion, but my dish was so ginormous I had to bring half home!  Seriously, come with an appetite!  I'm not that into curry, but the girl next to me ordered a curry dish and it looked delicious.  

The seating is too close for comfort. I could hear my neighbors conversation in detail.  It went something along the lines of 'using liquid nitrogen to freeze tissue.' Whether they were referring to human or animal tissue I didn't want to know!   All in all I enjoyed my meal here minus 1 star for cold service.
author: anne m.

description: I need to go back here as I feel I ordered the wrong thing. The portions are huge and the prices are cheap!  I was thrown off that their "pho" is called Noodle Soup so I missed out on it. I will definitely be ordering that upon my return.
author: Vanessa L.

description: The place is always crowded because the food is good and portions are big. I definitely would come back. The service was good as well. Lots of great yummy food and worth the price and taste good.
author: Joiera C.

description:
After one too many steak nights, my body was craving something a little more healthful. There were plenty of options on the Sunflower menu and it was nearby and open until 9:30 on a Sunday, so getting food to go quickly became the plan.

I ordered the garlic vegetables with tofu, while my sweetie (not one to pass up an opportunity to have meat) got the vermicelli with lemongrass beef. The woman on the phone was friendly and efficient, telling me the order would be ready in 10 minutes. 

Less than that time later, we walked into an almost full restaurant and were greeted warmly. Our order was ready, and the total for both dishes plus steamed rice was just under $20. Once home, we discovered that the portions were enormous, and we actually had enough for one more person. Everything was fresh and flavorful, and I had to stop myself from eating the entire order. We'll definitely get takeout from here again, and I'm looking forward to making my way down the menu.
author: Julie K.

description:
I came here on the recommendation of a friend... I'll get back to this little detail. 

The ambience is amazing and the atmosphere was romantic. I really liked the copper tables and the patina that developed on them. It seems like a well thought out trendy Vietnamese restaurant. This place was packed so it seemed like a good place to eat. This is where the positive comments end.

 We ordered grilled pork vermicelli and the "famous" garlic noodles.  The waitresses were rude, which is typical of Vietnamese restaurants, but I was expecting better since this was a trendy cool-looking place. The garlic noodles were not bad tasting, but they were definitely not garlic noodles. It tasted more like pad-see-ewe spaghetti. The chicken in it was overcooked and bland. It was a large portion, so I don't have an issue with that. it was $10, which is overpriced compared to comparable dishes.  $8 garlic noodles from Perilla in Inner sunset actually tastes like garlic noodles.  The  Grilled pork vermicelli was bad. The noodle were dry and choppy, with no long strands. Even Asian noodles should be al dente. These were dry and undercooked. Maybe they were just low quality noodles. The grilled pork was not bad. The imperial rolls, which are just egg rolls, were not good. They used spring roll wrappers instead of egg roll wrappers. I don't know if this is a cost saving measure or their preference, but that is not how a real egg roll should be. Not one water refill the whole time.

This last bit is what pissed me off enough to write a review. We ate maybe 15% of our food, and it was unappetizing enough for us to request the check and leave. They take away our dishes and return with tiny ass to-go containers.  I opened it up and saw that they were 3/4 full. Where the f*** was the rest of our food? Remember I said that the portions were pretty big. What the f***??? I know how much of our food was left when they took the plate and they returned with not even half of it. This was shady to me, so I ask some other friends about this place. A rumor is that they take some of the garlic noodles, which is a common dish and put it back into the community pot because it's easy to mix it in with other orders. A shady cost saving measure.  If it wasn't so obvious and blatant, I wouldn't mention it, but it seemed like they were more attentive and friendly towards white people. Asian people sometimes do this and it pisses me off. Everyone should be treated with the best customer service, or if you're going to treat people badly, at least do it to everyone. Equality should be the standard, if not good customer service.

So back to my first sentence... The friend that recommended me is a white guy. I looked around the restaurant and saw only white people. No other Asians. I'm not saying that white people don't know Asian food, but Im saying Asian people only eat good Asian food. 

Summing it up... Great decor and ambience. Mediocre food. Bad customer service. Food disappeared upon taking out. 

Good food and good customer service being the most important things to me, I strongly recommend you find another vietnamese restaurant to enjoy in SF.
author: Thomas L.

description: Had the garlic noodles that were so highly reviewed but found them good but not great. Lady on the phone was really rude when taking my order. It was decently priced.
author: Chris F.

description:
If it weren't confirmed right there on the website, I'd never believe this place and the one in the Mission are affiliated. I'll save my criticism of that location for its review, but let's just say this one beats it in a landslide.

The garlic noodles are awesome. Rich but not heavy. Garlicky but not overpowering. Perfectly cooked noodles. Fresh, crisp vegetables. And a huge portion, even at lunch. At least two meals worth for $8.71. 

Water stays filled throughout the meal. Servers are efficient and pleasant. 
The decor doesn't quite work (Tuscan? huh?) but it's not offensive. I like all the dark wood. Overall, quiet and comfortable environment for an inexpensive, tasty meal.
author: Bethany M.

description:
If you want to expand your cusine beyond pho, then head over to this location. 

We loved their garlic noodles with chicken, Seafood pan fried noodles, and Five Spices Roasted Chicken. Flavors were very tasty.
author: GARY C.

description:
This is the best Vietnamese restaurant that I've ever been to (note that I'm not an aficionado when it comes to Vietnamese food). The quality was amazing and the flavors were delectable.

We got the combo appetizer plate that rocked! Great serving size and lots of variety. Well worth it.

I got the Vermicelli bowl with BBQ pork. Delicious.
The Shaken Beef (cause it's a house specialty). The meat was tender and the seasoning was incredible.
And the Curry Vegetables. Excellent curry sauce.

The beer list also included Allagash white ale from Portland that was really good.

Even though I live somewhat far, I'm definitely going back soon and often to this place.
author: Tomas P.

description: This cute little Vietnamese restaurant in Potrero hill really hit the spot tonight! I was craving Bo bun, and although they call it vermicelli noodles with "imperial rolls" (fried spring rolls), that is what it was, and the dish was perfectly done. It was a huge portion for $7, and you could feed two people easily for dinner with that. Hip hip hooray to affordable and delicious Vietnamese food in the city! The parking situation isn't bad at all either, which further motivates me to go!
author: Terry K.

description:
+: Quick 
+: Large portions
+: Nice decor
+: Tasty thick spring rolls
+: Lots to choose from

-: A bit rude on the phone, couldn't tell me the current wait time b/c it was too busy.
-: Higher than normal prices for vietnamese food
-: 5 spice chicken was a bit over cooked and dry, however, the spices were tasty. 

Recommend: the portions are hefty, so family style seems the way to go.  

Will probably go back and try the other things on the menu outside of pho and banh mi.
author: Tammy T.

description:
YUM Vietnamese to go in Portrero! 
Really good prices and great quality.....my new speed-dial drive by for rainy days! Vietnamese Crepe, Vermicelli with spring rolls and beef, and chicken Pho noodle soup.....just say AAWW YEAHH!
author: Lee M.

description: The restaurant is very casual, food is pretty good. They have big portions, so you can share one dish with 2 other people. We ordered lemon grass chicken spicy and curry chicken. The lemon grass chicken was excellent. I definitely would order it again. The curry chicken was also pretty good, but not my favorite. They don't have a good wine selection or anything fancy.
author: Sophie N.

description:
This is officially my favorite lunch spot in Potrero Hill! 

For my $9 lunch special I got:
Fresh shrimp spring rolls
Soup
Brown Rice
Spicy lemongrass chicken
Spicy green beans
side salad

This beats any bento box i've had at other places nearby. I've tried the 5 spice chicken, garlic noodles and curry here too and it's all good.

Also, the service is speedy so you won't have to run like a mad woman back to work.
author: Chrissy L.

description:
Yummy, yummy, yummy yummy goodness! I was so happy when the hubster finally agreed to return to eat at Sunflower. Every visit is memorable b/c their food is so rich in flavor, so distinct, and different meals. 
I love the shaken beef, the prawns with garlic noodles, coconut drink (in actual coconut you can eat it later), and the make your own spring roll appetizer. I am dreaming about going back soo and you should to. 

Only bummer is parking at times on a busy weekend or late night, but if you find one it is worth a try! Go and you might should find me their obsessing about their wonderful and tasty food.
author: Ana A.

description: Food is good, but the people who work at the conneticut location are rude as hell. Not going to that location ever again!!!
author: Paul S.

description:
I think this place is pretty good.  Really big portions (I always bring the leftovers home and make at least another meal out of it).  My favorite is the garlic noodles with beef (I think I've ordered that almost every time).  It's super garlicky which I absolutely love!

I've gone here for lunch and dinner and if you had to choose, I would definitely come here for lunch because the prices are cheaper and I honestly don't see a difference in the portion size at all.

I would recommend this place to my friends.  The neighborhood is cute too so talk a walk around if you'd like!
author: Jennifer I.

description:
pretty good pho!
awkward waiter and polcy to charge $1 for a cup if you want to split tea...
author: Virginie F.

description: My wife and I had lunch here while wandering around in Potrero Hill.  I had one of the lunch specials (lemongrass chicken) and was amazed at how much food I got for $9.  The soup and imperial rolls were both great, as we as the main dish.  There was a small salad that I could live without, but hard to complain at the price.  My wife got the five spice chicken plate and she really enjoyed it.  Friendly and fast service too.  There are a ton of restaurants on our list to try in this area, but this was definitely a good first choice!
author: Richard M.

description: DELICIOUS food. Another place I have taken all my friends and family that have visited. Cheap prices especially for the amount of food you get. Beautiful location with amazing views of downtown. Highly recommend this place!
author: Jasmine B.

description: Terrible service. Empty restaurant and they want to seat me near the kitchen?!!?  Come on people you are ruining the reputation of Asian restaurants. I left and would rather not eat there.
author: Mima G.

description: Really good. I was hoping to get multiple dishes at lunch and share but you only can order from lunch menu at lunch. It got pretty busy and it was a little hard to get out of there. Food was great!! Get the lemon grass beef!
author: Kat S.

description: We've eaten here for dinner and take out and both experiences were good.  The portions are HUGE.  We had bun with pork and imperial rolls and it was a massive bowl full of noodles, veggies, and meat.  It was tasty, but was not as flavorful as I think it could have been.  Their shaken beef was extremely tender and had a nice, rich flavor.  Their garlic noodles are also good.  Service was fast and friendly both for take out and dining in.  I think it's a good option, but not the best in San Francisco.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Not only was the service great and accommodating (the place was packed and they still made room to seat 3 of us quickly), but the Pho is just amazing.  One of the people I was with was in a bad mood and our server successfully made him smile and brightened his day (what a nice touch).

I am having dinner there tomorrow night and plan to explore the menu a bit more, and I just can't wait.
author: Cortney E.

description: I LOVED this place!!! It was so elegant, warm, bustling, positive, and beautiful inside. Very fast service. I have only tried the veggie thick noodle and imperial rolls but it was outstanding! It was totally jam packed on a Thursday night but service was perfect. This is a model restaurant operation that others should strive for. I loved being on Potrero Hill so I am sooo excited to come back soon!!
author: Libra J.

description:
It's really a blessing to have this place so close to where I attend school. In a pinch, I can always depend on them to serve me one of their quite economical lunch specials and eat it for lunch and dinner.

Their lunch specials, generally around $10 (tax inc.) comes with soup (usually a sweet and sour soup), a roll, salad, rice, and whatever meat you ordered. It's really filling and all the different ones I've tasted so far (lemongrass everything, bbq pork, 5 spice chicken) have all been great. 

The service is quite decent, except if you go when they're really busy. There's a waiter there who remembers little things about customers and also their faces, which is sort of amusing. They are super nice to you if you're a frequent customer. 

Just remember, if you want to split your check, tell them when you make your order. They won't do it at the end of your meal. Also, this place gets rather crowded if you go around lunch time so try to get there before or after 12ish...
author: Aka C.

description:
This place is right down the block from me and I love the convenience. They are really warm to me and treat me like family. I am a big fan of the lunch special which are always filling and delicious. Also, I love their vermicelli dishes, in fact the manager always teases me that I should order other things but I like it so much. The whole coconut is great when I am feeling subpar and want a little electrolyte boost, quite refreshing. 

To me this is what San Francisco is all about, walking out my door and into a restaurant that rocks.
author: Mario G.

description: Have enjoyed (/devoured) the veggie imperial rolls here several times since I first discovered Sunflower. They're delicious, and for the the price, the portions are large. So are the rolls though - too big for one bite, in fact. The restaurant can also fare on the warmer side, but this is otherwise a good option for vegetarians or selective meat eaters like myself.
author: Zach N.

description: I would love, love, love to give them more stars, their food is good but I'm afraid I can't go anymore because they have horrible customer service.  I wanted to have my 40th birthday party there, with 14 people and offered to guarantee by placing my credit card and they wouldn't help me out.  To me a place is not only about their food but also about how they treat their repeat customers.  This was also a way to introduce my friends to their restaurant so that they would come back on their own but they are too short sighted to realize this, no matter what I offered to guarantee this reservation - they wouldn't accomodate.  14 top table, guaranteed . . . nothing.  Good to know they are doing so well they can turn all this money away . . . and mind you, my group are all in the tech industry and love to eat.  As I told them, I won't be back and they'll miss out on this guaranteed fare.
author: Maria H.

description: My favorite place to get vermicelli! Fast and friendly service to boot!
author: Kevin W.

description:
Great find in the Potrero Hill area! I went here for the first time yesterday and have been looking for some decent Vietnamese food in the SOMA/Potrero hill area. I came here with a friend and I loved the decor and the service was quick and very attentive. Our water glasses were never empty and the food came out fast.

We split the popular garlic noodle with vegetable dish and the beef pho noodle soup. The garlic noodles were good and not TOO garlicky, if that's even possible. :) I heart garlic! The beef pho also had had a nice level of pepper and spice. I liked it even though it was "fancy pho." I will definitely come back. 

It's got what I need.
Good Location
Good Pho
Good Prices
Good Service
Good Food
Good Atmosphere
author: Katherine F.

description: Overall the food here was bland.  The garlic noodles were basically noddles and chicken; the vermicelli bowl was not as good as most others I have had and the fried rice was just ok.  The crepe was good but a little oily and the 5 spice chicken was good.  I'm not sure if I will come back.
author: Becky T.

description:
The service at Sunflower was fantastic... especially for how busy the place was at lunch time. I wish I could say that I was more excited about the food I ate. I love curry dishes, naturally I ordered the prawn coconut curry here. It was okay, but mostly disappointing. For the neighborhood, I think it's a good place to consider, since there aren't many other Vietnamese restaurants in around there. The price was right too, for the portions served. 

Overall, it's an OK spot to try out in Potrero Hill, but I am still in search of a great curry dish in San Francisco.
author: Nichole P.

description: One of the many choices on 18th & Connecticut. They seem busy the moment they open, especially weekdays over lunch. I ordered the spring rolls and the hot & sour fish soup. Both were okay. The place is clean, perhaps a tad more upscale than the place on Valencia, service is prompt, prices are okay....
author: Michael E.

description: Nice atmosphere, good vegetarian options, easy parking.
author: Amy B.

description:
1) Asian place in Pot Hill - Win

2) Portion sizes are huge! 
        $The garlic noodles (either lunch or dinner) is enough to feed two and then some. 
        $The pho was quite tasty and "clean". You know sometimes you can see oil beads in your soup, not here. 
        $ BBQ Lemongrass beef - thumbs waaay up!

3) The ambiance is pleasant. The seats are a little close together (it's SF what do you expect), but it's not awkwardly close. Great place to take out-of-towners if you live out this way. The prices are fair, especially for the portion sizes.
author: Rana A.

description:
Whoa - I've been here 4 times in the past month already!  That's a record for little ol' non-committal me.  

This space used to be Baraka back in the day - and funny enough, now that it's Sunflower - it still looks like Baraka.  Forgivable only because I really didn't like Baraka and Sunflower is infinitely yummier.  

So, the space is small and cozy - which could also be read as crowded and hot depending on which side of the bed you woke up on this morning or how starving you are.   Definitely tolerable though - I haven't had to wait for a table yet (but probably have been lucky enough to always be grabbing the last tables).  The servers are definitely quick at taking your order and getting your food to you but not in that "let me rush you through your meal" annoying kind of way.  They were all superbly friendly - which I think is part of the reason I still keep coming back.  

I really enjoyed everything I've had on the menu so far - the garlic noodles (nothing too special but comfort-style delicious - like other reviewers I don't get why they don't just call it PHO on the menu), the Vermicelli with Imperial Rolls (I get this every single time I've been), Garlic Eggplant (which says a lot considering I don't like eggplant like ... at all), BBQ Lemongrass beef (similar tasting to Korean BBQ - the menu listing says it all "grilled to delicious" ... MmmM), and the Shaken Beef (okay, so it's not the Slanted Door but still delish).  I asked for brown rice the last time I was here and was pleasantly surprised when they served us forbidden rice which I love but can be difficult to prepare (sometimes comes out too dry).  Luckily - it was pretty darn good here!  Overall - the food was tasty without feeling food-coma greasy.  Double-like!  

Definitely deserving of its spot on my weekly/bi-weekly "routine."
author: Jean A.

description: Fresh, creative, and delicious!!  Great price point, efficient service, decent location.  Two big thumbs up!  California/Asian/Vietnamese mix.  Healthy options as well as some great noodle dishes if you're all about the carbs!
author: Jory S.

description:
if its your first time here, don't look for the glowing neon sunflower sign that you're used to seeing on Valencia!

Hasn't been open for more than a month, but i already prefer this location to the tried and true mission location, since i'm a huge fan of the easy parking here, and the sophisticated upgraded diggs of this place has a totally different feel than the mission sunflower and no price increases either!

This isn't your average dirty (but good) vietnamese pho joint, like PPQ, but at the same time, it isn't exactly the posh overpriced fusion styled food with waterfront views like slanted door (but this place does have a great view of the city at night since its at the top of the hill). Its juuuuuuuuust right. something reasonable to put on your repertoire of restaurants to frequent, not sacrificing on taste.

The food came out surprisingly fast despite our group of 8 and it was crazy busy dinner time, the food was hot, and the aroma made my mouth water (must be all the garlic). This place serves portions that are big enough to split in a group of 4 or 5 ppl. The crowd seems to be a lot of folks that live in the vicinity, or fans of the original sunflower who are thrilled at the closer locale. the restaurant is located near a bunch of other small restaurants in a cute area. The crowd is lively, and 96.5 KOIT fills the air in the background... Oh yeah, i know this is a vietnamese-chinese influence restaurant but they do serve thai iced tea!!! 

Prime dinner hrs, you'll probably have to wait a little for a seat, but around 8:30 or 9pm, seats are pretty readily available. 

I will def come back for my fav dishes, maybe try a new one here and there, if i find a new fav, i'll definitely post. 

The night ended well and everyone left satisfied and full without breaking the bank... thank goodness.

my favs:
shaken beef (surprisingly large tender chunks of beef)
sunflower prawns (comes on top of garlic noodles!!! SO YUM, this has to be my ultimate fav b/c its like two dishes in one and its huge, love the texture of the noodles too)
combination appetizer (imperial spring rolls so good!)
sea bass

p.s. they also have lunch specials which is awesome, i wish i could have ordered take out here when i was at my old townsend office. 

p.p.s. their bathroom is clean! a bonus! :D

p.p.p.s. they serve their beer in chilled glasses! CHEERS!
author: Irene C.

description: The vermicelli 5 spice chicken was featured as a "big eat" by 7x7. I call it a big disappointment. The chicken was dry and tough with hardly any 5 spice flavor. The second star was because the chicken salad we also ordered was good.
author: R. P.

description: Called after 1:00 p.m. to place a large take out dinner order; the lady who answered the phone said she could not take the order, and maybe I should call back later when they are not so busy. Really? Have a clue, you lost business today.
author: Bentley L.

description:
Another "top-dollar" Vietnamese restaurant located in pricey Potrero Hill.

Ordered the appetizer combination, which is basically make-your-own spring roll.  Unfortunately, I don't do very well with rolling spring rolls, so I ended up eating it like a salad.

Garlic noodles were delicious.  But my favorite part dish was the crispy sea bass with ginger sauce.  Probably the best dish on their menu in my opinion was the sea bass.  Another negative, is that they don't have a dessert menu...boo-hoo.

But the service was super-friendly and super attentive.  My water glass was always filled and the wait staff was constantly checking up on us.  It seems they have a regular clientele, because the employees knew half the people eating there, or at least they seemed they did, which goes right back to me saying that they are super-friendly.  I will def be back here soon!
author: Emmett B.

description: Great place to bring my vegetarian friends, we order the Garlic noodles with veggies
author: Tia G.

description:
sunflower is not bad. it's quite comparable to all the other vietnamese restaurants that i have been to around the city. the food is good, the service was good, the price was reasonable. 

so why only 3 stars? this place just didn't blow me away. there's no excitement, no motivation or urge. don't get me wrong- i wouldn't mind coming back here again... i just won't go out of my way to eat here.

fyi, if you order the banh xeo or seafood crepe, be prepared to see a whole bag of bean sprouts stuffed in the crepe. there's so much bean sprouts that your daily recommended veggie/fruit intake will be fulfilled after taking a crack at this appetizer.
author: The Hangry Chef O.

description:
I went here last night for dinner with my sister and was pleasantly surprised. It doesn't look like much from the outside, but looks can be deceiving. 

It is located in a great area of Potrero hill on the corner of 18th and Connecticut. Parking is a little tough, since there are so many houses and restaurants in this one area, but we found a spot a couple blocks away. There is also a Bus stop for the 22 right in front of it. 

As far as service, we were seated right away in the window at 7 (not too many people there yet). We decided to share a couple things, so we ordered the Vegetable Imperial Rolls to start and for our entree we shared the Garlic Noodles with Chicken and the Shaken Beef. Everything was really tasty and fresh. The amount of Garlic they use in the Garlic Noodles is unreal. When I got home, my girlfriend told me I reeked, but at least no vampires came into our house.

They brought out the Imperial rolls before the meal (always good when it is generally an appetizer). And they brought out the Noodles and Beef at around the same time after we had some time to enjoy our appetizer. We hung out and talked for about 2 hours here and never once did we feel like we were being rushed to get out or anything. They even kept bringing us water even though we already paid the bill and continued to chat for an hour. Because of this alone, I give them 5 stars. To top that off, they had really good food and it is located in a great area of SF.
author: Michael C.

description:
I'm glad enterprising folk are adding wallet-friendly dining options to this area. You can't always shell out for Chez Papa, or have the patience to wait at Chez Maman.   You never saw the point in overpriced mediocre thai food at Lingba or overpriced mediocre chinese food at Eliza's.  You don't want to take a chance on sushi at Umi - http://www.yelp.com/biz/umi-san-francisco#hrid:QOwKSnLO_ZKc2lPVXfJmkQ -  and you just don't feel like pizza, even if it is Goat Hill.  

Sunflower is a much needed/welcome dining option in this hood.  Lines form nightly now and it's unclear how long it will take to settle down.  I can forgive the service kinks but the food needs some work.  Garlic noodles were oily and bland except for a harsh, rather than sweet (naturally sweet) garlic flavor.  The saltiness of the shaken beef nearly killed me, had me chugging water for the rest of the night - and I have the post mortem puffy eyes to prove it.  

The waitstaff are mixed and various people will take your order, bring your order, chat you up.  There is sharp-tongued host who comes by from time to time ~ she was a crack up.  But our waitress for the rest of the time didn't speak any english, which was a bit frustrating when I tried to ask for a hot sauce.  Things got worse when the dish we ordered was brought over to the table next to us instead. Our neighbors protested they ordered their garlic noodles with tofu not veges, but she insisted it came to the right table, even though we tried to tell her it was probably ours.  They decided to switch up and dug in just before she rushed to whisk the plate back to the kitchen.  But 10 seconds later she reappeared with the dish to our table.  

Now, would you have said something?  Cause riddle me this.  You complain that the dish was the same one that the woman next to you served herself out of, but how do you know?  And how do you insist on getting a new one and know that a) you will get a new one or b) that your insistence won't just spark the ire in your server, who looks too tired to give a poop what you're eating anyway.  

I hope the success of this place attracts other entrepreneurial spirits too.  Next time I want a dining room vietnamese food experience I'll head over to Pagolac instead.  But for a wallet-friendly dining option in the area, I'd probably climb down the hill and head over to hard knox in the dogpatch.
author: Nikki F.

description:
I'm big on coconut curries, but this one seemed a little weak. 

Rather than order one of the lunch specials (which were good deals, but didn't offer any of the curries), I opted for the Seafood Curry and I was a little bit disappointed. The dish was kind of plain...it tasted like curries that I've made at home, with no extra "pizzaz" to make me happy that I'm paying $10 for it. This curry was also a bit spicier than I'm used to, as most coconut curries tend to be more mild. 

The restaurant itself is beautiful, the staff was chatty and fun, and the place was packed. I'm certainly not sold on their curries, but the brown rice here was fantastic, and the coconut drink (get it) was awesome. 

In summary: cheap prices, mediocre curry, nice atmosphere. A-OK.
author: Tom A.

description:
Opens at 5PM on Sunday. We went here for dinner on Sunday at 5PM. The menu was pretty typical. I had the chicken pho ($7.50) for my entree and split imperial rolls (don't remember the price) for the appetizer. It was all really good. I'm really full. The quantity was on par with a large from Pho Hoa, but this tasted way way more fresh. I was not disappointed with any of the food. The pho was also a little spicier than what I've had at other places. So note to self next time, try the pho before adding rooster sauce. Yes, I was sweating a ton after eating. 

They have a wine list and the prices are pretty reasonable. 

Worth it to try.
author: Andrew Y.

description: Good food... awful service. Do NOT come here if you have any food allergies. They will not even attempt to help you figure out what you can eat on the menu and are pretty rude about it.   If you don't have any allergies, the bbq lemongrass beef is the way to go.
author: aaron h.

description: This is my favorite restaurant. The food is always amazing (the beef noodle soup and BBQ pork especially). They are alway friendly and quick. My husband and I always take our out of town guests here and it's always a crowd pleaser.
author: Samantha A.

description:
We went to Sunflower with friends of ours who recommended. We went about 7:30 on a Friday, they don't take reservations, so we had to wait a while to get in. It is a tiny restaurant and since we had a group of 4 we had to wait outside. It was about 15 minutes before we got in. They took us to a back booth behind a curtain with throw pillows and fluffy felt covered cushions. They said they got us in there because someone had cancelled their reservation (even though they don't take reservations...). But I didn't complain because we were able to get in and had a great booth away from everyone else. 
The food portions are huge and we ordered WAY too much food. What we ordered for the 4 of us could have fed 8... 
Here is what we got: the imperial rolls, the calamari salad, the crab meat and sweet corn soup, bbq pork and imperial rolls vermicelli, prawn noodles, garlic beef and spicy green beans with a few sides of rice. The food was delicious. 
The service got a little slow at the end and it took a while to finally pay. Oh, and the prices are CHEAP!!! I can't believe how inexpensive for really good food. We were definitely satisfied and will be ordering it for take-out. The only thing I didn't like about eating there was that when you left, your coat and clothes smelled like the restaurant.
author: Alycia N.

description:
A SOLID, VIETNAMESE RESTAURANT THAT'S CONVENIENT FOR POTRERO RESIDENTS. 

This is one of the favorite restaurants in the neighborhood.  Since I live in Portero, I like to go to Sunflower to get a quick bite to eat or grab take-out.  My favorite dishes are the Sizzling Seafood (the fish is very tasty, especially in the chili sauce) and the crab fried rice.  The garlic noodles are good too.  However, their soup - their Vietnamese hot and sour - was way watery and overpriced for a couple of pineapple chunks and mushrooms.  The Pho is ok - I had better Pho in other places.  If you want Pho, stick with the beef.  The vegetable Pho was tasteless.  

Overall, a good place for some quick, affordable Asian food.  Now they just need to add garlic Crabs!
author: Chegi P.

description:
I love this place! Much better ambience than the Valencia and 16th locations, if you can make the trek. The service is fast and the prices are reasonable.

Highlights: They have vegetarian Pho, which can be hard to find.
-Spicy String Beans-so good!
-The Salads- a new find of mine
-The appetizer combo- a must! Imperial roll (you can get veggie for an additional $1...strange I know, why would subtracting meat cost more...), BBQ beef or pork, and grilled prawns, so good! Then you get a side plate of veggies, sauce and rice paper to roll it all together! Not to be missed!
-Vietnamese Ice Coffee or Thai Ice Tea- both so tasty and they have Tsing Tao, a great Chinese beer

Tip: Use the sauces and veggies they give you to make the flavors pop. The noodle bowls and veggie Pho can be a little bland if you don't add all the sauces and mix it well.
author: Anna Z.

description:
I was so torn by this place - figuratively and literally.  First, I was sad that a taqueria wasn't going in this space (18th St needs one!), but then I was happy when I discovered that at least an affordable place was joining the neighborhood.  Then, I tried the food and liked it, but later on my stomach dissented.  What a roller coaster ride!

I went for lunch two weeks ago.   I noticed that the decor had not changed from the previous restaurant, except for the increased number of tables. I liked the interior before, so I guess why mess with a good thing?

I ordered the bbq pork special, which included an imperial roll, soup, and salad.  Everything tasted fine.  One friend had the crepe, and she seemed to love it, and it came in a healthy-sized portion. 

Immediately after lunch, my stomach started to get upset.  Long story short, I was late picking up my sister at the airport because of my issues (we're all friends here, right?  So I can admit this).  I have actually been to Vietnam, and never once did I have an attack there, so I feel pretty dismayed that a Vietnamese place a block from my house did me in.  

Today, I found that they got an 86 on their routine health inspection, losing points for these reasons: 

019 (CFR) Inadequate/Inaccessible handwashing facilities & supplies
020 (CFR) Improper hot/cold holding temperatures
032 (CFR) Unapproved thawing methods used
050 (CFR) Improper or Defective plumbing/No backflow devices/Improper connections

Connection to my stomach problems?  Maybe, but I'm not chancing it with a revisit.
author: Kim S.

description: The food here has never disappointed me. While the parking situation is a bit of a pain, and the staff can be a bit short/abrasive at times, they are both worth dealing with for the quality of the food!
author: Ashley T.

description: The Beef Vermicelli is soooo goood and sooooo filling it's life changing! Call in your order if you're in the rush. The service is good even though they're always packed. You definitely get bang for your buck here. Noms!
author: Nikki W.

description:
Quite a gem located in Potrero Hill! I never quite make it out to this area, but would definitely come again for Sunflower.

I ate here for the first time a couple days ago with my coworkers. We were there to celebrate with our coworker who is leaving on maternity leave soon. We had a large party so when we got there, we had to push some tables together. Our very pregnant coworker attempted to help us, when the waiters/waitresses made her sit down and rest. In fact, I think they gave us special treatment after that. No water with umbrellas in it like we had asked for (j/k!) but they went all out with different orders of water, hot water, and water with lime. Definitely a plus that the staff was so attentive. 

I ordered the garlic noodles which I was really looking forward to. The last time I had garlic noodles was at Perilla located in SOMA, so I was expecting a very similar, hearty and buttery dish. The noodles were not quite as garlic-y as I expected. Nor was it as buttery and heart-clogging. But maybe that's what it needed?! Anyways, the dish it self was pretty good - chicken was a bit dry; the beef combo looked way better. The next time I come back, I am definitely trying one of their curry dishes instead. My coworker across from me ordered the dish, and I could just smell the curry as it was coming out! It looked (and smelled) delicious! And did I mention the portions are huge?
author: Lina W.

description:
My friend and I had dinner here Friday evening.  We arrived a little before 7:30pm and got seated right a way.  The tables along the walls were a little too close together, impeding entrance and exit, and you kinda had to share (eavesdrop on) conversation with people at the next table, making it less intimate an experience, but hey I was not on a date, so it was okay.

The place was pretty quaint with red walls, definitely a step up from many of the utilitarian Vietnamese restaurants I usually go to.  My friend and I did family style and shared:

Sunflower Crepe
Garlic noodles with vegetables
Shaken beef

Our favorite was the Crepe.  It comes as lightly golden crispy "crepe" which is thicker and fluffier than the French Crepe, stuffed with fresh bean sprouts, chicken and seafood (pieces of plump sweet shrimp).  Accompanying it is a plate of lettuce, mint leaves, pickled julienned carrots and slices of cucumbers, and the sweet/sour sauce.  We wrapped hunks of the crepe in lettuce, topped with the pickled vegis and the sauce, and ate it with our hands.  The contrast between crispy hot crepe and the cool vegis was so unexpectedly delicious!  It was a little messy but well worth it.

The garlic noodles and the shaken beef were also good, but we decided next time to try the noodles with one of the other options; tofu, chicken, beef, or shrimp (2 pieces).  The vegetables that were added to the noodles at our request were a little too big and crunchy and were difficult to eat.  The shaken beef was tender.

All in all a great experience and my friend has added this place to her list of take-out places.  Oh yes, they do take outs and I suspect that this is a popular option for people who live the neighborhood, because the counter was PACKED with take out bags at dinner time.  You can download their takeout menu from their website.
author: Alice A.

description: I love Sunflower for its food, service, and environment! It makes a great date place.  It is one of the most consistently yummy Vietnamese places to eat in Potrero Hill. My favorites are the Sunflower prawns with garlic noodles, spicy green beans, and vegetable spring rolls. It's hard from me to try anything else new because these dishes are lip smacking good. The portions are huge so bring lots of people with you to share. Unless you want the left over garlic noodles for yourself the next day! Bottle of wine selection is good and at reasonable prices.
author: Kathy J.

description:
Absolutely amazing little gem in potrero hill!!

we ordered:

- garlic noodle with prawns - personal fav. the sauce was amazing and i love the noodle which was not overly cooked and not dry. amazing dish.
- vermicelli with BBQ pork - i have had a lot of vermicelli so my standards are pretty high. This one meets my expectation in terms of quality and quantity. the bbq pork was cooked to perfection.

bonus? there's a bus that takes you right to the door. 

need i say more? Go try if you havent. i will definitely visit again.
author: J P.

description:
Mmmm, good stuff.  I think Sunflower may be a perfect fit for 18th and Connecticut.  This is a cursed location, nothing ever survives here for long, but maybe Sunflower can make a run at it.

Fried tofu was unlike any I have had before, it was stuffed with lemongrass!  Mmmm, delicious.  

Vermicelli was perfectly cooked.  Veggie Imperials were a tad greasy, but thats just how it is with Imperial Rolls.  

Prompt, friendly service, not too crowded (but enough people to make it lively) , and pretty cheap for Potrero Hill.

I don't think this place is going to compete too much with Lingba or Elizas.  It is defiantly Vietnamese, not some Asian hybrid.
author: Troy S.

description: This place is not all that great. They give you large portion but it doesnt mean its good. The only thing I like here is the Eggroll.
author: Aniko N.

description:
Having gone to college at UC Davis and now working in the SF Bay Area, I've had my fair share of Vietnamese food so I didn't think I'd find anything new when my friend suggested we go to Sunflower for lunch. 
Boy was I wrong! First of all, walking into the cute little restaurant with chardonnay colored walls, silk drapes and wrought iron candleholders, I was taken aback - not your typical Vietnamese decor. It's a small space and there were a few other tables occupied, but by the time we left the place was packed.

I ordered the lemongrass chicken lunch plate and was not prepared for the amount of food that came out. They serve it on a large round dish (bigger than the average dinner plate) and it comes with crispy Imperial rolls, fresh papaya salad, rice and a steaming bowl of soup. Whatever meat you choose comes sauteed with spicy, garlicky green beans - absolutely delicious! All of that for a thrifty $8.50.

My friends ordered the garlic noodles and veggie fried rice and both were perfection. The food is served hot and fresh, just the way I like it. I didn't care much for the soup which was a sweet, pineapple-chicken broth concoction, but everything else gets two thumbs up. I can't wait to come back to sample the rest of the menu.
author: Gigi V.

description:
Finally, a Vietnamese restaurant that isn't in the Mission or the Tenderloin. I have dined at Sunflower in the Mission but this second location - in the old Baraka space - is much nicer. The food is excellent. I recommend the crispy fried fish and spicy string beans. The shaken beef is ok, a bit bland. The fresh coconut juice is wonderful. 

On opening night it was absolutely packed. So making reservations is a must. We just walked in and sat at the bar.
author: Esme V.

description:
I had lunch here today with a friend. The place was 2/3 empty at 12:45 p.m. so we picked a nice comfy table and sat down. The waitress asked us how many in our party. When I replied "2" she informed us we had to move to the other side of the restaurant that was packed with small 2 person tables.
I told her that I'd rather sit on the nice, cushy seats and not be surrounded by diners on either side because we'd like to have a conversation. That did not register with her at all. She just kept saying we had to move.
The food was tasty, and the service quick. Also, the prices were reasonable. If they had any customer service at this restaurant I would have given them 5 stars. But they don't.
I watched the cushy-seated tables stay empty for the hour plus we were there and it left a bad taste in my mouth. 
Luckily San Francisco is jam packed with wonderful restaurants that DO want my business, so I will patronize those establishments. Bye-bye, Sunflower!
author: Tim G.

description:
This is my favorite lunch spot in Potrero Hill. It goes a little something like this, "Hmmm, should I spend $10 on a Whole Foods buffet salad with two crouton-sized-bits-o'-cold-chicken-cooked-two-days-ago-so-it-wouldn't-go-bad OR spend $7 on 5-spiced yumminess on top of vermicelli noodles... WITH THE BEST IMPERIAL ROLLS IN TOWN to boot?"

I always liked the number 7.
author: Danny E.

description: They only have one high chair which was taken before us. They didn't apologize or tried to accommodate us. We left and took note of how we were being ignored.
author: Mary S.

description:
As a regular snacker at the Mission Sunflowers, I was thrilled yet apprehensive about their arrival in my neighborhood. The location they're in seems to be cursed-- all restaurants I've ever seen there have lasted a few years at most. Could Sunflower break the spell?

The ambiance is sheer gentrification, reflected in the all-English menu and fancy wine list. The condiments come in little jars with spoons instead of squeeze bottles, but that's just the trappings. The flavors are the same, and that's a good thing.

But I'll probably just go to the Mission locations, anyway. This ambiance is not for me. Good luck, Sunflower!
author: Jaina D.

description: First time I've had Vietnamese and I really enjoyed it! Their vegetarian options are great, and they cook their vegetables perfectly with a crunch. If you like saucy, there are many saucy dishes, if you like light and fresh, there are many options. The portions are enough for two meals in my opinion and the menu is very reasonably priced.
author: Breena M.

description:
HOORAY!!!!  Affordable, yummy eats in the 'hood!!!

The place is a bit small and there are no reservations, but those would be my only negatives.  Had to wait for a table for 5, but they had us give them a cell phone number so we could have a drink across the street.  Service was fun and friendly, food delicious, filling, and cheap.  Will definitely be going back and also ordering take-out.
author: Patrick P.

description:
Convenient parking, table ready for us - a perfect way to start a meal.

We walked in and were very happy to see a familiar face. We had been frequent guests of Grandeho in Cole Valley and saw that Leslie was now working at Sunflower.

We ordered the following:
Imperial Rolls
Shaken Beef
Garlic Vegetables
Sunflower Prawns

The dishes were all amazing. They have the option of brown rice which is great for people wanting to eat more on the healthy side. The beef was very tender and well seasoned. The Veggies were super duper fresh. The Prawns were huge and on a bed of yummy garlic noodles. They also brought the food out super fast. I liked that they served fresh coconut juice. We loved everything and will be back. The wait staff was on top of everything - they recommended great things and read our minds when they brought boxes by. The prices are very affordable as well.
author: Vanessa W.

description:
Vietnamese? Really? Cause I could have sworn that what was on my plate was much more Thai related than anything else. 

Aside from this geographical sidestep, the food was quite good. Prepared quickly and served piping hot, we enjoyed such delicacies as steamed pot stickers (tofu stuffed of course), BBQ meat and lemongrass chicken with some jasmine (aka white) rice on the side. Though the portions were more than accommodating I feel that the lack of flavor was a deal breaker. Give me somethin' to work with here people.
author: Stephanie J.

description: Pretty good Vietnamese without having to go all the way to the westside or to the other location in the TL. The pho is pretty good and service is decent. I like sitting near the window and enjoying the views of sunny Portero. oh, love the fresh coconut juice!
author: Emm C.

description:
I'm a very happy customer!

The Vietnamese Potstickers are fantastic. Not like Chinese potstickers, these are rice balls filled with pork, shrimp, mushrooms, and carrots. They are deep fried, so when you bite into that outer layer of rice, you get  a nice crunch. Server with hoisin sauce, it's a nice way to start a meal.

Beware... the Garlic Noodles are addictive! They are so simple, but so enjoyable. You have the option to add a protein or vegetables, but they are perfectly fine on their own.

If you're in the mood for something fresh and healthy, their salads come in generous proportions and could be a meal on their own. A huge bowl of shredded cabbage, carrots, mint, topped with roasted ground peanuts and fish sauce with your choice of chicken, beef, shrimp or calamari -- mmm, good!

They have a good selection of entrees. The Shaken Beef is a favorite -- tender cubes of beef in a wonderful glaze of garlicky goodness. The Steamed Sea Bass is lightly infused with the spice and aroma of ginger. I also like the tender Five Spice Roasted Chicken.

The staff is friendly and attentive. The decor hasn't changed at all from its previous incarnation (Baraka), which is fine. They don't deliver, but it's easy enough to order and pick up. It's one of my favorite neighborhood restaurants.
author: Joel A.

description: I go here for takeout at least once per week.  Great food, quick service and a consistently great staff.
author: Rick C.

description:
Sunflower Potrero Hill was exactly what I expected.  Faux-chic decor, faux-chic table settings, mediocre but totally edible Americanized-Asian food.  

The restaurant is very P-Hill, which is lovely, but its just so bland and...white.  I love Potrero, I live there, but I wish we could get an ethnic restaurant with a little more grit, a little more authenticity.    

I will compliment the very attentive service, even during a Thursday night rush.  And its not that the food is bad, its just "eh".  Its too clean, honestly.  And I was a little miffed by the fact that they don't call Pho "Pho" on the menu-- they call it "Noodle Soup."  This is San Francisco, we're mostly over-educated, well-travelled folk.  We know what Pho is.  And we'd rather get it in the Tenderloin.
author: Kristin P.

description: This place rules. The lunch special is amazing. Get the BBQ Pork. The Hot and Sour soup is amazing. No question. If you are in that annoying nest of a neighborhood, go eat here. You won't regret it.
author: F.f. Durst D.

description: Let 3 groups of people in front of us tonight because they were greedy, and/or too stupid to push 2 tops together.  They had 2 opportunities within a 5 minute period to do so, and instead of seating our group of 3, filled them each in with groups that had immediately arrived.  Although their portion sizes are pretty good for the price (at least in SF), their food isn't really that great anyway.  Will be boycotting this place from now on.
author: xxxx x.

description:
Very tasty Vietnamese in a very clean and friendly space. What more can you ask for?  And it's inexpensive, too.

The only thing I don't like about Sunflower, and this explains why I am taking out a star, is their neon green chopsticks.  Neon green + burgundy interior = yuck!
author: Jun B.

description:
Honestly, Im actually not a fan of the other Sunflower locations so my expectations were low when I visited this location. I was however pleasantly surprised because the food was really tasty. I ordered the Vermicelli bowl with Bbq pork and springrolls - which was really good. The Mrs  - ordered the Lemongrass chicken " wrap style" - this dish was also decent - it came with lots of fresh green veggies and the chicken was well seasoned and very flavorful! The rice paper though was cold - they should serve this warm. We also ordered a side of garlic noodles which were tasty as well - they were not so greasy like other restaurants that  serve this dish.

I think I am going to be a regular.
author: Christian S.

description: 5 starts for lemongrass chicken lunch special.  soo tasty, and only like $8.  the service can be snappy, but in an endearing way.
author: Steven S.

description:
We went here because my wife wanted Elizas but we got to Potrero and found out that the 'new location' on California wasn't an expansion but a relocation.  So we decided to try Sunflower.

Pretty mediocre.  The Hot & Sour soup was sickeningly sweet, and had such 'Asian' flavors as tomatoes and jalapenos.  I think they dumped a whole can of diced pineapple in, with the sugar water.  We also had the noodle crepe; over-fried and bland, and the fried sea bass, which wasn't much to speak of.  The decor is fine, the service is good.  But there are five other restaurants on the same block, including another Laotian/Vietnamese place, so they had better sort themselves out because the other spots are almost certainly better. Yes, it was inexpensive.  But so are taquerias, they're 50% cheaper and twice as good.  Skip it.
author: Mark G.

description: Love the food here. Probably the best garlic noodles in town! I also think the pho is the best in town. The only thing I am not crazy about is their sauteed dishes like calamari. Four stars only because their service is not the friendliest. Even that started to change. I started noticing wait staff to be friendlier in the last two visits. I may upgrade them to five stars if the trend continues. But the food really rocks here!
author: bora o.

description: Totally decent Vietnamese. I liked the shrimp spring rolls and the garlic noodles. The shaking beef wasn't as good as elsewhere.
author: Eadweard M.

description: The pho here is as ood as any I've had, and I really enjoyed it! A few friends I was with got the spicy seafood combo and the lemongrass chicken, which were delicious! It's casual, fresh and the service was very good. One other plus: the view of the city is spectacular.
author: T. Y.

description:
