Food is great and the ambiance is romantic and sensual.  It is a different experience than the mission branch... you get the cheap good food AND a nice quiet upscale ambiance.
author: farangis f.

description: This is for the takeout for Sunflower: Not great. The Pho is dull, the garlic noodles were lacking garlic, while the garlic vegetables was positively smothered with garlic and overwhelmed.  Potstickers were bland. Spring rolls were good, though. But after two experiences, I don't plan on ordering again.
author: Graham M.

description: A decent Vietnamese place on Potrero Hill. I like the chicken they serve because it's very tender.
author: O L.

description: Man date on a Tuesday was pretttty good. I just started to get into Vietnamese food so I can't critique the food too much. I had the standard vermicelli w/ bbq beef. I thought it was good and of great portion (dinner + breakfast). Still can't tell the difference too much between the vermicelli, it seems like a dish you can't really f*ck up. Anyway, I like this place cuz I just moved to Pot Hill and it is inexpensive comparatively. I will definitely be going back, but.... I don't think its a place to get reservations for on a Friday night
author: Stan W.

description:
Great restaurant. When we came in, we wanted the private table for 6 in the back, partly cuz one of us was on crutches. The hostess was initially very rude, but turned out to be super cool. She was joking with us throughout dinner and we chatted for a while after eating.

The food was fantastic and the ambience was very nice.

Spicy lemongrass chicken was a definite favorite. Spicy green beans were a close second. The "small" soups are pretty big and definitely shareable. Curry prawns were great as well.
author: Nithin R.

description: I love this place - you in fact get what you pay for. Very good, fresh and lively dishes that are very easy on the wallet. I have had dishes that were great, and others that were simply good. But I've been happy with every dish, and the staff is lovely - and they've made a great use of space that has otherwise been acoustically problematic for the other higher end businesses/menus.
author: I. V.

description: Pretty meh.  Clothes stank of the kitchen which is never a good sign. Can find much better vietnamese elsewhere
author: Bitzz B.

description: Great food with great hospitality! The food is delicious with the fish claypot and BBQ pork vermicilli dishes being my favorite. The portions are very good with the standalone vermicilli dishes being impossible to finish unless you're ravenous (at ~$8.50 they're a steal).
author: Abhik P.

description: My office is near here and we frequently order takeout lunches. We've never been disappointed. The servings are large and the food is fresh and tasty. Especially great is the lemongrass-stuffed tofu; it's fun to watch guests who are trying it for the first time, as their faces light up when they bite into that lemongrass layer. My only complaint is that it's a noisy place to eat in--hard to hear your dining companions talking.
author: Laurie W.

description: the pho is not the most authentic, but it's pretty damn good. (i like pho made with weird stuff like tripe and tendons). it's, hands down, the best hangover food in the world.the other entrees are delish as well and prices are very reasonable. a staple place for me due to both it's proximity to mi casa as well as previously stated qualities.
author: cyrus t.

description: The garlic noodles are fab. If you're vegetarian, get them with tofu. Add the spicy green beans and veg spring rolls and you've got an ample, tasty veg meal for 3-4 folks for under $30 bucks! According to my non veg people, the other stuff is great, too!
author: Wendy R.

description: I love the crispy egg noodles and the pho is my favorite among all the Vietnamese places I have tried...and I've tried a lot of them.  I also love the staff and have been treated very well every time I go in.  I definitely recommend this spot to anyone wanting a great deal for really great food.
author: Sench M.

description: mediocre food AND rude snarky service???  No thanks.
author: Fallon C.

description:
After discovering that the nearby Chinese restaurant was no more, and still in the mood for Asian, decided to stop at Sunflower. 

The interior was nice, though perhaps some of the tables were a bit close to each other. The service was quite efficient and friendly. My entree was OK, nothing spectacular, but then again I was trying something different. The Vegetarian Hot & Sour soup was tasty though. 

I would like to try a few more items on the menu, and maybe be surprised!
author: Rodney S.

description: I'm happy they finally opened.  Been there 3 times and got pho twice.  Its listed as beef noodle soup, but its your basic pho.  The broth isn't quite what I prefer, kinda short on flavor compared to others I've enjoyed.  No tripe or tendon though, which is a shame.  It feels a little too simple a version of a dish that is capable of so much rich dimension.  I love how close it is to my house, but if I had a car I'd look farther afield if I were looking for some good pho.
author: Godis A.

description: After a quick snack of Creole food, I was still hungry, and since one of my friends lives on Potrero Hill, she suggested Sunflower. I'd never been, and Vietnamese sounded light enough. I was correct, cuz we ordered the Combo Appetizer and Fresh Shrimp Spring Roll. The Combo was on the messy side, but I clearly needed practice with making the wraps. As for the rolls, they weren't anything special but very fresh. Spent just a little over $20 and it was worth it.
author: Jaime J.

description: Yum yum yum. Love the garlic noodles. And the portions. You'll sure to have extras.
author: jennifer t.

description: I'm very particular about where I go for Vietnamese food. I must say this place is pretty darn good authentic Vietnamese food. The service is quite respectable as well especially for the affordable price of the meal. I would definitely go back. It's in a super adorable neighborhood as well.
author: Kelly N.

description: It's OK food, but generally low quality. Last time we went the spring rolls tasted like soap, and we decided that was the last time.  Sux because I live two doors down...
author: Geoff L.

description: Great food, good service, inexpensive! What's not to like?
author: jesse j.

description: This is the kind of restaurant that makes me proud to be an "honorary resident" of Potrero Hill (i.e., frequently resident on P-Hill friends' futon).  Cute Vietnamese place with great neighborhood ambiance.  Service was fast and pleasant.  I had the best lemongrass beef in a long time here, and even put aside my dislike of leftovers to enjoy the leftovers the following day.  Although my days in SF are numbered, and I'm trying to visit/revisit as many favorite restaurants as possible, I'll still have to make time to come back here.
author: B L.

description: good food, fresh, reasonable prices.  for what it is this is pretty good.  lemongrass chicken was delicious.
author: sarah b.

description: Cheap, efficient service and good Vietnamese food.  Enjoy the spring rolls and rice noodle with 5 spice chicken.  not a huge fan of the garlic noodles - too bland.
author: Stacy N.

description: The food is especially delicious here and generously sized and I love the fact that they left the decor as it was in Baraka (an upgraded aesthetic from their Mission area  venue), but I also want to compliment them on their exceptionally friendly service. It is refreshing to be greeted by such a friendly staff, a welcome change from their neighbors across the way (Aperto) who scowl at you if you dare to bring your own (superior) cup of coffee to their brunch service. In such hard economic times it would be wise for restaurants to follow the model of the Sunflower staff's sunny disposition. Such friendliness makes eating out well worth the splurge, while few of us have any reason to frequent a business full of haughty waiters.
author: Ruth M.

description: I live down the street and was THRILLED when Sunflower opened. I'm a fan of the other restaurants on 18th street but it's always nice to have a "go to" asian food joint. We frequently order out from here, but it actually has a nice interior (the space formerly housed the tapas place Baraka). My "must order" items are the garlic noodles and the imperial rolls. I also love the vermicelli noodle bowls, the clay pots, and the shaken beef dishes - and the brown rice option is a big plus! Portions are hearty and quality of food is definitely up there. A great alternative if you don't want to trek to the tenderloin for good Vietnamese food.
author: Kylene S.

description: love the garlic noodles and the string beans. so tasty and fresh.   the lemon grass chicken was awesome (it has string beans too!!!)  all so good! mmmmmmmmm
author: Elaine Y.

description: We had a fantastic meal here the other night.  In particular, we really enjoyed the eggplant stir fry.  It wasn't slimy at all, and had a really good, not-overdone flavor.  We'll certainly be back.
author: David B.

description: I am so excited about this place!  We wanted a light dinner after a weekend of heavy eating.  We ordered the lean pork and shrimp salad and the shrimp and chicken vietnamese crepe.  They were both oustanding!  Also, the portions were huge.  We ordered that to go with some leftovers but didn't end up eating the leftovers as those 2 dishes were enough for 2 adults.  Oh, and I love the fact that I can throw a rock at it from my front door!  Yeah!!!!!  So happy it is open.
author: PHill Resident G.

description: We live in the area, saw the reviews thought we would give it a try... big mistake. The service was inattentive--no one was watching the line at the door or the open tables. Once we were seated the waiter did not greet us, rather she simple barked "What you want to drink?"  The menu looked promising but when the appetizers (crepe and pot stickers) arrived the pot stickers were lumps of something that looked like they came frozen from 7Eleven and tarted up with Rice Krispies, the crepes were not better, being so greasy they stuck to our teeth and left a pool of oil on the plate. Both were left unfinished. The entrees, beef noodles and combo pan fried noodles, were no better--very bland and very greasy lacking any flavor save for the generous portion of MSG in both. The pan friend noodles had been cooked well in advance and had solidified into a single glutinous mass requiring a knife to cut them into slices. The random ingredients meant to add flavor to the dish looked like someone was cleaning out the fridge rather than following a traditional Vietnamese recipe. The beef noodles while generous in portion size appeared to have been made with canned stock and lacked any flavor--or actual real beef. The waiter forgot to bring the basil, bean sprouts and chili for the beef noodles but given they were only offering three wilted basil leaves with the spouts I can see how he overlooked them. When we asked about the chili, we were told that was for carry out orders only. We had to ask a second waiter to get the chili--which regrettably did not manage to make the meal edible. As with the appetizers, both entrees where left unfinished. While the physical space is acceptable, the quality of the service and the food are not. By far the worst meal we have had in San Francisco.
author: Colin C.

description: Nice authentic food in a nice fun area, the owner is always there and very friendly with good sense of humor that maybe doesn't suit everybody if you don't get it, overall when you go there and eat you should relax more than being too concern, they also have a great booth for larger party and it's private.
author: A D.

description: easy parking. fast service. bright, comfortable and airy ambiance.. friendly service. LOVE the fresh and mostly authentic tasting food. imperial rolls, soups and garlic noodles are amazing.
author: Alison O.

description: For some reason last week, I kept getting cravings for pho.  Last Friday I happened to be dropping off a coworker in Portrero when he mentioned a place close by that served pho.  Imagine my surprise!  I found this restaurant right across from goat hill pizza and it was completely packed!  The husband and I got the last table and were excited to see that pho was indeed on the menu.  Unfortunately, it seemed like one of those Asian places that wasn't too authentic.  We were practically the only Asians there.  There was only one beef noodle soup on the menu (wah?) and they didn't even have the red spicy and hoisin vietnamese sauces.  We also ordered a combo crispy egg noodle which I had thought was more of an HK dish.  The food was pretty good actually and was semi-authentic but I when I go for pho, I tend to go for the places that focus on the food more and not the ambiance so much.  The service was eh.  After we ordered the food, they took away our plates and utensils without a word because I guess we didn't order appetizers and then we had to flag them down for every little thing, including getting those plates back.  Also, we were kind of rushed through the process I'm guessing because they wanted to seat more people.  I would say this is a dependable neighborhood eatery with decent pho but I wouldn't travel far just to try it out.
author: Susan L.

description: very good food, nice and friendly staff, can be packed during lunch hour.
author: David F.

description: I started out eating at the restaurant in the Mission and when I saw they were opening up another location in my neighborhood I was psyched! The fresh spring rolls are great!  The Pho and the beef salad are my regulars.  I just discovered the Vietnamese Crape and that's yummy too!  I don't think you can go wrong with whatever you order.
author: Lana L.

description: Good value (quality meats and fresh vegies) for Pot Hill with classy environs! Celebrated a birthday and the birthday boy was happily satisfied.  We had the shaken beef, garlic noodles, imperial rolls, the sampler, etc ... All good. Better than the viet places in Nob Hill or Russian Hill. I didn't know what I was missing. Sunflower even has got a good malbec on the menu. It's one of the places that you'll end up craving.
author: Seymour S.

description: Sunflower is a nice addition to the mostly expensive restaurants on Potrero Hill. The price is reasonable. The food is standard American-Vietnamese fare you'd find all over the city, in other words it's decent and good value for the price. The service is not awesome, in fact, unless you know culturally what to expect, they can seem a little rude. But all that aside, Sunflower is a welcome change to the culinary gentrification of Potrero Hill - meaning, it's not all $$$ and French (which is nice too, but you need variety).
author: Patrick A.

description: is banh mi not authentic? don't spot it on the other location's menu which makes me sad. but everything else on their menu makes me mouth water! OPEN 'ER UP!
author: jizzie b.

description: This place is awesome on Mission/16th OR Potrero Hill. Just goes to show good Vietnamese food doesn't need to be fancy priced, though the new Potrero location has a swankier atmosphere than its grungy Mission sister,  and a few new upscale dishes too.  Standbys though for both include the fresh spring rolls (all of them are soooo tasty), the pho is excellent. Shaken beef and garlic noodles...yes please. So consistent, this place never disappoints for lunch or dinner.
author: Shannon B.

description: I got back from lunch at Sunflower and felt the need to review it while the experience was fresh in my mind. The most important thing about Sunflower for me is its convenience of being in my neighborhood.  The restaurant itself is clean and designed nicely.  They have a very comprehensive menu with a pick for every taste from yummy rolls to various noodle soups to main course dishes like 5 spice chicken (one of my favorites).  When I got there today, the place was packed and people were waiting outside for a table.  Once I finally got to sit down, I ordered the noodle soup with beef which is one of the main Vietnamese dishes (Pho). Although you can argue that the food may not be as traditional as places in Berkeley or San Jose, you can still have a tasty experience right here in San Francisco without having to drive so far! The staff is friendly and the food gets to your table fast and hot.  Overall I had a great experience but the only thing that I would caution you about is when the restaurant is full, they don't manage the wait list too well:  When I got there today, there was no written wait-list and they told me that it would take 30 minutes for a table to become available when in reality I got to sit down in 10.  Most people who are on a tight lunch schedule would have walked away when in reality the wait was manageable!
author: Alex S.

description: pretty good but nothing special. came here with a group of 5, shared two apps. spring rolls came out fast and were ok-- the shrimp tasted pretty badly overcooked but the peanut sauce was light and not too sweet. sunflower crepe was unremarkable. i got pan fried noodles that were good but tasted like takeout chinese with some fish sauce. tasty white-people food but nothing to write home about. there's much better, yummier, cheaper, and slightly dirtier vietnamese food in the tenderloin on larkin.
author: Dana D.

description: From the outside it looks like a funky fusion cuisine restaurant but inside it is pretty standard fare, unpretentious, good portion size. Been here twice, the pho is nice, the chicken curry is ok as well. Nothing special but a decent choice as there are not very many asian restaurants in this neighborhood, and nowhere in the immediate vicinity that you can get pho
author: adrian t.

description: I love the food here. I love the freshness and love the veg. spring roll-soo good!! This is my new favorite place in potrero besides Lingba!
author: e c.

description: The food here is very good - I get a lot of home cooked vietnamese food and am pretty discerning.  The lunch specials are yummy and a really good deal, with samplings of soup, rolls, a main dish, rice, etc.  I've found the service to be friendly too.
author: sf f.

description: great little restaurant in potrero hill. the ambiance was warm and romantic, food was delicious and portions were large and VERY reasonably priced. we had to wait about 15 min to be sat -- to be fair, we were there on a friday night at 7:30. 2 plates for two people  was more than enough food without having to order any sides of rice. the curry vegetables had a great flavor and weren't too mushy. that plate also had tofu which was a nice addition. lemongrass chicken is a must try. it was a plate of mostly chicken and green beans (again, with a little crisp, very fresh) and had delicious flavors, included an unexpected sugar coating every few bites that kept me hunting for more. nice, affordable wine list. i love sweet wines and they had a great assortments of whites in my taste. if you like chards though there was only one on the menu. service was very quick but we never felt rushed. perfect place for a date...even a first one :) i know i'll be back in the near future. $50 total for a good bottle of wine, 2 entrees, tax and tip.
author: theresa v.
